Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an off-season overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this off-season, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offence that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the off-season, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:47:00Z", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "source": {"uri": "edmontonsun.com", "title": "Edmonton Sun", "id": "1063"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:47:00", "url": "http://www.edmontonsun.com/2017/08/11/bills-trade-watkins-to-rams-get-matthews-from-eagles?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=recommend-button&utm_campaign=Bills trade Watkins to Rams; get Matthews from Eagles", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8698838", "image": "http://storage.edmontonsun.com/v1/suns-prod-images/1297981710589_LARGE_BOX.jpg?quality=80&stmp=1502481665265", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:47:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe Bills' shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins was a Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick out of Clemson. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in the offseason after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews was Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free agents Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason and drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson. Also, 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor has improved.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T22:18:00Z", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "source": {"uri": "richmond.com", "title": "Richmond Times-Dispatch", "id": "8528"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:26:00", "url": "http://www.richmond.com/ap/sports/bills-trade-watkins-to-rams-get-matthews-from-eagles/article_5dbeb00d-4702-5886-847a-0bbac52a1cfd.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8729410", "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/richmond.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/7d/57d09c51-a36b-5909-9ee6-e0ccfe42cd58/598e4c4ba404e.image.jpg?resize=972%2C630", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "22:18:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\nAP Pro Football Writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP Sports Writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:46:00Z", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "source": {"uri": "aurorasentinel.com", "title": "Aurora Sentinel", "id": "2965"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:46:00", "url": "http://www.aurorasentinel.com/sports/pro/bills-trade-watkins-rams-get-matthews-eagles/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8707068", "image": "http://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/aurorasentinel/asuplads/20170811153231/AP17222845771107.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with the Rams new coach Anthony Lynn, who spent the previous two seasons in Buffalo. Lynn started as the Bills receivers coach before being promoted to offensive coordinator last year and finished the season as the team's interim coach after Rex Ryan was fired a week before the final game.\n\nWatkins is also reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:05:00Z", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "source": {"uri": "greenvilleonline.com", "title": "The Greenville News", "id": "9130"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:05:00", "url": "http://www.greenvilleonline.com/story/sports/college/clemson/2017/08/11/bills-trade-sammy-watkins-los-angeles-rams/559943001/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8676111", "image": "https://www.gannett-cdn.com/GDContent/applogos/greenvilleonline.png", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:05:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 1, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Trumaine Johnson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trumaine_Johnson", "score": 2, "id": "540224", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kayvon Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 2, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:45:00Z", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", "title": "Chicago Tribune", "id": "1697"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:45:00", "url": "http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/ct-bills-trade-sammy-watkins-jordan-matthews-20170811-story.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8682418", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-598df709/turbine/ct-bills-trade-sammy-watkins-jordan-matthews-20170811", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:45:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

(AP) -- The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\n___\n\nAP Pro Football Writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP Sports Writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\nThis story has been corrected to remove an incorrect reference to Anthony Lynn, who coaches the Chargers, not the Rams.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:06:00Z", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "source": {"uri": "seattlepi.com", "title": "seattlepi.com", "id": "19267"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:06:00", "url": "http://www.seattlepi.com/sports/article/Eagles-trade-Jordan-Matthews-to-Bills-for-Ronald-11750822.php", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8685042", "image": "http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/64/12/72/13676193/3/rawImage.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:06:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alshon_Jeffery", "score": 2, "id": "361975", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "E. J. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 2, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Trumaine Johnson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trumaine_Johnson", "score": 3, "id": "540224", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anthony Lynn"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Lynn", "score": 2, "id": "1272578", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 1, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kayvon Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 3, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with the Rams new coach Anthony Lynn, who spent the previous two seasons in Buffalo. Lynn started as the Bills receivers coach before being promoted to offensive coordinator last year and finished the season as the team's interim coach after Rex Ryan was fired a week before the final game.\n\nWatkins is also reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\n___\n\nAP pro football writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP sports writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFor more NFL coverage: http://www.pro32.ap.org and http://www.twitter.com/AP_NFL\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 2, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Trumaine Johnson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trumaine_Johnson", "score": 3, "id": "540224", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "2015 NFL draft"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_NFL_draft", "score": 1, "id": "1272379", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 1, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kayvon Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 3, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. (AP) - The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\n___\n\nAP Pro Football Writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP Sports Writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\nThis story has been corrected to remove an incorrect reference to Anthony Lynn, who coaches the Chargers, not the Rams.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with the Rams new coach Anthony Lynn, who spent the previous two seasons in Buffalo. Lynn started as the Bills receivers coach before being promoted to offensive coordinator last year and finished the season as the team's interim coach after Rex Ryan was fired a week before the final game.\n\nWatkins is also reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 1, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Trumaine Johnson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trumaine_Johnson", "score": 3, "id": "540224", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 3, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anthony Lynn"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Lynn", "score": 2, "id": "1272578", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kayvon Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 3, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nOrchard Park, N.Y. -- The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with the Rams new coach Anthony Lynn, who spent the previous two seasons in Buffalo. Lynn started as the Bills receivers coach before being promoted to offensive coordinator last year and finished the season as the team's interim coach after Rex Ryan was fired a week before the final game.\n\nWatkins is also reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:00:00Z", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "source": {"uri": "detroitnews.com", "title": "The Detroit News", "id": "2989"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:00:00", "url": "http://www.detroitnews.com/story/sports/nfl/2017/08/11/bills-get-busy-make-two-blockbuster-trades/104501532/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8675382", "image": "https://www.gannett-cdn.com/-mm-/33a1c7f8ff82b84ddbf78889a687e707924d77cc/c=0-156-2338-1477&r=x803&c=1600x800/local/-/media/2017/08/11/DetroitNews/B99563967Z.1_20170811134720_000_GUO1JO5OM.1-0.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:00:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

(AP) -- The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\n___\n\nAP Pro Football Writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP Sports Writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFor more NFL coverage: http://www.pro32.ap.org and http://www.twitter.com/AP_NFL\n\n___\n\nThis story has been corrected to remove an incorrect reference to Anthony Lynn, who coaches the Chargers, not the Rams.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:29:00Z", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "source": {"uri": "boston.com", "title": "Boston.com", "id": "318"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:29:00", "url": "https://www.boston.com/sports/nfl/2017/08/11/bills-trade-sammy-watkins-to-rams", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8696359", "image": "https://www.boston.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Vikings_Bills_Football_71107-850x478.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:29:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 1, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Trumaine Johnson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trumaine_Johnson", "score": 3, "id": "540224", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anthony Lynn"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Lynn", "score": 2, "id": "1272578", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 1, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kayvon Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 3, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with the Rams new coach Anthony Lynn, who spent the previous two seasons in Buffalo. Lynn started as the Bills receivers coach before being promoted to offensive coordinator last year and finished the season as the team's interim coach after Rex Ryan was fired a week before the final game.\n\nWatkins is also reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\n___\n\nAP pro football writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP sports writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:03:00Z", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "source": {"uri": "timesunion.com", "title": "Times Union", "id": "653"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:03:00", "url": "http://www.timesunion.com/sports/article/Eagles-trade-Jordan-Matthews-to-Bills-for-Ronald-11750822.php", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8675731", "image": "http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/64/12/72/13676193/3/rawImage.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:03:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

(AP) - The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with the Rams new coach Anthony Lynn, who spent the previous two seasons in Buffalo. Lynn started as the Bills receivers coach before being promoted to offensive coordinator last year and finished the season as the team's interim coach after Rex Ryan was fired a week before the final game.\n\nWatkins is also reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\n___\n\nAP pro football writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP sports writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an off-season overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this off-season, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offence that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the off-season, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nLatest NFL stories Cowboys' Elliott suspended six games Top 20 fantasy football wide receivers in 2017 Jets face questions beyond just QB competition Top 20 fantasy football runnings backs in 2017 Jets' Powell out, Forte iffy for preseason opener\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nadvertisement | advertise on newsday\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with the Rams new coach Anthony Lynn, who spent the previous two seasons in Buffalo. Lynn started as the Bills receivers coach before being promoted to offensive coordinator last year and finished the season as the team's interim coach after Rex Ryan was fired a week before the final game.\n\nWatkins is also reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\n___\n\nAP pro football writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP sports writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFor more NFL coverage: http://www.pro32.ap.org and http://www.twitter.com/AP_NFL\n\n2 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 1, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Trumaine Johnson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trumaine_Johnson", "score": 3, "id": "540224", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anthony Lynn"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Lynn", "score": 2, "id": "1272578", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 1, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kayvon Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 3, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills shook up their roster with two separate blockbuster trades Friday, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills acquired cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\n\u00d7 Advertisement\n\nThe moves were made day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills in May declined to pick up his fifth-year option. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nThe Rams need playmakers for an offense that finished last in the NFL over the past two seasons. Watkins can be that type of dynamic threat when healthy.\n\nWatkins had been the Bills starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nHe's been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. Watkins required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nIn Los Angeles, Watkins is reunited with the Rams new coach Anthony Lynn, who spent the previous two seasons in Buffalo. Lynn started as the Bills receivers coach before being promoted to offensive coordinator last year and finished the season as the team's interim coach after Rex Ryan was fired a week before the final game.\n\nWatkins is also reunited with former Bills starter Robert Woods, who signed with the Rams in free agency after four seasons in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills continue revamping their receiver group, with Matthews' acquisition coming four days after Buffalo signed veteran free agent Anquan Boldin.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\n-- -- --\n\nAP pro football writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP sports writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\n-- -- --\n\nFor more NFL coverage: http://www.pro32.ap.org and http://www.twitter.com/AP -- NFL", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:21:00Z", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "source": {"uri": "idahostatejournal.com", "title": "Idaho State Journal", "id": "5921"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:21:00", "url": "http://idahostatejournal.com/sports/national/bills-trade-watkins-to-rams-get-matthews-from-eagles/article_de694648-afe1-5290-9ed9-681c1c67cf9a.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8678595", "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/idahostatejournal.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/75/6757a59c-2178-5e20-85c3-4764bbe13377/598deb8b736c0.image.jpg?resize=512%2C380", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:21:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Buffalo addressed both positions by acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia and cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nThe Bills also continued looking to the future by further stockpiling 2018 draft selections. They acquired a second-round pick from L.A. and a third-rounder from the Eagles, while also sending a sixth-round pick to the Rams. Buffalo now has two picks in each of the first three rounds next year after acquiring the Kansas City Chiefs first-round selection in April.\n\nThe additional picks provide Bills general manager Brandon Beane assets in a draft that looks as if it will have several top-end quarterback prospects. Bills starter Tyrod Taylor's future is uncertain beyond this season.\n\nMcDermott acknowledged his most difficult challenge was not merely breaking the news of Watkins' departure to Taylor.\n\n\"I'll take it a step further: How do you sell it to the entire team?\" McDermott said, before outlining his message.\n\n\"You put one step in front of the other and we move on,\" he said. \"I asked them to continue to trust me and our decisions in terms of what we're doing.\"\n\nJust don't call it a rebuilding plan , Beane said.\n\n\"This is not a throw-in-the-towel thing at all,\" Beane said. \"If we were throwing in the towel, I wouldn't be trying to get that starting receiver back.\"\n\nThe deals, however, involve more changes to a team with just 28 players who opened training camp on Buffalo's roster a year ago. The Bills also have just 14 players whom they've drafted, not including this year's six-player class.\n\nThe trades caught Bills players by surprise a day after a 17-10 preseason-opening loss to Minnesota.\n\n\"It's tough to lose a guy like Sammy,\" Taylor said. \"We have to put a positive lining. It's a win-now league. And as a team, we have to refocus, do whatever it takes to win games.\"\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills declined to pick up his fifth-year contract option in May. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract.\n\nWhen healthy, Watkins showed glimpses of being a dynamic threat since Buffalo gave up a 2015 first-round pick to trade up five spots and select him fourth overall in 2014. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nWatkins has been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last season after having surgery for a broken left foot. He required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nHe joins a revamped group of receivers on a Rams offense that has ranked last in the NFL in each of the past two seasons.\n\nBuffalo is also retooling its receiver position, with the trade coming four days after signing veteran free agent Anquan Boldin .\n\nMatthews was Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith and drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson.\n\nThe key for Philadelphia was adding a starting-caliber cornerback in Darby to a defense that plays in the pass-happy NFC East.\n\n\"It's a corner-deficient league. It's hard to find those guys,\" Eagles executive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman said. \"And teams that have them aren't really ready to move them.\"\n\nDarby started 29 games since the Bills selected him in the second round of the 2015 draft.\n\nGaines was a valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015, but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nMcDermott is aware how the trades have the potential of setting back Buffalo's preparedness at a time the franchise is in the midst of a 17-year playoff drought -- the longest active streak in North America's four major professional sports.\n\n\"I'm invested. I know and feel what they feel,\" McDermott said, referring to Bills fans. \"We're building a football team that we want to compete in the short and long term and be good for a long time. Sometimes that's a day-to-day process, and sometimes those are not easy decisions.\"\n\nNOTES: S Bacarri Rambo is listed week to week after hurting his hamstring against Minnesota. ... The Bills are off Saturday before returning to training camp on Sunday. ... Matthews and Darby will get to face their former teams on Thursday, when the Bills travel to play Philadelphia in a preseason game.\n\n___\n\nAP Pro Football Writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP Sports Writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T00:13:00Z", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "source": {"uri": "sanluisobispo.com", "title": "The Tribune", "id": "9482"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:02:00", "url": "http://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/business/article166714557.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8775029", "image": "http://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/vttvua/picture166718317/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/Vikings_Bills_Football_71107.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "00:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

They acquired a second-round pick from L.A. and a third-rounder from the Eagles, while also sending a sixth-round pick to the Rams. Buffalo now has two picks in each of the first three rounds next year after acquiring the Kansas City Chiefs first-round selection in April.\n\nThe additional picks provide Bills general manager Brandon Beane assets in a draft that looks as if it will have several top-end quarterback prospects. Bills starter Tyrod Taylor's future is uncertain beyond this season.\n\nMcDermott acknowledged his most difficult challenge was not merely breaking the news of Watkins' departure to Taylor.\n\n\"I'll take it a step further: How do you sell it to the entire team?\" McDermott said, before outlining his message.\n\n\"You put one step in front of the other and we move on,\" he said. \"I asked them to continue to trust me and our decisions in terms of what we're doing.\"\n\nJust don't call it a rebuilding plan , Beane said.\n\n\"This is not a throw-in-the-towel thing at all,\" Beane said. \"If we were throwing in the towel, I wouldn't be trying to get that starting receiver back.\"\n\nThe deals, however, involve more changes to a team with just 28 players who opened training camp on Buffalo's roster a year ago. The Bills also have just 14 players whom they've drafted, not including this year's six-player class.\n\nThe trades caught Bills players by surprise a day after a 17-10 preseason-opening loss to Minnesota.\n\n\"It's tough to lose a guy like Sammy,\" Taylor said. \"We have to put a positive lining. It's a win-now league. And as a team, we have to refocus, do whatever it takes to win games.\"\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills declined to pick up his fifth-year contract option in May. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract.\n\nWhen healthy, Watkins showed glimpses of being a dynamic threat since Buffalo gave up a 2015 first-round pick to trade up five spots and select him fourth overall in 2014. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nWatkins has been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last season after having surgery for a broken left foot. He required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nHe joins a revamped group of receivers on a Rams offense that has ranked last in the NFL in each of the past two seasons.\n\nBuffalo is also retooling its receiver position, with the trade coming four days after signing veteran free agent Anquan Boldin .\n\nMatthews was Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith and drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson.\n\nThe key for Philadelphia was adding a starting-caliber cornerback in Darby to a defense that plays in the pass-happy NFC East.\n\n\"It's a corner-deficient league. It's hard to find those guys,\" Eagles executive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman said. \"And teams that have them aren't really ready to move them.\"\n\nDarby started 29 games since the Bills selected him in the second round of the 2015 draft.\n\nGaines was a valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015, but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nMcDermott is aware how the trades have the potential of setting back Buffalo's preparedness at a time the franchise is in the midst of a 17-year playoff drought -- the longest active streak in North America's four major professional sports.\n\n\"I'm invested. I know and feel what they feel,\" McDermott said, referring to Bills fans. \"We're building a football team that we want to compete in the short and long term and be good for a long time. Sometimes that's a day-to-day process, and sometimes those are not easy decisions.\"\n\nNOTES: S Bacarri Rambo is listed week to week after hurting his hamstring against Minnesota. ... The Bills are off Saturday before returning to training camp on Sunday. ... Matthews and Darby will get to face their former teams on Thursday, when the Bills travel to play Philadelphia in a preseason game.\n\n___\n\nAP Pro Football Writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP Sports Writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFor more NFL coverage: http://www.pro32.ap.org and http://www.twitter.com/AP_NFL", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "source": {"uri": "bostonherald.com", "title": "Boston Herald", "id": "2238"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:41:00", "url": "http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/patriots/2017/08/bills_trade_watkins_to_rams_get_matthews_from_eagles", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8772526", "image": "http://www.bostonherald.com/sites/default/files/styles/full/public/media/ap/2016/11/11/70eb2f53fa3a427b8bd11bee45e0c144.jpg?itok=NHfGqxmD", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nORCHARD PARK, N.Y. -- The Buffalo Bills' offseason overhaul isn't over yet with receiver Sammy Watkins and cornerback Ronald Darby the latest players to be sent packing.\n\nThe Bills dealt both starters in separate blockbuster trades on Friday as part of an effort to reshape the roster under new coach Sean McDermott.\n\nWatkins was traded to the Los Angeles Rams, while Darby was sent to the Philadelphia Eagles. Buffalo addressed both positions by acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia and cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nThe Bills also continued looking to the future by further stockpiling 2018 draft selections. They acquired a second-round pick from L.A. and a third-rounder from the Eagles, while also sending a sixth-round pick to the Rams. Add in the acquisition of the Kansas Chiefs' first-round pick in trade completed in April, and the Bills now have two picks in each of the first three rounds next year.\n\nThe additional picks provide Bills new general manager Brandon Beane assets in a draft that looks like it will have several top-end quarterback prospects. Bills starter Tyrod Taylor's future is uncertain beyond this year.\n\nBeane disputed the notion he's strictly looking ahead to next year.\n\n\"This is not a throw-in-the-towel thing at all,\" Beane said. \"If we were throwing in the towel, I wouldn't be trying to get that starting receiver back.\"\n\nThe deals, however, involve more changes to a team with just 28 players who opened training camp on Buffalo's roster a year ago. The Bills also have just 14 players whom they've drafted, not including this year's six-player class.\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills declined to pick up his fifth-year contract option in May. He is entering the final year of his deal. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract, so the Eagles also faced the possibility of losing him in free agency.\n\nWatkins showed glimpses of being a dynamic threat when healthy in three seasons with Buffalo since being selected in the first round of the 2014 draft. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nWatkins has been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last year after having surgery to repair a broken left foot. He required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nHe joins a revamped group of receivers on a Rams offense that has ranked last in the NFL in each of the past two seasons.\n\nThe change for the Bills came four days after signing veteran free agent Anquan Boldin. Matthews was Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith and drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\nThough he wasn't shopping either player, Beane said he first began receiving inquiries about Watkins in June. The Eagles' interest in Darby then developed later and both deals began falling into place over the past week.\n\nHe presented both trades to McDermott and owner Terry Pegula on Thursday night, following Buffalo's preseason-opening 17-10 loss to Minnesota.\n\nMcDermott said he had little sleep after spending much of the night attending meetings and going over the pros and cons of the two trades.\n\nHe's also aware of how two new additions have the potential of setting back the team's preparedness for the start of the regular season at a time the franchise is in the midst of a 17-year playoff drought -- the longest active streak in North America's four major professional sports.\n\n\"I'm invested. I know and feel what they feel,\" McDermott said, referring to Bills fans. \"We're building a football team that we want to compete in the short- and long-term and be good for a long time. Sometimes that's a day to day process, and sometimes those are not easy decisions.\"\n\nBuffalo's secondary will be completely revamped minus Darby. The Bills lost starter Stephon Gilmore and third-stringer Nickell Robey-Coleman in free agency and also released both starting safeties, Aaron Williams and Corey Graham.\n\nGaines was valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015 but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nNOTES: S Bacarri Rambo is listed week to week after hurting his hamstring against Minnesota. ... The Bills are off Saturday before returning to training camp on Sunday.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:17:00Z", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "source": {"uri": "goerie.com", "title": "GoErie.com - Erie, PA", "id": "813"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:51:00", "url": "http://www.goerie.com/sports/20170811/bills-trade-watkins-to-rams-get-matthews-from-eagles", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8731300", "image": "http://www.goerie.com/storyimage/PA/20170811/SPORTS/170819796/AR/0/AR-170819796.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:17:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"337440", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tyrod Taylor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrod_Taylor", "score": 3, "id": "357144", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sammy Watkins
