Jr."}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odell_Beckham_Jr.", "score": 3, "id": "1270484", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 2, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "When the Philadelphia Eagles play the Buffalo Bills in a preseason game at Lincoln Financial Field on Thursday, wide receiver Jordan Matthews will be on the visitor's sideline.\n\nA lack of reliable players at cornerback and a surplus of wide receivers prompted the Eagles to trade Matthews and a 2018 third-round draft pick to the Bills in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nMatthews, the Eagles' second-round pick in 2014, was among the most productive receivers in NFL history in his first three seasons. The 6-foot-3, 205-pounder had 225 receptions for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns. According to the Eagles, he was one of only five receivers in the league with at least 65 receptions and 800 receiving yards in each of his first three seasons. The others were Odell Beckham Jr., Mike Evans, A.J. Green and Randy Moss.\n\nLatest Video\n\n\"Since the day we drafted him, Jordan has been an unbelievable teammate, hard worker and obviously incredibly productive,\" Eagles Vice President of Football Operations Howie Roseman said in a news conference streamed on the team's website. \"It's hard to pull the trigger on a trade like that when you're giving up that kind of player and person.\n\n\"A lot of priorities go into building a team that consistently competes for championships, and having a group of cornerbacks that are young and can grow together is very important. We wish Jordan all the best, but we did what we thought was best for our team going forward.\"\n\nThe new guy\n\nDarby, the Bills' second-round draft pick in 2015, appeared in 29 games for Buffalo over the last two seasons. The 5-11, 190-pounder had two interceptions and 137 tackles.\n\nHe joins a secondary that lacks top-notch cornerbacks. Darby, 23, is expected to immediately start for the Eagles, leaving Jalen Mills, Patrick Robinson, rookie Rasul Douglas and Ron Brooks to compete for two other spots. Rookie Sidney Jones could also become a factor when he's recovered from a ruptured Achilles tendon.\n\nBrooks, who was in line to be the Eagles' slot corner this season, suffered a hamstring injury in the Eagles' 24-9 loss at Green Bay on Thursday night.\n\n\"This is a passing-driven league,\" Roseman said. \"People are spreading you out (on defense) with three- and four-wide receiver packages. (The trade) was a unique opportunity to have a bunch of young corners at that position. It's hard to find solid starters.\"\n\nMatthews, who has one year left on his contract, became expendable after the Eagles upgraded their wide receivers during the offseason.\n\nThey signed free agents Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith and then drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson. Nelson Agholor, the Eagles' first-round draft pick in 2015, has been a standout during training camp after two disappointing seasons.\n\n\"You look at wide receiver group as a whole and how they performed throughout the spring, and the competition has been encouraging,\" Roseman said. \"Looking at that group, we have bunch of young players we're excited about.\"\n\nPopular among Eagles\n\nBy trading Matthews, 25, the Eagles lost one of their locker room leaders, however.\n\nAlong with quarterback Carson Wentz and tight end Zach Ertz, he was among the most popular teammates.\n\nThat was reflected in the reaction of some of the players on Twitter when the trade was announced.\n\n\"Crazy part of this business,\" Wentz tweeted. \"(Matthews) you'll always be my boy both on & off the field. Couldn't ask for a better teammate & friend.\"\n\n\"Honestly don't think a teammate had a bigger impact on my life,\" Ertz wrote. \"Going to miss going to battle with (Matthews) on Sunday! Love you bro!\"\n\nIn Buffalo, Jordan will be reunited with running back LeSean McCoy, who was his Eagles teammate in 2014 before being traded to the Bills.\n\nDarby was teammates in Buffalo in 2015 with Eagles linebacker Nigel Bradham and Brooks. Darby has two years remaining on his contract.\n\n\"It hurts when people you care about leave,\" Roseman said. \"The hardest part was talking to Jordan about it. However good he is as a player, he's a better person. But we have to do what's best in moving forward.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:20:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"uri": "pressofatlanticcity.com", "title": "Press of Atlantic City", "id": "9805"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:34:00", "url": "http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/eagles-trade-jordan-matthews-and-draft-pick-for-corrnerback/article_01db864a-7eb8-11e7-b996-531a34995b3e.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8791496", "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pressofatlanticcity.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/0/1d/01dc3914-7eb8-11e7-b997-3344eb632d29/598de512ccf65.image.jpg?crop=533%2C400%2C33%2C0&resize=533%2C400&order=crop%2Cresize", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:20:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 1, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 2, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "2014 NFL draft"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_NFL_draft", "score": 3, "id": "1272372", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "While the NFL preseason has just started, it looks like the Buffalo Bills are making some moves. The latest Bills news and rumors have indicated that the team participated in two different trades as of Friday. One of those trades sent their receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams. In a separate deal, the Buffalo Bills traded away their best cornerback for the Eagles' Jordan Matthews. Both of the deals might give a good sign of the direction that the Buffalo Bills are heading in for the future. Here are the latest details on these two different NFL trade reports as they have happened.\n\nAccording to Bleacher Report on Friday, the Bills' trade involves sending away wide receiver Sammy Watkins and a 2018 pick in the sixth round to the Los Angeles Rams. In exchange, Buffalo is getting cornerback E.J. Gaines and a 2018 second-round pick from the deal. The move seems shocking to many fans as the team made a big trade to go up to No. 4 in the 2014 NFL Draft to acquire him. However, Watkins was hobbled over the 2016 season with a foot injury. He played in just half of the games of the season, racking up just 28 receptions for 430 yards and two touchdowns scored.\n\nThe Sammy Watkins trade wasn't all the Buffalo Bills had in store for their roster, though. Shortly after that news hit, the team traded for Philadelphia Eagles wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round pick. In exchange, the Bills sent away cornerback Ronald Darby, according to ESPN. Darby was considered their top cornerback on the depth chart.\n\nMatthews, who like Watkins is also in just his fourth season, had 73 receptions for 804 yards and three touchdowns in the 2016 season. Over his career, he's had 225 catches for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns. It would seem that this separate trade brings in a new potential top receiver for the team's depth chart heading into their upcoming season.\n\nWith these two deals, the Buffalo Bills have now traded two of their top players at their respective positions, which might signal a rebuild is in progress. In exchange for Watkins and Darby, they did acquire needed position players but also two future draft picks. Buffalo will now have two picks in each of the first three rounds of the 2018 NFL Draft.\n\nThe 2017 season will be the Bills' first under first-year general manager Brandon Beane and coach Sean McDermott. For the 2016 NFL season, Buffalo finished with a record of 7-9 overall but seemed to have a roster that may have been on the rise. Now it looks like that roster will be built in a new direction in the coming seasons.\n\n[Featured Image by Tom Szczerbowski/Getty Images]", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:04:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"uri": "inquisitr.com", "title": "The Inquisitr News", "id": "2639"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:04:00", "url": "http://www.inquisitr.com/4426117/buffalo-bills-news-rumors-team-trades-sammy-watkins-to-rams-gets-jordan-matthews-from-eagles/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8684731", "image": "http://cdn.inquisitr.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/buffalo-bills-news-sammy-watkins-traded-to-rams-jordan-matthews-from-eagles.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:04:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

The Bills dealt Ronald Darby to the Eagles and acquired E.J. Gaines in the trade with the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by acquiring a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were announced early Friday afternoon, a day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. The shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nMatthews had been Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in the offseason, drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson and have been pleased with 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor's improvement.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. Buffalo addressed both positions by acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia and cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nThe Bills also continued looking to the future by further stockpiling 2018 draft selections. They acquired a second-round pick from L.A. and a third-rounder from the Eagles, while also sending a sixth-round pick to the Rams. Buffalo now has two picks in each of the first three rounds next year after acquiring the Kansas City Chiefs first-round selection in April.\n\nThe additional picks provide Bills general manager Brandon Beane assets in a draft that looks as if it will have several top-end quarterback prospects. Bills starter Tyrod Taylor's future is uncertain beyond this season.\n\nMcDermott acknowledged his most difficult challenge was not merely breaking the news of Watkins' departure to Taylor.\n\n\"I'll take it a step further: How do you sell it to the entire team?\" McDermott said, before outlining his message.\n\n\"You put one step in front of the other and we move on,\" he said. \"I asked them to continue to trust me and our decisions in terms of what we're doing.\"\n\nJust don't call it a rebuilding plan , Beane said.\n\n\"This is not a throw-in-the-towel thing at all,\" Beane said. \"If we were throwing in the towel, I wouldn't be trying to get that starting receiver back.\"\n\nThe deals, however, involve more changes to a team with just 28 players who opened training camp on Buffalo's roster a year ago. The Bills also have just 14 players whom they've drafted, not including this year's six-player class.\n\nThe trades caught Bills players by surprise a day after a 17-10 preseason-opening loss to Minnesota.\n\n\"It's tough to lose a guy like Sammy,\" Taylor said. \"We have to put a positive lining. It's a win-now league. And as a team, we have to refocus, do whatever it takes to win games.\"\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills declined to pick up his fifth-year contract option in May. Matthews is also entering the final season of his contract.\n\nWhen healthy, Watkins showed glimpses of being a dynamic threat since Buffalo gave up a 2015 first-round pick to trade up five spots and select him fourth overall in 2014. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons, but topped 1,000 yards just once, in 2015.\n\nWatkins has been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last season after having surgery for a broken left foot. He required a second operation in January after aggravating the injury last season.\n\nHe joins a revamped group of receivers on a Rams offense that has ranked last in the NFL in each of the past two seasons.\n\nBuffalo is also retooling its receiver position, with the trade coming four days after signing veteran free agent Anquan Boldin .\n\nMatthews was Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith and drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson.\n\nThe key for Philadelphia was adding a starting-caliber cornerback in Darby to a defense that plays in the pass-happy NFC East.\n\n\"It's a corner-deficient league. It's hard to find those guys,\" Eagles executive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman said. \"And teams that have them aren't really ready to move them.\"\n\nDarby started 29 games since the Bills selected him in the second round of the 2015 draft.\n\nGaines was a valuable defensive back in the Rams' rotation. He won a starting job in 2015, but then got hurt before the season started. He became expendable after the Rams acquired Kayvon Webster this offseason, who is pegged to start opposite Trumaine Johnson.\n\nMcDermott is aware how the trades have the potential of setting back Buffalo's preparedness at a time the franchise is in the midst of a 17-year playoff drought - the longest active streak in North America's four major professional sports.\n\n\"I'm invested. I know and feel what they feel,\" McDermott said, referring to Bills fans. \"We're building a football team that we want to compete in the short and long term and be good for a long time. Sometimes that's a day-to-day process, and sometimes those are not easy decisions.\"\n\nNOTES: S Bacarri Rambo is listed week to week after hurting his hamstring against Minnesota. ... The Bills are off Saturday before returning to training camp on Sunday. ... Matthews and Darby will get to face their former teams on Thursday, when the Bills travel to play Philadelphia in a preseason game.\n\n___\n\nAP Pro Football Writer Rob Maaddi in Philadelphia and AP Sports Writer Greg Beacham in Los Angeles contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFor more NFL coverage: http://www.pro32.ap.org and http://www.twitter.com/AP_NFL", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:44:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"uri": "wsoctv.com", "title": "WSOC", "id": "497"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:44:00", "url": "http://www.wsoctv.com/sports/eagles-trade-jordan-matthews-to-bills-for-ronald-darby/588609101", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8730712", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The simplest distillation of the Philadelphia Eagles trade of Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick to the Buffalo Bills for Ronald Darby is this: The move alleviates a glut at one position and brings help to another that was dangerously thing entering training camp.\n\nOf course, there's always much more to it than just that, so here's a breakdown of how the trade impacts the Eagles at both positions moving forward.\n\nPhiladelphia Eagles trade WR Jordan Matthews to Buffalo Bills for CB Ronald Darby\n\nWide receiver\n\nMatthews was the most productive member of the wide receiver corps last year with 73 catches for 804 yards and three touchdowns. Nelson Agholor struggled. Dorial Green-Beckham was untapped potential. Running back Darren Sproles had a more significant role in the passing game in Carson Wentz's rookie season.\n\nSo in the offseason, the group underwent a significant teardown. Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith were signed in free agency. Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson were drafted. Green-Beckham was released. And as Matthews battled a knee injury in camp, Agholor started to impress, especially in spelling Matthews in the slot.\n\nThe Eagles carried only five wide receivers for much of last season. If they do it again, there are still some tough decisions left on the horizon.\n\nIt was becoming clear that there wouldn't be enough passes from Wentz to go around.\n\nSo shedding Matthews elevates Agholor to the projected starter in the slot -- the Eagles official site already has him at first string -- with Jeffery and Smith on the outside. Marcus Johnson, a 23-year-old out of Texas who spent last season on the practice squad, has been impressive in camp and might be in line for a spot.\n\nHollins has been impressive in camp and had a 38-yard touchdown catch-and-run that featured a fearsome stiff arm in the preseason opener. Bryce Treggs, a speedy deep threat, was the Birds' leading receiver with seven catches for 91 yards with a long of 38 yards.\n\nSo the top five wide receivers would appear to be Jeffery, Smith, Agholor, Johnson and Hollins. Treggs and Gibson could be on the bubble depending on how they perform the rest of the preseason and how the Eagles decide to structure their roster.\n\nSo what it means in a nutshell: Agholor will start, and a wide receiver who might have been a numbers casualty has a job in Philadelphia.\n\nHowie Roseman: 'Unique opportunity' led to Philadelphia Eagles trade of Jordan Matthews for Ronald Darby\n\nCornerback\n\nExecutive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman said Darby was an intriguing trade target because he's only 23 years old and under team control for another two years on his rookie contract. It puts the Eagles in the unique position of having five cornerbacks -- Darby, Jalen Mills, C.J. Smith, Rasul Douglas and the injured Sidney Jones -- under the age of 25 who could start for them.\n\nRoseman called the NFL \"corner-deficient,\" and he's not wrong. It's becoming one of the positions where a team can never have too many.\n\nSo the Eagles instantly got younger and more experienced -- a rare combo -- in one swoop.\n\nThe ripple effect of adding Darby is a little cloudier than that of subtracting Matthews.\n\nDarby has started all 29 games he's been healthy for in the first two years of his career, so it's not unreasonable to pencil him as the starter. But does that mean Mills of veteran Patrick Robinson, a 29-year-old the Birds signed in free agency, bump down to the No. 3 spot? And then what happens to Ron Brooks, who started last season as the Eagles' slot corner before suffering a season-ending quad injury in October.\n\nJones, a second-round pick who may or may not play this season after tearing his Achilles' tendon in March, and Douglas, a third-round pick, seem like definitely parts of the Eagles' plans. Those two, combined with Mills, Robinson and Darby give the Birds a stable of five cornerbacks. If Jones doesn't play this season, maybe Smith can slide up into a contributing role.\n\nBut where does that leave Brooks and third-stringer Aaron Grymes?\n\nIt's clear that the Eagles are going to need plenty of able cornerbacks given the competition they're going to face in the NFC East, but the question becomes which cornerbacks will the Eagles put on the field. There's plenty of mixing and matching to do over the next couple weeks.\n\nSo what it means in a nutshell: This competition got a whole lot more interesting.\n\nMeet new Philadelphia Eagles cornerback Ronald Darby, with Howie Roseman's scouting report\n\nOverall impact\n\nIt's clear the Eagles paid a stiff price for Darby. Matthews was historically productive -- 225 catches for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns in his first three seasons -- in Philadelphia, and Agholor is no sure thing despite the strides he's made in camp.\n\nA third-round pick is also an asset that shouldn't be overlooked. Douglas figures into the Eagles plans this season, and he was their third-round pick in April. In 2018, the Eagles already gave up their second-round pick to Cleveland when they traded up to select Carson Wentz. Now the third-round pick will be in Buffalo. They do have three fourth-rounders -- one of which could become a third-rounder if Eric Rowe plays 50 percent of the New England Patriots' defensive snaps this season -- but not having a second or third-rounder is a tough situation, especially for a team that's trying to build around a franchise quarterback.\n\nWhat it means in a nutshell: The Eagles might have gotten better, but they definitely got a lot more interesting.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T09:54:00Z", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "source": {"uri": "pennlive.com", "title": "PennLive.com", "id": "371"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:16:00", "url": "http://www.pennlive.com/philadelphiaeagles/index.ssf/2017/08/what_the_jordan_matthews-ronal.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8808855", "image": "http://image.pennlive.com/home/penn-media/width620/img/philadelphiaeagles_impact/photo/23221556-standard.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "09:54:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "LeSean McCoy"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LeSean_McCoy", "score": 2, "id": "409985", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Howie Roseman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howie_Roseman", "score": 3, "id": "571949", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 5, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 2, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Trading a returning top receiver a month before the season starts is an unusual move. Receiving a promising young player with multiple years left on his contract at a premium position is just as rare.\n\nAnd so that's why Philadelphia Eagles executive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman decided to \"pull the trigger\" on the deal that sent Eagles wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick in next year's draft to the Buffalo Bills for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\n\"This is a unique opportunity,\" Roseman told reporters Friday afternoon.\n\nPhiladelphia Eagles trade WR Jordan Matthews to Buffalo Bills for CB Ronald Darby\n\nThe Eagles gave up a receiver who had been historically productive in his first three years in the NFL. Matthews caught 67 passes for 872 yards and eight touchdowns last season and seemed poise to be team's starting slot receiver this fall. But Matthews was also a pending free agent, and whether or not he would re-sign -- or if the Eagles could afford to re-sign him -- was still up in the air.\n\nIn return, the Eagles got a 23-year-old cornerback who had a stellar rookie season before regressing. Darby has two years left on his rookie contract, which gives the Birds time to see how he fits in with the team and the development of the other young corners on the roster.\n\nThe Eagles entered the offseason incredibly thin at corner. They added veteran Patrick Robinson in free agency as a stopgap before selecting the injured Sidney Jones and Rasul Douglas in the draft. Now Darby's in the mix. Suddenly, the Eagles have five cornerbacks under the age of 25 who could potentially start for them in Darby (23), Jones (21), Douglas (23), Jalen Mills (23) and C.J. Smith (24).\n\n\"It's kind of a unique opportunity to have a bunch of young corners at that position, and we spent a lot of time going over this because this is obviously a big trade for our football team,\" Roseman said. \"You look around the league, and it is a corner-deficient league. It is hard to find those guys.\"\n\nPhiladelphia Eagles react to trade of Jordan Matthews to Buffalo Bills\n\nThe control over a young player was important to Roseman in the trade. He said he wouldn't have made the trade if he was getting a free agent in return. The front office won't have to worry about re-signing Darby until 2019, and the Eagles will have a better idea if he's the player who was Pro Football Focus' defensive rookie of the year in 2015 or the one who struggled last year.\n\nRoseman said once Matthews' name surfaced in the media in trade rumors, teams started reaching out about trading for Matthews. When Darby's name came up from the Bills, it piqued the Eagles' interest.\n\n\"We were not out there shopping Jordan Matthews,\" Roseman said.\n\n\"We weren't picking up the phone and calling teams on Jordan because of his value to our team,\" Roseman added. \"Certainly, we know the production he had. It goes to the player that we got, the position that we're acquiring and how difficult it is to find those guys.\"\n\n4 Philadelphia Eagles who shined, 4 who struggled against Packers\n\nWith Matthews joining another former Eagle skill position player up north in LeSean McCoy, third-year pro Nelson Agholor seems poised to step up into the spot vacated by Matthews in the slot. Agholor, along with Marcus Johnson, has been impressive in camp and helps lessen the blow of the trade. Of course, Agholor will have to avoid a repeat of last year's disastrous performance to help replace Matthews' production alongside free-agent signees Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith.\n\n\"Obviously, Nelson's had a really good spring, and really, the young players have taken a step up, which is a great testament to our coaching staff,\" Roseman said. \"We're excited about some of their futures, and when we looked at it, we were concerned if we could keep a bunch of them, but by the same token, we knew that it was an opportunity to add to our back end, which is an important part of our football team.\"\n\nThe trade has a deep impact on two positions that were most in need of a revamp after last season. Whether it works out for either side will play out on the field this fall and beyond.\n\n\"There's no insurance on any of these things,\" Roseman said. \"We do what's in the best interest of the team, and then when you pull the trigger on anything like this, you think about the player you're giving up and the draft pick, but we felt like this was the best decision for us.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:13:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"uri": "pennlive.com", "title": "PennLive.com", "id": "371"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:03:00", "url": "http://www.pennlive.com/philadelphiaeagles/index.ssf/2017/08/howie_roseman_unique_opportuni.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8775061", "image": "http://image.pennlive.com/home/penn-media/width620/img/philadelphiaeagles_impact/photo/23218940-standard.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 4, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 2, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 3, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carson Wentz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 3, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "In wake of the Buffalo Bills' preseason opener, general manager Brandon Beane already has an eye toward the organization's future. That future comes at a certain cost and in the Bills' case that included wide receiver Sammy Watkins, who the Bills once considered their franchise superstar.\n\nOn Friday, Beane announced that Watkins -- along with a 2018 sixth-round pick -- was heading to the Los Angeles Rams in exchange for E.J. Gaines and a 2018 second round pick.\n\nSIGN UP to watch every Bills game this season on DAZN\n\nWatkins, the fourth overall pick in 2014, had been long plagued by injuries throughout his professional career -- especially in 2016 where he missed the last eight games with a foot fracture.\n\nThe Bills declined Watkins' option in May, thus igniting the inevitable end of his tenure in Buffalo. Watkins was set to make over $13 million if the Bills were to keep him. As a result of the trade, Buffalo avoids Watkins' immense payday.\n\nLast season, Gaines struggled in his first year since a foot related injury. According to Pro Football Focus, Gaines allowed nine touchdowns. It was the most that a cornerback has allowed all season.\n\nMORE: Bills happy with start\n\nAlmost simultaneously, the Bills acquired wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 second round pick from the Philadelphia Eagles for cornerback Ronald Darby and a 2018 sixth-round pick.\n\nBoth trades were announced within minutes of each other even though they were unrelated. According to Beane, both Los Angeles and Philadelphia had long inquired about the two now-former Bills players.\n\n\"LA got very serious about Sammy [Watkins] and Philadelphia got very serious about Ronald [Darby],\" Beane said. \"And the timing worked out, I was able to acquire Jordan to help fill in for Sammy and E.J. Gaines help fill in for Ronald.\"\n\nMatthews, like Watkins, faced his own battle with injuries. Last season, Matthews missed two games due to a back-related injury, and more recently he has been dealing with tendonitis in his knee. Matthews has been the Eagles most dependable receiver -- even before the Carson Wentz era took over -- but a mix of career-low numbers in 2016 plus the Eagles additions of Alshon Jeffrey and Torrey Smith made the 25-year-old more expendable.\n\nThe Bills have Zay Jones, Anquan Bolden, and Matthews as options in the slot but all have experience to fill Watkins' old role on the outside.\n\n\"[Matthews] is a self-made man,\" Beane said. \"He's a tough kid and he's going to work hard.\"\n\nBeane also mentioned Matthews' leadership as something that he will bring into the Bills locker room. Hours after it was announced that Matthews would be leaving, many of his former teammates, including Wentz, offered parting words.\n\nCrazy part of this business. @jmattjmattjmatt you'll always be my boy both on & off the field. Couldn't ask for a better teammate & friend. -- Carson Wentz (@cj_wentz)\n\nAugust 11, 2017\n\nThe Eagles desperately sought cornerback help dating back to the NFL Draft. At the draft the Eagles brought in Sidney Jones and Rasul Douglas, but the addition of Darby immediately fills in the Eagles' void. Darby will be the presumed starting right-side cornerback going forward.\n\nWhat both Matthews and Gaines have in common is that both are set to be unrestricted free agents after this season. Matthews is in the final year of his rookie deal which payed him $4.9 million over four years -- compared to the potential pay increase Watkins was going to receive. Gaines has will earn $1.7 million in 2017 with the Bills.\n\nWhile many fans found it difficult to part ways with one of the most promising receivers in Bills history, Buffalo is building for something special.\n\nThe Bills currently have two picks in each of the first three rounds of the 2018 draft. The abundance of draft picks allows Buffalo to secure a safe selection in one of the deepest draft classes in recent memory, with the likes of USC's Sam Darnold or OSU's Mason Rudolph giving solace to Beane's claim that the Bills will \"try to win today and win tomorrow.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 2910, "textStart": 2895}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T20:18:00Z", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "title": "Sporting News", "id": "1722"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:26:00", "url": "http://www.sportingnews.com/ca/nfl/news/buffalo-bills-sammy-watkins-ej-gaines-philadelphia-eagles-carson-wentz-jordan-matthews-ronald-darby/1wo9559cn4mj71otpe8sa8jz5e", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8729407", "image": "http://images.performgroup.com/di/library/Sporting_News_CA_CMS_image_storage/db/4/jordan-matthews-ftr-eagles-081117-getty_d8dl9wl5ybn112phhd6zovo1w.jpg?t=-755044779", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "20:18:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

The Buffalo Bills traded wide receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams.\n\nYou read that correctly. Watkins, whom the Bills paid a steep price to draft No. 4 overall in 2014, is gone with one year remaining on his original rookie contract.\n\nThe Bills also packaged their sixth-round pick in 2018 with Watkins, and got back cornerback E.J. Gaines and the Rams' second-round pick in 2018.\n\nIn a separate deal, another high draft choice, the 2015 second-round pick, Ronald Darby, was sent to the Philadelphia Eagles in exchange for wide receiver Jordan Matthews and Philadelphia's third-round pick in 2018.\n\nAfter these deals, the Bills now own two picks in each of the first, second and third rounds of 2018, a draft that is expected to be rich in quarterback talent.\n\nThus, what these trades would seem to indicate is that quarterback Tyrod Taylor can expect to be the Bills quarterback this season, but shouldn't make any plans beyond this year.\n\nWith all those draft picks available, it seems like the Bills -- if they choose -- can really put an attractive deal together to go up and get the best quarterback available, whether that's USC Sam Darnold, UCLA's Josh Rosen, or whomever. This, of course, is assuming the Bills don't hit rock bottom this season and won't have to worry about moving up in the draft to get one of the top QBs.\n\nThe trade of Watkins brings an end to what could only described as a disappointing three-year tenure for the talented wideout in Buffalo. He was the top-rated wide receiver in the 2014 draft, but that was also a draft filled with several top prospects, including Odell Beckham Jr. who has proven to be the best of the bunch.\n\nRather than stay at No. 9, the Bills switched places with the Browns, plus sent their 2015 first-round choice to Cleveland, so they could move up five spots to get Watkins. It was a reckless trade by former general manager Doug Whaley, and now it has proven to be a terrible one, too.\n\nWatkins endured non-stop nagging injuries, and he wound up missing 11 of the possible 48 games he could have played, but also was well less than 100 percent in many others.\n\nHe caught 153 passes for 2,459 yards and 17 TDs as a Bill. By comparison, the man who will probably replace him in the starting lineup -- Matthews, who was the Eagles' second-round pick in 2014 -- has missed only two games in his career and has 225 catches for 2,673 yards and 19 TDs.\n\nMatthews, like Watkins, is eligible for unrestricted free agency after this year.\n\nSome would say the writing was on the wall for Watkins when the Bills declined to exercise the fifth-year option on his contract. At the time, it was a move that made sense because the team was essentially telling him to prove he could stay healthy and produce.\n\nIf he did so, then new GM Brandon Beane and coach Sean McDermott would look to extend Watkins during this season, or perhaps prior to his hitting the market in 2018.\n\nBuffalo's wide receiver corps now contains rookie second-round pick Zay Jones, and two players -- Matthews and Anquan Boldin -- who will be playing on what amounts to one-year deals.\n\nMatthews has been a steady performer in Philadelphia. His lowest reception total is 67 as a rookie, and for yards it was 804 last season when he missed the only two games of his pro career.\n\nThe trade of Darby to Philadelphia was certainly interesting because the third-year pro seemed like he'd be a good fit in McDermott's defense. However, after a solid rookie season in 2015, Darby declined in 2016 and the Bills decided to move on.\n\nGaines was a sixth-round pick of the Rams in 2014. He started 15 games as a rookie and made two interceptions, missed all of 2015 with a foot injury, and then started 10 of 11 games in 2016 and did not make a pick.\n\nSal Maiorana, USA Today\n\nCONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:28:00Z", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "source": {"uri": "wltx.com", "title": "WLTX", "id": "18532"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:41:00", "url": "http://www.wltx.com/sports/bills-send-sammy-watkins-to-the-rams/463724173", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8772567", "image": "http://content.wltx.com/photo/2017/05/03/sammy%20watkins_1493786399486_9357508_ver1.0.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ezekiel_Elliott", "score": 4, "id": "1269795", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Odell Beckham Jr."}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odell_Beckham_Jr.", "score": Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 2, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Just when you thought the biggest story of the weekend might be the Ezekiel Elliott suspension, the Bills decided to flip their roster overnight with a pair of out-of-nowhere trades.\n\nBuffalo's new regime of Sean McDermott and Brandon Beane inherited a roster that appeared to top out short of the playoffs, so it's no surprise they've spent most of the offseason trying to undo deposed general manager Doug Whaley's mistakes. The Bills repeatedly traded down during the 2017 draft, grabbing an extra 2018 first-round pick from the Chiefs from their troubles, before firing Whaley the day after the draft.\n\nOn Friday, they added to their haul by acquiring a pair of 2018 picks as part of deals with the Eagles and Rams. Those trades amount to the following:\n\nThe dust is still settling, but at first glance, let's run through the winners and losers from these three deals:\n\nJared Goff\n\nAs the Rams try to build some sort of offensive infrastructure for the 2016 first overall pick, it's hard to imagine their acquiring a better receiver to work with than Watkins, who averaged 80.5 receiving yards per game while healthy in 2015, good for what would be nearly 1,300 receiving yards over a 16-game campaign. While Watkins hasn't lived up to the draft-day trade that saw the Bills deal two first-round picks to move up and acquire him ahead of Mike Evans and Odell Beckham Jr. in 2014, injuries have been the problem, not talent.\n\nSammy Watkins\n\nThis was always going to be a huge season for Watkins, who was set to hit unrestricted free agency after the Bills declined to pick up the fifth-year option on his rookie deal for 2018. Last year was a lost season for the Clemson product, given that the Bills repeatedly pushed Watkins onto the field with a clear foot injury before Watkins finally underwent what ended up as two surgeries on his left foot. It seemed likely that the Bills would part company with Watkins after the year regardless of what happened.\n\nIt's hard to see how Watkins will be in a better situation for either his short- or long-term future. After being traded to the Rams, who gave up a starting cornerback and a high pick to acquire him, Watkins is likely looking at the franchise tag if he breaks out in 2017. It's not clear that would have been the case in Buffalo, and the tag will cost him millions of dollars versus what he could get on the free market.\n\nHe's also now set to play out his contract year with Goff, who was one of the worst quarterbacks in recent memory during his debut season, as opposed to the criminally underrated Tyrod Taylor. Goff should be better during his second season, especially with the arrival of Sean McVay from Washington as coach, but there's a chance Watkins is relying on a replacement-level quarterback to make him millions of dollars.\n\nTyrod Taylor\n\nSpeaking of the Bills quarterback, Taylor also finds himself in a make-or-break year, even if that career might not be in western New York. Taylor just lost his top receiver, and while he's getting a viable weapon in Matthews, remember that Matthews was the focal point of a wide receiving corps that was seen as one of the worst in the league in Philadelphia last season. Even if you argue that Matthews has a higher floor than Watkins by virtue of missing a total of just two games over the past three seasons, it should take some time for Taylor to develop a rapport with his new No. 1 wideout.\n\nJordan Matthews\n\nThe Broncos were comfortably a three-wideout team under new Bills offensive coordinator Rick Dennison, going three-wide as high as 72 percent of the time in 2014, per Football Outsiders, which was the fourth-highest rate in the league. At the same time, though, the Bills just paid $8.4 million over four years to sign fullback Patrick DiMarco this offseason, suggesting that their organizational plan was to roll a fullback onto the field more often than not.\n\nThe presence of DiMarco (and Mike Tolbert) suggests that Matthews will be spending more time on the outside than he did in Philadelphia, where he was primarily a slot receiver. That could be a positive if he succeeds on the edge, given that some teams still discount the work done by receivers out of the slot.\n\nMore than anything, though, it's clear that Matthews is going to get far more targets in Buffalo than he would have in Philadelphia, where he was competing with Alshon Jeffery, Torrey Smith, Darren Sproles and a bevy of tight ends for targets. Now Matthews will be the primary focus of a receiving corps that includes second-round pick Zay Jones, the newly signed Anquan Boldin, a limited Charles Clay and LeSean McCoy. The Vandy product has a great shot at topping the 117 targets he racked up a year ago, which could get Matthews paid this offseason. It's also possible that the Bills give him a sweetheart deal in an attempt to smooth things over with their fans in advance of what looks like another rebuild.\n\nNelson Agholor\n\nWho saw that one coming? Agholor was basically left for dead after two frustrating seasons in Philadelphia, but after training camp reports suggested Agholor looked like a new man in the slot, the Eagles cleared out a spot for him by trading away Matthews. Coach Doug Pederson might not go three-wide all that often -- Philadelphia was there 60 percent of the time last season, 26th in the league -- but Agholor went from looking like a likely trade candidate to securing a roster spot with an outside shot at meaningful receptions.\n\nThe Eagles\n\nPhiladelphia was looking downright bereft at cornerback for the second consecutive season, having cycled again through middling veterans while using second- and third-round picks on Sidney Jones and Rasul Douglas, the former of whom is likely to miss a chunk of the 2017 season after rupturing his Achilles at his pro day. While the Eagles had long-term hope at the position, this is a team that should be capable of competing as early as this season. Cornerback was their biggest weakness.\n\nNow they have a promising option in both the short term and long term in Darby, who was stunningly effective during his debut season in Buffalo before slipping badly last season. Defensive coordinator Jim Schwartz has done excellent work with undersized corners in years past, notably launching Cortland Finnegan's career in Tennessee. It's too early to suggest Darby's a reclamation project, but dealing a wide receiver the Eagles were unlikely to sign for a likely starter at cornerback is a totally logical move, even if it did hurt to give up a third-round pick in the process.\n\nThe Rams\n\nSo much of what the Rams do on a year-to-year basis seems to be about erasing or accounting for the mistakes they've made in the past. Here again they're addressing their disastrous investment and reinvestment in the badly miscast Tavon Austin by shelling out another draft pick and what is (in the best case) going to be a huge contract to retain Watkins for the years to come.\n\nYou could understand why the Rams would want to take a shot at Watkins, but the 2018 free-agent wide receiver class is staggering, including players like Matthews, DeAndre Hopkins and Allen Robinson. Some of those guys will re-sign with their current teams, of course, but maybe the Rams end up giving someone like Jeffery or Terrelle Pryor a big deal. That wouldn't be the end of the world.\n\nWhat's frustrating about this move is that the Rams had to give up a second-round pick to acquire Watkins. Given that they're unlikely to be very good -- ESPN's FPI projects them to finish with the league's fifth-worst record -- chances are they'll be sending a high second-rounder to the Bills to acquire a player who hasn't been healthy for most of his career.\n\nAfter trading away a bevy of picks to acquire Goff, the Rams can't be in the pick-trading business. If anything, they should be looking at trading down and acquiring selections. (I realize they're getting a sixth-rounder, but per Chase Stuart's chart, even the top pick of the sixth round is worth just 12 percent as much as the fifth pick of the second round, the selection the Rams project to send to Buffalo.)\n\nEven if Los Angeles' bet on Watkins works out in 2017, the Rams are going to be stuck using their franchise tag or making a long-term bet on a player with a history of foot injuries. They could recoup a compensatory draft pick if they let Watkins leave, but that assumes Watkins will have a big-enough year to justify a serious deal in free agency while the Rams themselves mostly sit out, which seems like a very unlikely proposition.\n\nThey're also going to be in serious trouble at cornerback, where they just traded away Gaines and won't be able to afford franchising Trumaine Johnson for a third time after the season. Wade Phillips is a defensive genius, but the best guy on Los Angeles' depth chart for 2018 appears to be Broncos import Kayvon Webster, who played 58 defensive snaps last season and has spent the last several years buried underneath a stacked depth chart in Denver.\n\nThe Bills\n\nAs frustrating as this must be for Buffalo's fans, who are stuck undergoing yet another rebuild, the Bills are making the right sort of moves as they try to build a team to (eventually) make noise in the postseason. It's clear that the organization had soured on Watkins and had serious concerns about his ability to stay healthy; otherwise, they wouldn't have passed up the wideout's fifth-year option. And if the Bills don't have a lot of faith in Watkins staying healthy enough to pass a physical in 2018, it's difficult to imagine that they would see signing Watkins as a wise decision in the long term, either.\n\nIf you're going to move on from Watkins, then, this is a reasonable haul. You might argue that the Bills make a slight downgrade at cornerback by swapping Darby for Gaines, who has struggled with his own foot injuries. It's pretty clear Watkins has a higher upside than Matthews, although the higher floor for Matthews might offer some level of certainty the Bills prefer if they're handing out a long-term deal.\n\nWhat's really crucial, though, are those extra draft picks. As projected by FPI and using Stuart's chart, the Bills trading their sixth-round pick for Los Angeles' second-rounder and Philadelphia's third-round pick to trade the Rams pick (37, fifth-lowest FPI projection) and Eagles pick (80, 16th-lowest FPI projection) for pick 190 (the Bills have the sixth-lowest projection and that was the sixth-lowest pick of the sixth round, obviously the exact pick will pend specific compensatory selections) is roughly the equivalent of acquiring the 16th overall pick in a typical draft (17.1 points, closest to value of 16th pick, 16.9 points).\n\nThat gives the Bills what essentially amounts to three first-round picks in the 2018 draft, given that they'll have their own pick and Kansas City's selection from the Patrick Mahomes II trade. They can add a third-round compensatory pick for Stephon Gilmore if they cut three players from the group of DiMarco, Vladimir Ducasse, Ryan Harris, Andre Holmes and Steven Hauschka before Week 10, a move I would strongly encourage. Draft picks alone aren't a solution, but the best way to build a sustainably effective team isn't to trade up for a stud wide receiver or an inside linebacker, as the Bills did by sending multiple picks to acquire Reggie Ragland last season. It's to acquire draft picks and build a core of cheap, effective talent. As the Bills try to chase the juggernaut Patriots, they're wisely taking a page out of Bill Belichick's book.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T17:18:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"uri": "espn.com.au", "title": "ESPN.com", "id": "5195"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:26:00", "url": "http://www.espn.com.au/nfl/story/_/id/20313763", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8729430", "image": "http://a2.espncdn.com/combiner/i?img=%2Fphoto%2F2016%2F0913%2Fr125415_1296x729_16%2D9.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "17:18:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

(AP) -- The Buffalo Bills have shaken up their roster with two separate trades, dealing starting receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams and acquiring Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia.\n\nBoth are blockbuster trades in which Buffalo also shuffled its cornerbacks. Gaines in the trade with the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by acquiring a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe moves were announced early Friday afternoon, a day after Buffalo opened its preseason with a 17-10 loss to Minnesota. Gaines and a second rounder.\n\nIn his three years as a member of the Buffalo Bills, Watkins caught 153 passes for 2,459 and 17 touchdowns. In flashes, he looked explosive, but he just couldn't stay healthy. He missed three games in 2015 and half the season last year. The Buffalo Bills actually traded with the Cleveland Browns to get the fourth overall pick to take Watkins back in 2014, and three years later, he's on another team.\n\nAt the same time this news broke, the Bills also announced that they were trading corner Ronald Darby for Philadelphia Eagles wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third round pick. So essentially, the Bills traded Watkins for Matthews, and Darby for Gaines, while adding a second and a third round pick.\n\nThe reality is that the Bills probably didn't want to pay Watkins number one receiver money next year, mostly because he just can't stay healthy. 722}, {"label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Medical Billing", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Medical_Billing", "wgt": 100, "id": 1021}], "uri": "708345961", "lang": "eng", "title": "Buffalo Bills had to trade Sammy Watkins to improve for future", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "Cornerback"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornerback", "score": 4, "id": "304975", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "National Football League"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League", "score": 4, "id": "305661", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Quarterback"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_Bills", "score": 5, "id": "312097", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Philadelphia Eagles"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles", "score": 4, "id": "327126", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Miami Dolphins"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Dolphins", "score": 4, "id": "331328", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "score": 2, "id": "357144", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sammy Watkins (American football)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sammy_Watkins_(American_football)", "score": 2, "id": "360557", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 5, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carson Wentz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 3, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jared Goff"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Goff", "score": 2, "id": "1270390", "type": "person"}], "body": "Once the #NFL preseason starts, there are hardly any surprises when it comes to roster spots. Outside of injuries, such as the one that caused the Miami Dolphins to sign a retired quarterback like Jay Cutler, no one expects any other huge shocks. The #Buffalo Bills turned the NFL on its head with a surprising out-of-nowhere trade on Friday involving the Los Angeles Rams and Philadelphia Eagles.\n\nThe Buffalo Bills traded their top wide receiver and former No. 1 draft pick #Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams along with the team's 2018 sixth round draft pick. In exchange, the Los Angeles Rams sent their 2018 second round draft pick and cornerback E.J.\n\nGaines to the Buffalo Bills. A third team in the trade, the Philadelphia Eagles, received former Bills cornerback Ronald Darby and sent their 2018 third round pick to Buffalo.\n\nSo, the Buffalo Bills gave away their best wide receiver but this isn't as bad as it sounds. Jordan Matthews is a pretty good receiver although he wasn't explosive with Carson Wentz throwing the ball last season. Tyrod Taylor is a better quarterback than anyone gives him credit for and he should make Matthews better.\n\nThey might just be looking forward to next year already.\n\nNo one expects the Los Angeles Rams to set the world on fire this season although there are some who think they are a great sleeper pick to somehow sneak into playoff contention. However, Jared Goff was one of the worst quarterbacks in the NFL in 2016 and only Sean McVay can hope to turn him around.\n\nHaving Sammy Watkins to throw the ball to could do that. Now, Watkins has not remained healthy his entire NFL career, so that is a worry. Interestingly, Watkins bragged that he was going to change how the NFL gives out contracts when he becomes a free agent and had big demands. Playing for a weak Rams team will kill a lot of his value next season. There was almost no chance he was going to resign for a reasonable deal in 2018 so the Buffalo Bills had to cut ties now to protect their future. The Rams have to hope he pays off this year.\n\nThat leaves the Philadelphia Eagles. They lost Jordan Matthews but don't seem concerned because Nelson Agholor has been amazing in training camp and they still have Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith. This Friday, however, is different. First, the league announced that it had suspended Dallas Cowboys star running back Ezekiel Elliott for the first six games of the upcoming season. Not even an hour later, the Buffalo Bills made announcements of their own.\n\nAccording to the team's Twitter account, the Bills have made two trades involving two of their starting players:\n\nWe've acquired CB E.J. Gaines and a 2018 2nd round pick from the Rams for WR Sammy Watkins and a 2018 6th round pick.\n\nWe've acquired WR Jordan Matthews and a 2018 3rd round pick from the Eagles for CB Ronald Darby.\n\nLet's break down the two trades.\n\nSammy Watkins, the fourth overall selection in the 2014 NFL draft, has been the Bills' number one wide receiver the last three seasons. The 24-year old caught 153 passes for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in the 37 games he played for the team. However, he also has struggled with injuries and appeared in only eight games last season. Consequently, Buffalo opted not to pick up his fifth-year contract option.\n\nRonald Darby, on the other hand, was picked in the second round of the 2015 draft. He quickly established himself as one of the Bills' starting perimeter cornerbacks. Playing opposite Stephon Gilmore, who joined the New England Patriots this offseason, the 23-year old appeared in 29 games for the team, registering two interceptions (both during his rookie campaign).\n\nAs noted above, Buffalo will also give up a 2018 sixth round draft pick as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nE.J. Gaines is expected to replace Darby in Buffalo's starting lineup. The 25-year old originally entered the NFL as a sixth round draft pick by the then-St. Louis Rams in 2014. In his three seasons in the league, the 5'10 Gaines appeared in 26 games - missing the entire 2015 campaign due to injury - and registered two interceptions as one of the Rams starting cornerbacks.\n\nJordan Matthews was picked in the second round of the 2014 NFL draft by the Philadelphia Eagles. The 6'3 wideout played the second-most snaps on his team last season and finished with 73 catches for 804 yards and three scores. Over the course of his three-year career, the 25-year old has caught 225 catches for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns. Consequently, he will take over for Watkins as one of Buffalo's top offensive weapons.\n\nAs noted above, Buffalo will also receive a 2018 second round draft pick as well as a 2018 third round draft pick.\n\nThe Bills' new leadership of head coach Sean McDermott and general manager Brandon Beane has basically replaced Watkins and Darby one-by-one. While it remains to be seen whether or not the two moves will actually make the team better in the short term, the two draft picks give Buffalo additional capital to move around the board during next year's draft.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T16:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"uri": "patspulpit.com", "title": "Pats Pulpit", "id": "7873"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:03:00", "url": "https://www.patspulpit.com/2017/8/11/16135100/afc-east-report-buffalo-bills-trade-sammy-watkins-ronald-darby-los-angeles-rams-philadelphia-eagles", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8775064", "image": "https://cdn.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/WdK24BXoMpkdq_hcMZaLsz9wrwM=/0x427:4425x2916/1600x900/cdn.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/56155467/629151628.0.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "16:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Gaines and a second-round pick.\n\nThe wheeling and dealing wasn't done. The Bills also swung a deal with the Philadelphia Eagles, shipping cornerback Ronald Darby to the Philadelphia Eagles in exchange for wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick.\n\nDarby, who was a second-round pick of the Bills in 2015, played well as a rookie but struggled last season. Watkins was an even bigger disappointment -- the talented but oft-injured former No. 4 overall pick the Bills traded an extra first-rounder to move up for and draft back in 2014. The Bills had already declined Watkins' fifth-year option for 2018, but his sudden departure was still a surprise.\n\nNew Buffalo GM Brandon Beane vehemently denied the moves were a white flag from the team in 2017.\n\n\"This is not a throw-in-the-towel thing at all,\" Beane told reporters. \"Somebody mentioned that somebody said that out there, and honestly, that's annoying to me. You don't know me if you think I'm throwing in the towel. When I go out there and play pingpong, whatever I'm doing, I'm not throwing in the towel. If we're throwing in the towel, we're not trying to get a starting receiver back.\"\n\nThe argument can be made that in refusing to pick up his option, the Bills had already passed judgment on Watkins' long-term future with the team, and Matthews is at least a capable young receiver with more receiving yards the past three years than Watkins. But in selling off young talent from the Doug Whaley era and stockpiling picks, the Bills certainly look like a team more focused on the future than the present.\n\nThe Rams, in theory, got the No. 1 wide receiver Jared Goff so badly needs if he's to take the next step (or a step) forward in his second season. But that \"in theory\" caveat is a lulu with Watkins, who has missed 11 games the past two years.\n\nNever mind that he's still working his way back from foot surgery and will become a free agent after the season.\n\nThe Eagles found a taker for Matthews (who they'd been shopping for some time) and added a young defensive back in Darby who will probably be their best cornerback as soon as he sets foot in Philly. However, Darby backslid badly with the Bills in 2016, ranking 68th at his position, per Pro Football Focus.\n\nIn other words, there could just as easily be zero winners in these trades as three, depending on how things shake out over the next year.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:47:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"uri": "bleacherreport.com", "title": "Bleacher Report", "id": "3199"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:00:00", "url": "http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2727017-nfl-preseason-week-1-roundup-roberto-agauyo-pick-continues-to-haunt-buccaneers", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8755379", "image": "https://img.bleacherreport.net/img/images/photos/003/688/780/666f1eb5292f770c1f68c58d82c27ba6_crop_exact.jpg?w=1200&h=1200&q=75", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:47:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"342534", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Forward pass"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_pass", "score": 2, "id": "345076", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tyrod Taylor"}, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alshon_Jeffery", "score": 3, "id": "361975", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "A. Green"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A._J._Green", "score": 2, "id": "363557", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Darren Sproles"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darren_Sproles", "score": 3, "id": "374360", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rick Dennison"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rick_Dennison", "score": 3, "id": "379257", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Terrelle Pryor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrelle_Pryor", "score": 2, "id": "379307", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tavon Austin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tavon_Austin", "score": 2, "id": "379841", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Zach Ertz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zach_Ertz", "score": 3, "id": "382797", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Brent Celek"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brent_Celek", "score": 3, "id": "386829", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 3, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 3, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rod Streater"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_Streater", "score": 3, "id": "503201", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Andrew Whitworth"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Whitworth", "score": 2, "id": "548258", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carson Wentz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 3, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "If you thought it was hard to pull off just a straight-up swap of players in the NFL between just two teams, how about this: On Friday, it was announced that the Bills made deals with both the Rams and Eagles, involving players and draft picks.\n\nBy the time the twister had settled, the Rams ended up with wide receiver Sammy Watkins and a sixth-round pick from Buffalo, the Eagles held the rights to cornerback Ronald Darby and the Bills had the most new pieces to work with by adding receiver Jordan Matthews, cornerback E.J. Gaines, a second-rounder from the Rams and a third-rounder from Philly.\n\nThe deals were announced before most people could even take a breath following the news of Ezekiel Elliott's six-game suspension by the NFL. That means that the Cowboys, a slight favorite in the NFC East, may be the favorites no longer, which opens the door just a little bit more for the Eagles. Philly's biggest weakness was potentially at corner, where it was set to start Jalen Mills and Patrick Robinson. Now, Darby gets his chance to break out with a change of scenery. A 2015 second-round pick, Darby was PFF's Defensive Rookie of the Year that season, but he slumped a bit as a sophomore.\n\nThe move improves the Eagles' secondary, and the loss of Matthews is more than survivable, as they added Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith on one-year free-agent deals and still have Zach Ertz, Darren Sproles, Nelson Agholor, Paul Turner, Brent Celek and rookie Mack Hollins around to catch passes from Carson Wentz. Philly, maybe the best team last season to not make the playoffs, is definitely taking steps in the right direction.\n\nMatthews makes the transition to Buffalo's offense, in its first season under head coach Sean McDermott and offensive coordinator Rick Dennison. Swapping out Watkins for Matthews means that Tyrod Taylor might not have a receiver on the offense with whom he has worked before; Matthews joins Anquan Boldin, rookie Zay Jones, Rod Streater, Andre Holmes and Corey Brown in the unit, among others. Matthews averaged just 11.4 yards per catch over the past two seasons and caught only three touchdowns over 14 games in 2016. Per Football Outsiders, he was 76th in both DYAR and DVOA among all qualified receivers.\n\nGaines doesn't bring much more to the table and is well below the caliber of Darby. He missed all of 2015 with a foot injury and another five games in 2016. He was set to only be a backup for the Rams, but he could compete to work his way opposite of rookie first-rounder Tre'Davious White in Buffalo. The real reason for the Bills to complete these deals was not either of the players they received -- both are free agents after the season -- but the two picks. The Bills chose not to option the fifth-year on Watkins' deal, thereby making him a free agent in 2018. At best, Watkins leaving would have meant a third-round compensatory pick. Instead, the Bills get a second-rounder and third-rounder, guaranteed.\n\nThe added bonus is that Matthews and Gaines have potential to get better and become a part of the Bills' long-term plans, though they haven't really seemed to handle the Watkins or Taylor contract situations -- or most contract situations since their last postseason appearance in 1999 -- very well, so maybe it won't matter. The Bills were a longshot to win eight games this season, and, if anything, this move comes at the expense of the 2017 roster with the hope that it's good for 2018 and beyond.\n\nOn paper this does look like a good move for Buffalo, but only because it had begun to sever ties with Watkins anyway. The Bills were headed in the wrong direction with Watkins and Darby, their two best players under 25, and now they're trying to get the most return on that sullied investment.\n\nFinally, the Rams get the prized player, but can they do what Buffalo couldn't seem to figure out and utilize him properly? Watkins seems to be on par with A.J. Green and Amari Cooper -- two other fourth overall picks of recent years -- in terms of talent, but he has missed 11 games over the past two seasons. He is also inconsistent, though in 2015 he had five 100-yard games over a nine-game stretch, and that was playing in an offense that rarely threw the ball and finished 31st in pass attempts with Taylor.\n\nWatkins' latest challenge will be playing in an offense that ranked 32nd in both points and yards in 2016 behind the worst passer of last season: Jared Goff.\n\nThe Rams' best move was signing left tackle Andrew Whitworth in free agency, but they have also added Watkins, former Buffalo teammate Robert Woods and rookies Gerald Everett, Cooper Kupp and Josh Reynolds, and they are looking for continued growth from Todd Gurley, Tyler Higbee and Mike Thomas. In the case of Tavon Austin, the third-highest paid receiver in the league this year, the Rams are just looking for any type of growth at all.\n\nThat's a lot of weapons and Watkins may be the best of them, but all of the moves and all of the money spent will be for nothing if Goff continues to struggle.\n\nIt is highly improbable that the Rams will make a postseason run unless Goff is at least above average, and though the move to add Watkins is a net positive, it doesn't seem like Los Angeles is very close to a playoff run. If Watkins isn't re-signed, then the Rams lost yet another future pick without much return. Even a third-round comp pick seems like an uncertainty given that Jeffery and Terrelle Pryor could receive only one-year deals.\n\nThe overall winner appears to be Philadelphia, a team that has a decent shot at making the playoffs and acquired a young player who has two more years left on his deal. Matthews is not a special receiver, and the third-round pick for Darby is more than fair.\n\nThe biggest loser is Buffalo, which managed to downgrade at receiver and cornerback and received only two Day 2 picks in return. Those picks are meaningless if they don't pan out, and if they do, there's little guarantee that the Bills will even know what to do with them or know how to retain them long-term.\n\nMeanwhile, the Rams still seem to have that 7-9 smell to them, even without Jeff Fisher, because they finished somewhere in the middle of this trade and likely did not improve significantly. Despite Watkins' obvious talent, he has injury concerns and could be leaving for another team next year without having helped L.A. make any sort of postseason run in a division where it seems like the clear third-place team. If Goff does break out in 2017, it probably won't be solely because of Watkins. If he doesn't break out, then it was all for nothing.\n\nAt least the fans got to see something interesting and rare on a mid-August Friday: trades involving three teams. If only they were better teams.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:28:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"uri": "sportsonearth.com", "title": "Sports on Earth", "id": "5273"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:41:00", "url": "http://www.sportsonearth.com/article/247799536/nfl-trades-bills-eagles-rams-watkins-matthews", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8772562", "image": "http://www.sportsonearth.com/assets/images/9/8/0/247800980/cuts/1980x1100/cut.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "PHILADELPHIA -- The Eagles started to move on Saturday.\n\nOne day after wide receiver Jordan Matthews was traded to Buffalo, the team went about its business with a rigorous practice at the NovaCare Complex.\n\nThe Eagles endured their longest workout of training camp at 2 hours, 40 minutes and featured plenty of hitting. It possibly was done in an effort to take the players' minds off the trade, which sent Matthews and a third-round pick in the 2018 draft to the Bills in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nLatest Video\n\n\"I had a good relationship with (Matthews), but this business is a difficult one and you have to make some tough choices from time to time,\" Eagles coach Doug Pederson said. \"We're moving forward. It's business as usual.\"\n\nSome of the players were clearly still shaken by the trade move, however. In addition to being the Eagles' most productive receiver with 225 catches over the last three seasons, Matthews was also one of the more popular players off the field.\n\nHe was especially close with tight end Zach Ertz and quarterback Carson Wentz. According to Ertz, they were among \"five or six guys\" who went out to dinner with Matthews after the trade was announced Friday afternoon.\n\n\"You can't quantify with numbers what he meant to this team and to me, personally,\" Ertz said Saturday. \"Jordan played a huge role in helping me develop as a player and as a man. He's a brother for life.\"\n\nWentz had also bonded with Matthews on the field and away from football.\n\nLast season, Matthews caught 73 passes from Wentz -- Ertz led the team with 78 receptions -- for 804 yards and three touchdowns. Matthews sat out much of the recent offseason minicamps and organized team activities (OTAs) with knee tendonitis, but still accompanied the other wide receivers to North Dakota for a series of informal workouts with Wentz last month.\n\nAfter the dinner Friday, Wentz drove Matthews to Philadelphia International Airport for him to catch a flight to Buffalo.\n\n\"On the personal side, it's tough,\" Wentz said Saturday. \"This is my first time experiencing this with someone who is one of my best friends. Seeing him (Friday), it was tough on him, too. Kind of out of the blue.\"\n\nThe Eagles made the trade out of a desperate need to upgrade their defense as cornerback.\n\nDarby, the Bills' second-round draft pick in 2015, will be a starter as soon as he gets comfortable with the Eagles' defense.\n\nHe watched Saturday's practice on the field, frequently chatting with fellow cornerback Ron Brooks, who was also his teammate in Buffalo.\n\n\"I was a little surprised at the trade because everything happened so fast,\" Darby said Saturday. \"But at the end of the day, it's a blessing. I think this defense is a great match for my skill set, and I'm excited to get out there.\"\n\nDarby, 5-foot-11 and 190 pounds, is known for his blazing speed, which allows him to play aggressive, man-to-man defense without fear of getting beat deep.\n\nHe will be paired at cornerback with some combination of Jalen Mills, Patrick Robinson, rookie Rasul Douglas and Brooks, once he recovers from a strained hamstring.\n\n\"(Darby) has speed, he's versatile, he's a playmaker, he's smart and he's got great instincts and ball skills,\" said Eagles linebacker Nigel Bradham, who was Darby's teammate in Buffalo in 2015. \"He's going to be a great asset to our defense.\"\n\nMatthews became expendable because of the depth the Eagles have at wide receiver.\n\nNelson Agholor, the Eagles' first-round draft pick in 2015, will have the first shot at replacing Matthews in the slot with outside receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith. Mack Hollins, Shelton Gibson and others are also vying for playing time.\n\n\"We all have a lot of respect for Jordan, and he's a friend,\" Agholor said. \"My only worry now is with myself. I have a job to do and that's to keep working hard and making plays to help this team win football games.\"\n\nThe Eagles will not have to wait long to have a reunion with Matthews.\n\nThey play their preseason opener at Lincoln Financial Field on Thursday against the Bills.\n\n\"It's going to be really weird seeing him on the other team,\" Wentz said. \"It's not going to fun, I'll tell you that.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T17:28:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"uri": "pressofatlanticcity.com", "title": "Press of Atlantic City", "id": "9805"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:07:00", "url": "http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/sports/local/eagles/eagles-try-to-move-on-from-matthews-trade/article_9c9e0730-eff2-57e6-8722-f99b8256cd77.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8924743", "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pressofatlanticcity.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/a5/3a504fc9-3be8-5de1-9ee4-8c9e9725997d/597a3365daf3d.image.jpg?crop=1567%2C1175%2C98%2C0&resize=840%2C630&order=crop%2Cresize", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "17:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"1272372", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The #Buffalo Bills have not made the playoffs in 17 years, and general manager Brandon Beane has decided the team needed to take some drastic measures. In one trade, the Bills dealt top cornerback Ronald Darby to the Philadelphia Eagles for #wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third round pick. In the other, the Bills shockingly decided to trade #Sammy Watkins, whom Buffalo drafted with the 4th overall pick in the 2014 NFL draft.\n\nWatkins has had a varied career with the Bills, as he struggled to stay on the field for an entire season for his entire time with the team. His best year came in 2015, when Watkins had 60 receptions for over 1000 receiving yards and nine touchdowns.\n\nIn 2015, Watkins was easily one of the best receivers in the league in the second half of the year.\n\nUnfortunately, his production declined significantly in 2016, as he had only 28 catches for 430 receiving yards and just two touchdowns. He again struggled to stay on the field with injury issues. Those injury issues have been a continuous problem for the Bills since he was drafted, and it's likely that those medical concerns played a part in the Bills trade decision.\n\nEven though Sammy had expected to be in Buffalo for at least this year, he hasn't criticized the team for its decision. Instead, he has accepted the decision of general manager Brandon Beane and even thanked Buffalo for all the memories.\n\nNew chapter in life everything happens for a reason... Here's a video that is just a reminder of how explosive Watkins is when he is healthy.\n\nOpinions of the Bills trade have varied widely. Many fans are glad that he is gone, as they are tired of watching Watkins sit on the bench with injuries. But there are also a ton of Bills who are upset that the star wide receiver has been traded. Still, it's hard not to see Matthews as a significant downgrade from Watkins.\n\nAs a Bills fan, I'm glad to see that Watkins appreciated his time in Buffalo and I am sorry that he had to go.
