J. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "LeSean McCoy"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LeSean_McCoy", "score": 3, "id": "409985", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Terrence Pegula"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrence_Pegula", "score": 2, "id": "566969", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 3, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}], "body": "ROCHESTER, N.Y. -- Buffalo Bills general manager Brandon Beane said Friday afternoon that he doesn't like the word \"untouchable\" as it pertains to the trade status of players on his team. But after the bombshell he dropped at One Bills Drive, one would have to believe that no one on the Buffalo roster is untouchable.\n\nWide receiver Sammy Watkins and cornerback Ronald Darby were sent packing in two separate trades within minutes of each other, and it left the Bills with a collective, wide-eyed look as they convened for a short practice. If guys like that, two starters including one who was a No. 4 overall draft pick just three years ago, can be dealt, then anybody is in play.\n\n\"Definitely surprised,\" said quarterback Tyrod Taylor. \"Being in this league seven years, you know every day you step into the building could be your last day. I wish Sammy the best. I have faith in coach (Sean) McDermott, I have faith in management that they made a decision based on the betterment of this team. Just surprised it happened so fast.\"\n\nWatkins and a sixth-round draft pick in 2018 are on the way to the Los Angeles Rams in exchange for cornerback E.J. Gaines and the Rams' second-round pick in 2018. And 2015 second-round pick Ronald Darby, who started two years at cornerback for Buffalo, was sent to Philadelphia in exchange for wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a conditional third-round pick in 2018.\n\nRunning back LeSean McCoy, like Taylor, was surprised by the trades, but unlike Taylor, he knows what it feels like to get the shocking news that you never saw coming. In 2015, the Eagles traded him to the Bills for linebacker Kiko Alonso and it took a year for McCoy to fully grasp what happened, and to get comfortable in his new surroundings.\n\n\"I'm sure he's hurt,\" said McCoy. \"You get traded. It's a business and he has to understand that. But I can understand how he feels, being traded for a guy that he's better than.\"\n\nThe deals had been coming together over the past few days, and after the Bills' 17-10 preseason-opening loss to the Vikings, Beane met with McDermott and owner Terry Pegula to lay it on the table, and the decision was made to pull the trigger.\n\n\"They were two separate moves, though fortunately the timing worked out the way I wanted,\" said Beane. \"I had calls from multiple teams about Sammy back to June shortly after I took over the job. People ask about different players all the time; you never know what's serious or just bait. We were not actively shopping either of these guys, but L.A. got very serious about Sammy, and Philadelphia got very serious about Ronald and the timing worked out.\"\n\nMcDermott admitted to being taken aback slightly, but as everything was presented, he clearly saw the vision.\n\n\"Last night, coming off my first game, trying to digest some of that and then have these conversations late into the night, not a lot of sleep,\" said McDermott. \"It was a difficult decision, one that we spent a lot of time discussing, but these are the conversations that have to be had.\"\n\nThe Bills are a team trying to build for the future. Beane repeatedly said the goal for 2017 remains unchanged and the Bills want to win now, but it's obvious these moves were made for success down the road. The Bills now have two picks in each of the first three rounds of the 2018 draft, and that will give Beane plenty of ammunition to either plug multiple holes on the team, or packaging some of the picks to perhaps draft an elite quarterback.\n\nSo comes to an end a somewhat disappointing three-year stint in Buffalo for Watkins. The Bills paid a hefty price to draft him in 2014, switching places with the Browns (No. 9 to No. 4) while also giving the Browns their 2015 first-round pick to ensure they could pick Watkins.\n\nWatkins endured non-stop nagging injuries, and he wound up missing 11 of the possible 48 games he could have played, but also was well less than 100 percent in many others. He caught 153 passes for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns as a Bill. By comparison, the man who will probably replace him in the starting lineup - Matthews, who was the Eagles' second-round pick in 2014 - has missed only two games in his career and has 225 catches for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns.\n\nAs for Darby, he had a nice rookie season in 2015, but declined last season, so a change of scenery may do him good. Unlike Matthews, who should be able to earn a starting job, Gaines will be joining an open competition to replace Darby.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"uri": "upi.com", "title": "UPI", "id": "149"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:50:00", "url": "https://www.upi.com/Sports_News/NFL/2017/08/11/Buffalo-Bils-high-profile-deals-show-no-one-is-untouchable/5831502505301/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8735362", "image": "https://cdnph.upi.com/ph/st/th/5831502505301/2017/upi/30f8a3709822f32d331f252cf4600609/v2.1/Buffalo-Bils-high-profile-deals-show-no-one-is-untouchable.jpg?lg=4", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:50:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Angeles Rams and Philadelphia Eagles to offload two stars from the Bills' former front office regime.\n\nThrough their acquisition of Watkins, it looks as though the Los Angeles Rams have finally managed to acquire a true number one wideout for their 2016 first-overall pick Jared Goff to link up with. Watkins' best NFL season came in 2015, his sophomore year, when he caught 60 passes for 1,047 yards and nine touchdowns (in 13 games).\n\nGaines has started at cornerback for the Rams since he was a rookie in 2014, when he made the 2014 NFL All-Rookie team. He was forced to sit out the entire 2015 season with a foot injury, but returned in 2016 to start 10 games.\n\nDarby, 5'11, 195, was a second-round pick by the Bills in 2015. He had two solid seasons in Buffalo, earning 2015 NFL All-Rookie honors, but his style of play isn't seen as ideal for the zone coverage defensive scheme the Bills are shifting to.\n\nJordan Matthews, the likely new number one receiver for the Bills, started 13 games for the Eagles last season, catching 73 passes for 804 yards and three touchdowns. His low TD total was down last year from eight in each of 2014 and 2015.\n\nThese blockbuster trades signify a clear change in direction for the Bills, as Brandon Beane, hired as the Bills' new general manager in May, is clearly willing to move on from stars drafted by the previous regime.\n\nThe Bills now own the Kansas City Chiefs' 2018 first-round pick, the Rams' 2018 second-round pick, and the Eagles' 2018 third-round pick (via ESPN's Field Yates).", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T17:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "source": {"uri": "thesportsquotient.com", "title": "The Sports Quotient", "id": "10204"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:03:00", "url": "http://thesportsquotient.com/nfl/2017/8/11/bills-trade-watkins-to-rams-acquire-matthews-from-eagles", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8775122", "image": "http://thesportsquotient.com/media/posts/36848/usatsi_9709574.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "17:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

after three seasons, pulling in 225 catches for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns. He missed just two games over the past three seasons, and totaled more catches in his first three seasons than any other receiver in team history.\n\nThe deal also strips of the team of their most reliable receiver.\n\nFor all of the improvements the Eagles have tried to make at their receiving position this offseason, the loss of Matthews now just leaves them with a whole lot of question marks, and no receiver they can absolutely count on to produce for them.\n\nRanking all 90 Eagles players after loss to Packers\n\nAlshon Jeffery? He has missed a large portion of training camp due to a shoulder injury, hasn't topped 55 catches since 2014 and is coming off of a four-game suspension for a failed PED test.\n\nTorrey Smith? He is coming off of a terrible season in San Francisco, where he dropped 24% of the catchable passes thrown his way.\n\nNelshon Agholor?\n\nWith Matthews gone, the Eagles will no choice but to move Agholor to the slot, a role you have to wonder if he is ready for. Although Agholor has had a strong offseason, he has yet to prove he can produce consistently like Matthews did. Agholor also dropped the only pass thrown his way on Thursday night in the team's loss to the Green Bay Packers.\n\nThe issue for Agholor has always been performing under pressure. Now, the spotlight is even greater.\n\nAs for quarterback Carson Wentz, this move strips him of his favorite target among the wide receiver position, and also removes one of his closest friends in the locker room. The trade of Matthews seems to go against what executive vice president of player personnel Howie Roseman has preached all offseason -- building around Wentz and putting receivers around him with whom he can grow.\n\nThere is no denying the Eagles have upgraded their cornerback position with the addition of Darby.\n\nOverall, however, the Eagles are a worse team now than they were before the trade -- and their receiver position is now once again a question mark going into the season.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T17:10:00Z", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "source": {"uri": "nj.com", "title": "NJ.com (New Jersey)", "id": "144"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:07:00", "url": "http://www.nj.com/eagles/index.ssf/2017/08/trading_away_jordan_matthews_is_a_huge_mistake_by.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8676435", "image": "http://image.nj.com/home/advance-media/width620/img/nj-lvl_eagles_syndication/photo/2017/08/11/23217880-standard.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "17:10:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 4, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Randy Moss"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randy_Moss", "score": 2, "id": "381128", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kenny Stills"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenny_Stills", "score": 2, "id": "435902", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McVay"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McVay", "score": 3, "id": "491961", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Wade Phillips"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wade_Phillips", "score": 2, "id": "517893", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Howie Roseman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howie_Roseman", "score": 2, "id": "571949", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Odell Beckham Jr."}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odell_Beckham_Jr.", "score": 2, "id": "1270484", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kayvon Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 2, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The Buffalo Bills have traded wide receiver Sammy Watkins and a sixth-round pick in next year's draft to the Los Angeles Rams for cornerback E.J. Gaines and a 2018 second-round pick, the Bills announced Friday.\n\nAlso Friday, the Bills acquired wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round pick from the Philadelphia Eagles for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nThe Bills' decision to trade their top receiver and top cornerback for future draft picks signals that first-year general manager Brandon Beane and coach Sean McDermott view the team as a long-term rebuilding project.\n\nBuffalo now owns two selections in the first, second and third rounds of the 2018 draft. The Bills previously acquired the Kansas City Chiefs' first-round pick when they traded down during the 2017 draft to select cornerback Tre'Davious White at No. 27.\n\nWatkins' departure strips quarterback Tyrod Taylor of his top passing target this season. Taylor took a $10 million pay cut during the offseason to remain with the Bills, but his future with the team remains in doubt. The Bills can release Taylor before paying him a $6 million roster bonus in March and save most of his $18 million cap number in 2018, the final year of his contract.\n\n\"It doesn't say anything,\" said Beane about what the trade means for Taylor. \"Everybody's forgettingAnquan [Boldin]last week. This is not a throw-in-the-towel thing at all. Somebody mentioned that somebody said that out there, and honestly, that's annoying to me. You don't know me if you think I'm throwing in the towel. When I go out there and play pingpong, whatever I'm doing, I'm not throwing in the towel. If we're throwing in the towel, we're not trying to get a starting receiver back.\n\n\"To your question on Tyrod, it's nothing. We got Anquan, who we added. I told you, I honestly believe he's a Hall of Famer. He still can play in this league. Jordan Matthews is a starting receiver. If you look at his numbers and what he's done, those aren't anything to laugh at. So Tyrod will get every opportunity to lead this team, and we're all rooting for him. It's our best interest.\"\n\nDarby, who finished second in voting for Defensive Rookie of the Year in 2015, had two years remaining on his contract. White now projects as the Bills' top cornerback this season with Gaines likely to start opposite him.\n\nThe Rams have been searching all year for an outside vertical threat to complement new coach Sean McVay's offense and finally have that player in Watkins, who joins former Bills teammate Robert Woodsin the Rams' wide receiver corps.\n\nThe Rams had been talking to the Bills about a deal like this dating back to early May, when Buffalo declined its fifth-year option on Watkins' contract.\n\nRams general manager Les Snead called Watkins a \"complementary piece,\" though he figures to be much more than that.\n\n\"When you attack a team with your pass game, you'd like to use the width of the field and the length of the field, and that's what speed can do,\" Snead said at the team's annual charity luncheon in downtown Los Angeles. \"It's really just trying to open the field up.\"\n\nWatkins can play a role similar to the one DeSean Jackson played in Washington the past three years for McVay, who was the Redskins' offensive coordinator. Watkins joins Woods and slot receiver Cooper Kupp in three-receiver sets, putting Tavon Austin's role on the team in serious question.\n\nThe Rams had hoped that the 5-foot-8 Austin could develop into more of a vertical threat in this offense, but he spent the offseason recovering from wrist surgery and had been held out of training camp because of a hamstring injury. The Rams' other vertical threat, Mike Thomas, is suspended the first four games of the regular season for violating the NFL's policy on performance-enhancing substances, and their other receiver, Josh Reynolds, is a rookie who is still developing.\n\nSnead said Austin \"definitely has a place.\"\n\n\"Tavon is a fast kid,\" Snead said. \"Jimmy Johnson probably said it best, long before I was in football -- speed is important.\"\n\nWatkins enters the 2017 season on the final year of his contract after the Bills declined his fifth-year option earlier this offseason. Snead \"definitely\" wants to figure something out with Watkins long term but hasn't yet broached that topic with his representatives.\n\n\"He's 24,\" Snead said. \"So, you don't just do it for the now -- although we do think he'll help the now. But because of the age, you'd want it to be for the future, as well.\"\n\nGaines seemingly entered training camp in competition with newcomer Kayvon Webster for the No. 2 cornerback job, alongside Trumaine Johnson. But Webster's familiarity with Rams defensive coordinator Wade Phillips' system -- playing on Phillips' Denver Broncos defenses the past two years -- gave him an advantage and ultimately won him the job.\n\nMatthews has been a highly productive player since being selected 42nd overall in 2014. He ranks first in receptions (225) and third in receiving yards (2,673) among Eagles in their first three years and is one of only five players in NFL history with 65-plus receptions and 800-plus receiving yards in each of their first three seasons, joining a club that includes Randy Moss, Odell Beckham Jr., Mike Evans and A.J. Green.\n\nDespite the production, the Eagles never got serious about working out a contract extension with Matthews, who is in the final year of his rookie deal. Executive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman has a history of re-upping homegrown players early if they have been identified as part of the core. It was telling that he chose not to aggressively pursue a new contract with Matthews.\n\nPart of the issue is that Matthews' value is difficult to gauge. His numbers suggest he's deserving of something in the range of Kenny Stills (four years, $32 million) or Austin (four years, $42 million). The counter would be that Matthews is a slot receiver -- not an exceptionally explosive one relative to some others out there -- and paying big money for a player who might end up being the team's third receiving option doesn't make sense, especially if the Eagles want to extend Alshon Jeffery beyond this year.\n\nThere is also a knee injury to consider. Matthews has struggled to get right since sustaining what was described as a bone bruise last August on a low hit during training camp. One ailment after the next has crept up in the months since. He is currently dealing with knee tendinitis, which kept him from practicing for a good portion of the spring. A recent report suggested some team employees believe Matthews could have practiced more but allowed his contract status to influence his decision-making, a charge that Matthews strongly denied.\n\nNelson Agholor enjoyed a strong spring manning the slot in Matthews' absence. The Eagles are also high on rookie Mack Hollins and second-year player Marcus Johnson. The departure of Matthews will make it easier for the front office to keep some of the promising young talent on the 53-man roster.\n\nJust as importantly, the trade brings some much-needed talent to a suspect cornerback group. Patrick Robinson and Jalen Mills sat atop the depth chart before the deal, with Ron Brooks as the favorite to man the slot. (Brooks, coming off a ruptured quad tendon, injured his hamstring Thursday in the preseason opener against the Green Bay Packers.) Inconsistency has plagued the group during the spring and summer, and defensive coordinator Jim Schwartz has made it quite clear that the competition is far from settled.\n\n\"I'd love to have some continuity there. But we also have to let it play,\" he said.\n\nESPN Bills reporter Mike Rodak, ESPN Rams reporter Alden Gonzalez and ESPN Eagles reporter Tim McManus contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:17:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"uri": "6abc.com", "title": "6abc Action News", "id": "187"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:51:00", "url": "http://6abc.com/2297153/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8731307", "image": "http://a.espncdn.com/media/motion/2017/0811/dm_170811_nfl_schefter_on_watkins_and_matthews_trade/dm_170811_nfl_schefter_on_watkins_and_matthews_trade.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:17:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "2015 NFL draft"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_NFL_draft", "score": 2, "id": "1272379", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Less than 24 hours after their preseason loss to the Green Bay Packers, the Eagles shook up their roster, sending wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round draft pick to the Buffalo Bills in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nOn the surface, it would appear that Howie Roseman is using his depth at receiver to help accommodate for the lack of depth at cornerback.\n\nCheck out the video at the top of this story to find out why trading Matthews for Darby is a great move by the Eagles.\n\n9 reasons Eagles are crazy for trading Matthews\n\nBelow is the press release from the Eagles detailing the trade with the Bills:\n\nThe Philadelphia Eagles have acquired CB Ronald Darby from the Buffalo Bills in exchange for WR Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick in the 2018 NFL Draft.\n\nA third-year player out of Florida State, Darby was originally drafted by the Bills in the second round (50 overall) of the 2015 NFL Draft. In his first two NFL seasons, Darby started 29 games for the Bills and registered 137 tackles (121 solo), 2 interceptions and 33 passes defensed. An immediate starter as a rookie in 2015, Darby tallied 2 picks and 21 passes defensed en route to earning a spot on the Pro Football Writers Association All-Rookie Team and being named the Pro Football Focus defensive rookie of the year.\n\nDarby, a native of Oxon Hill, MD, played three seasons for the Seminoles, appearing in 42 career games and totaling 79 tackles (57 solo), 16 pass breakups, 2 interceptions, 2 forced fumbles and 1 fumble recovery. A three-time Atlantic Coast Conference champion, Darby was named the ACC Defensive Rookie of the Year as a freshman in 2012 and helped the Seminoles win the BCS National Championship in 2013.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T17:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"uri": "nj.com", "title": "NJ.com (New Jersey)", "id": "144"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:03:00", "url": "http://www.nj.com/eagles/index.ssf/2017/08/watch_eagles_trade_jordan_matthews_for_ronald_darb.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8775054", "image": "http://image.nj.com/home/advance-media/width620/img/nj-lvl_eagles_syndication/photo/2017/08/11/23218619-standard.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "17:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Devin Hester"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Devin_Hester", "score": 2, "id": "381512", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 4, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 3, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ezekiel Elliott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ezekiel_Elliott", "score": 4, "id": "1269795", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jared Goff"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Goff", "score": 2, "id": "1270390", "type": "person"}], "body": "Earlier this week we ranked the top quarterbacks for fantasy football in 2017. While we waited for a verdict on Ezekiel Elliott's 2017 season from the NFL to continue our rankings, the Buffalo Bills decided to shake up the receiver rankings at the same time.\n\nOn Monday, the Bills signed veteran Anquan Boldin. But the moves made by Buffalo on Friday were intriguing to say the least.\n\nFirst, the Bills sent their number one receiver, Sammy Watkins, and a 6th round draft pick in the 2018 NFL Draft to the Los Angeles Rams for cornerback E.J. Gaines and a 2nd round pick in the 2018 NFL Draft.\n\nThat move was subsequently followed by another corner-for-receiver deal. Buffalo dealt corner Ronald Darby to Philadelphia for Jordan Matthews and a 3rd round pick in the 2018 NFL Draft.\n\nBuffalo adding a couple picks is a nice component of these deals, and they also saved money. Both nice. Neither has any impact on fantasy football this season.\n\nSo let's talk about Watkins and Matthews.\n\nAdvantage Watkins, who was hyped coming out of a football powerhouse program and has athletic ability for days. Matthews went to Vanderbilt.\n\nEverything here is a significant advantage to Matthews, who has been a more consistent part of the offense in Philadelphia in spite of quarterback changes and has been on the field more than Watkins during the three years since they were drafted. Indeed, Matthews is one of only five receivers in NFL history to catch at least 65 balls and post at least 800 receiving yards in each of his first three seasons - and he did that with a merry-go-round at quarterback in Philly.\n\nAdvantage Watkins. The dynamic athletic ability that made him the fourth overall pick has shown - when he's been healthy - on the field in Buffalo, leading to one of the highest yard-per-reception averages over the last three years in the NFL. Matthews is more of a steady possession receiver.\n\nThat's all the past, though. What about the new homes of these guys?\n\nLet's start with Matthews, who heads to a Buffalo team that has a lot of nice pieces but the mix doesn't feel settled.\n\nShady McCoy will remain a key component of their passing game as well, and we already mentioned Boldin. However, the problem in Buffalo is simple: there doesn't appear to be a vertical threat on the roster.\n\nThe Bills used a second round pick on Zay Jones out of East Carolina this spring, He put up huge numbers at East Carolina (caught an NCAA record 158 passes for 1,746 yards and 8 touchdowns) but his average depth of target was only 8.3 yards. Indeed, the perfect mentors for the rookie might be Boldin and Matthews.\n\nBut who is going to stretch out an opposing defense?\n\nIf we back off the need for a deep threat, though, the reality is that the Bills host three games to open December before traveling to New England and Miami to close out the season. If you've paid attention to professional football in your life, you undoubtedly know that Buffalo isn't a kind place to play once the snow begins to fall; deep threats are great only if you can get the ball to them. Having more consistent receivers will likely be a good thing for the Bills.\n\nOverall Fantasy Impact: Bills\n\nI think the biggest winner in these deals is quarterback Tyrod Taylor. He won't be able to open up the field, but now he has two dependable veteran targets and a good rookie coming to work with. When the weather goes to hell in Buffalo, Taylor should be able to get the ball out quickly and keep the chains moving. Whether or not the Bills can get the ball in the end zone will be something to keep an eye on, though.\n\nLet's look at the situation in LA now, where Watkins will certainly bring some sexy to a team that wasn't lacking in that department.\n\nIn 2016, the Rams used the first overall pick on Jared Goff out of Cal to be the face of the franchise as they moved from St. Louis to LA. Rookie seasons aren't an end-all measuring stick for quarterbacks, but Goff's rookie campaign wasn't very good. He completed under 55 percent of his pass attempts and threw seven touchdowns to only five touchdowns.\n\nBut, again, he was a rookie. And running back Todd Gurley - an emerging young superstar in his own right - was banged up, which put more pressure on Goff and Case Keenum to win games with their arms.\n\nTavon Austin is the biggest threat on the Rams' offense. Watkins has speed to stretch a defense; Austin has Devin Hester-level speed. He's a game-breaker in every way, but the Rams have struggled to find the right role for him. He finished second on the Rams in rushing yards last year (albeit with only 149 yards on the season) and third in receiving yards with only 509.\n\nThe Rams needed real receivers to open up space for Austin.\n\nSo they added... two former Bills.\n\nRobert Woods, who spent the last three seasons playing opposite Watkins in Buffalo, signed in LA earlier in the offseason. The addition of Watkins will likely shift the two back into the roles they played with the Bills, with Woods being more of a possession receiver; Woods had 51 receptions for 613 yards and one touchdown last year.\n\nOverall Fantasy Impact: Rams\n\nTo me, the big winner here is Gurley. Woods, Watkins and Austin is a more interesting mix at the receiver position than the Rams has last year, should present more opportunities for the Ram's quarterback to make big plays, and should open up the field for Gurley. Because the quarterback position is still a mess, Gurley will still need to be the heartbeat of the offense but now there are more options for the ball to get spread out.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T14:02:00Z", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "source": {"uri": "chicagonow.com", "title": "chicagonow.com", "id": "5828"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:32:00", "url": "http://www.chicagonow.com/daily-chicago-sports-tab/2017/08/fantasy-football-breakdown-buffalo-receiver-moves/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8867695", "image": "http://www.chicagonow.com/daily-chicago-sports-tab/files/2017/08/Sammy-Watkins.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "14:02:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 2, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "In a shocking move, the Philadelphia Eagles traded away talented wide receiver Jordan Matthews for cornerback Ronald Darby. The Eagles desperately needed cornerback help, so acquiring Darby was a priority that is now satisfied. However, the team could've used Matthews as a great complementary piece to Alshon Jeffrey, and will miss his presence in the locker room. What do you think?\n\nAs much as Jordan Matthews was important to the Eagles offense, the team needed help in the defensive backfield more. Ronald Darby gives Philadelphia a young, starting-caliber cornerback it desperately needed. His 4.3 speed is something the Eagles have lacked in recent years and will be invaluable for a team that looked weak on that side of the field.\n\nJordan Matthews was a big price to pay for defensive secondary help. However, it'll be well worth the gamble when the Eagles are a more complete team come playoff time.\n\nThe Eagles wide receiving corp improved with the additions of Alshon Jeffrey and Torrey Smith. However, Jordan Matthews was the piece who made those moves worth it because he was so reliable. Now, questions are cropping up as the Eagles head into the season regarding its depth at wide receiver.\n\nMatthews may not have been the most explosive receiver, but you could always count on him to make a big catch. Jeffrey hasn't done much since his last 1,000-yard season in 2014, Torrey Smith was awful in San Francisco last year, and Nelson Agholor hasn't been able to maximize his talent yet. Philadelphia is a worse team than it was before.\n\nGetting a cornerback should have been a priority for the team, but it shouldn't have come at such a high price. Now, one of the Eagles' strengths is a questionable aspect of the team. Virginia Butler\n\n6 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nORCHARD PARK - Let's take a deep breath, exhale, and think about what the Buffalo Bills did Friday afternoon in a rational and thoughtful way.\n\nOn the surface, it was jarring to learn that new general manager Brandon Beane traded away perhaps the most dynamic player on the team, wide receiver Sammy Watkins, not to mention a young starting cornerback, Ronald Darby.\n\nWhen that news hit almost simultaneously around lunch time, Twitter feeds began to erupt and the word I kept seeing was \"Tank!\" All I could do was roll my eyes at the nonsense. I can tell you right now, no team in the NFL truly tries to tank -- not the Jets this year, not the Browns the past couple years, no one -- and the Bills aren't going to become the first.\n\nI smiled when I sat in the Bills media room and watched Beane answer the tank question. \"Everybody is forgetting we signed Anquan (Boldin) last week,\" he said. \"This is not a throw-in-the-towel at all. That's annoying to me. You don't know me if you think I'm throwing in the towel. If I was throwing in the towel, I wouldn't have tried to get a starting receiver back.\"\n\n\u25ba Blockbuster trade for the Bills\n\nWhat Beane did Friday in sending Watkins and a 2018 sixth-round pick to the Los Angeles Rams in exchange for cornerback E.J. Gaines and the Rams' second-round pick in 2018 was a master stroke. And when he traded Darby to Philadelphia for wide receiver Jordan Matthews and the Eagles' third-round pick in 2018, the double-barrel deal looked even better.\n\nLet's break this down: Watkins and Matthews are both eligible for free agency after this season, so their future status in Buffalo basically washes clean. The Bills lose some potential brilliance this season from Watkins (potential being the operative word because he's never been able to approach his high ceiling), but they gain a player in Matthews who has 70 more NFL receptions and has missed only two games in three seasons.\n\nDarby had a fine rookie season, and a rather disappointing second year for Buffalo. Gaines had a fine rookie year in 2014, and after missing all of 2015 with a foot injury, bounced back and played decently in 2016, though. No one is ever going to call him a standout, but he has started 25 NFL games. Will anyone ever be able to call Darby a standout? Maybe, but right now, he certainly isn't.\n\nPlayer for player, on paper, things look pretty equal, and the only wild card is that Watkins is the one man in this group who could go on to become a star, perhaps even this year. If his breakout happens, he'll likely outperform Matthews.\n\nNow, dig deeper and look at what the Bills get in draft currency. They lose a sixth-rounder (who cares?), but they gained a second- and third-round pick. So, not only did they gain immediate on-field replacements, they now have in the bank two picks in each of the first three rounds in 2018.\n\nBeane and coach Sean McDermott are in lockstep on just about everything, and that certainly pertains to the importance of the draft.\n\n\"With the draft picks, that's a big part of planning for the future,\" said McDermott. \"We believe that you build through the draft.\" In echoing those comments, Beane said, \"You have to draft well in this league to win. That helps us to have that kind of currency in the first three rounds, at the prices you pay those guys.\"\n\nBoth men wouldn't touch the Tyrod Taylor question, only to pledge their undying support to him, but what transpired Friday can only be perceived one way: Neither man is sold on Taylor as the long-term answer at quarterback. He was, by far, the best option for 2017, but they know they need to be better at that position and now, with all these early-round picks, they have put themselves in a prime position to be draft-day wheelers and dealers in the pursuit of a high-end quarterback.\n\nAnd hey, if Taylor shocks us all and performs at a Pro Bowl level, maybe they keep him and use all those picks to address the several other needs they have on this roster.\n\nIn the end, the Bills were not a playoff team with Watkins and Darby on the roster, and they aren't with them off the team. That's how you have to look at this.\n\nPut another way, Doug Whaley foolishly thought the Bills were on the cusp of being a playoff team when he made the Watkins trade, a trade I never supported because of what it cost. In making these deals, though he'll never admit it publicly, Beane is correctly assessing that while the Bills aren't a playoff team in 2017, these types of transactions are the steps you take on the road to becoming a playoff team.\n\nIt was a good day for the Bills.\n\nMAIORANA@Gannett.com\n\n6 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T21:18:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"uri": "democratandchronicle.com", "title": "Rochester Democrat and Chronicle", "id": "8075"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:26:00", "url": "http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/sports/2017/08/11/buffalo-bills-surprisingly-trade-sammy-watkins-and-ronald-darby/561278001/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8729409", "image": "https://www.gannett-cdn.com/GDContent/applogos/democratandchronicle.png", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "21:18:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

The Buffalo Bills traded their top wide receiver today, and Beane declared that the Bills are not throwing in the towel this season. He might need to clarify a few items in order for #Fans to believe him.\n\nBills wideout Sammy Watkins was traded to the Los Angeles Rams for a 2018 sixth round draft pick and cornerback EJ Gaines. The Bills also sent cornerback Ronald Darby to the Philadelphia Eagles for wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third round pick. The trade ensures that the Bills have two picks in the first, second, and third rounds in next year's draft.\n\nThe trade sent a wide receiver that clipped over 1,000 yards receiving in 2015 with nine touchdown passes. The former No. 4 overall draft pick was selected by Buffalo in 2014. Watkins suffered an injury-plagued season a year ago in which he recorded only 430 yards receiving and two touchdown passes. The Bills brought in Matthews who corralled 804 yards receiving last season with three touchdown passes. EJ Gaines will replace Darby in the cornerback position. Neither corners had any interceptions last season, while Darby recorded 13 more tackles.\n\nBeane made comments that the team is not throwing away this season and immediately looking to the future. These comments are problematic as the Bills traded away their best wideout and cornerback in order to receive draft picks.\n\nThe Bills acquired Anquan Boldin this week, and Beane tried to play off that quarterback Tyrod Taylor has plenty of weapons to throw to in Boldin and Mathews. Boldin may be a future hall of famer, but he is turning 37 years old on October 3rd. Watkins is just 24 years old. That's a huge difference, as Boldin only had 584 receiving yards last season.\n\nThe move also brings into question Taylor's job security. Taylor took $10 million less to come back to Buffalo this offseason. The Bills can release him in March before paying him a $6 million bonus which saves the Bills about $18 million in cap space. Taylor also loses his top target in Watkins and will surely see his numbers decline this season.\n\nWatkins was in the final year of his contract, which would make the trade make sense if the Bills did not want to pay him. However, Beane's comments are a sign of #False Hope. The Bills share a division with the New England Patriots who won 14 games, and the Miami Dolphins who won 10 games last season. pick in 2018 for Bills cornerback Ronald Darby on Friday afternoon.\n\nMatthews caught the first career touchdown pass from Carson Wentz in last season's opener and the two were very good friends. A second-round draft pick out of Vanderbilt in 2014, the 42nd player taken overall, Matthews made 225 catches for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns. The Birds will hope to get that kind of production now from Nelson Agholor, who will likely take over Matthews' role in the slot.\n\nIt was evident that the Birds needed help at corner. Darby, who is 5-11, 195, is just 23-years-old. He, like Matthews, was a former second-round pick, the 50th player taken overall in 2015 after having played at Florida State. In his rookie season two years ago, he had two interceptions, but none last year. He has made 29 career starts during his two seasons, collecting 61 tackles as a rookie and 60 last season.\n\nIn the first game of his pro career, Darby intercepted Indianapolis' Andrew Luck.\n\nThe Eagles perceive their receiver group to be a strength now, after signing Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith during the offseason. They also drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson. Hollins had a strong game in the Birds' 24-9 loss in the preseason opener to the Packers on Thursday night as did Bryce Treggs. Additionally, Greg Ward and Marcus Johnson are having strong camps.\n\nMatthews caught three passes for 18 yards against Green Bay.\n\nInterestingly, the Bills and Eagles will play each other Thursday night in their second preseason game.\n\nEnjoying our content? "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrod_Taylor", "score": 2, "id": "357144", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sammy Watkins (American football)"}, "uri": Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 5, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Josh Reynolds"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josh_Reynolds", "score": 3, "id": "406886", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 3, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 5, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ezekiel Elliott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ezekiel_Elliott", "score": 4, "id": "1269795", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jared Goff"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Goff", "score": 3, "id": "1270390", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "2014 NFL draft"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_NFL_draft", "score": 3, "id": "1272372", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 2, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "With two tweets, the Buffalo Bills shifted the football world's focus from the recently announced suspension of Cowboys star RB Ezekiel Elliott to New York. The Bills, under new management in 2017, just announced blockbuster trades on both sides of the football.\n\nThe team, which recently declined star WR Sammy Watkins' fifth-year option, traded the fourth-overall pick in the 2014 NFL Draft to the Los Angeles Rams. In return, Buffalo receives the services of a quality starting cornerback, fourth-year veteran E.J. Gaines, and a second-round pick in 2018.\n\nBut the team wasn't done, as it also announced it was moving starting cornerback (and budding star) Ronald Darby to Philadelphia in return for WR Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick in 2018.\n\nSo to review, the Bills traded Sammy Watkins and Ronald Darby for veterans E.J. Gaines and Jordan Matthews, while gaining second- and third-round picks in next year's NFL draft.\n\nThis string of moves suggests that Bills management is moving swiftly to ensure coach Sean McDermott has all of the ammunition he needs to load up on players that fit his system in the future. When adding on the Bills trading back in order to allow the Kansas City Chiefs to land QB Patrick Mahomes last April, Buffalo now holds two selections in each of the first three rounds next spring.\n\nThe team has to be thrilled with it's allocation of resources, but for the coming season, they're meaningless. Gaines and Matthews are quality football players. But they are not the same caliber of athletes as the players they are replacing. Nor do they bring the same level of game-changing ability. The Bills have flipped perhaps the two biggest chess pieces on their roster and replaced then with quality role players.\n\nThese personnel decisions were not made with the present in mind. The same cannot be said for their partners, the Rams and the Eagles.\n\nThe Rams suddenly tout an impressive wide receiver group, with sophomore QB Jared Goff finding himself with a number of new toys. Watkins will step in as the alpha of a group that features rookies Cooper Kupp, Josh Reynolds and Gerald Everett and recently signed Robert Woods. It's a completely re-worked group and one that is a massive upgrade over last season.\n\n(Photo by Rich Graessle/Icon Sportswire)\n\nWhile Goff's arm strength doesn't necessarily lend itself well to pushing the ball down the field to Watkins, the Clemson product will do well as a run-after-catch target and possesses the route running and suddenness to get open underneath.\n\nPhiladelphia has to be thrilled with how this trade changes its 2017 outlook. The team had a problem at the slot receiver position: both Matthews and 2015 first-round pick Nelson Agholor are most effective from the slot. With Matthews shipped out to Buffalo, the log jam for the middle-of-the field receiver has been cleared. And in return, the Eagles bring back a high-end starter in Darby. Darby will immediately be the best cornerback on the roster and be a Day 1 starter.\n\nBut while this trade has implications for all parties and their respective divisions (should we just give the Patriots a bye now?), there appears to be a seismic shift taking place in Buffalo. The team appears content to take its lumps in 2017, particularly on the offensive side of the ball. The team's top three targets now? Rookie Zay Jones, long-time veteran Anquan Boldin and the previously mentioned Matthews.\n\nBoldin and Matthews are cut from the same cloth, and the Bills are likely to find themselves in a similar quandary to what the Philadelphia Eagles faced just several hours ago: many of their pass catchers are best suited to play the same role in the offense. And who is going to be the downfield beneficiary of QB Tyrod Taylor's big-play mentality?\n\nThe answer figures to be Jones. But wide receivers frequently face a steep transition period when joining the ranks of the NFL. And while Jones is a great athlete, there's no guarantee he's going to grasp the nuances of NFL route running to assimilate quickly as a featured receiver. Defensively, the Bills' changes will be less harsh, but a difficult season lies ahead nonetheless.\n\nMcDermott has always had speed on the second level. Buffalo is transitioning out of a traditional 3-4 defense, which has more down-hill gap plugging linebackers. There's some dissonance there between personnel and ideologies that could pose a problem.\n\nThe Bills have made their intentions very clear with their moves on Friday: they're playing the long game. A rapid youth movement is underway as the team loads up to saturate its roster with high draft picks next season.\n\nOr perhaps the Bills have their eyes on installing \"one of their own\" at another position with all of this ammunition. They have been very shaky in their commitment to Taylor ever since he stepped into the starting role. With six selections in the first three rounds next year, perhaps the Bills have their eyes set on trying to move for one big fish instead of six fresh ones.\n\nEither way, times of change are here in Buffalo. For as sudden as the changes came on Friday, let it be known now that there's no end in sight.\n\nMORE COVERAGE: Anquan Boldin getting warm reception with Buffalo Buffalo needs Marcell Dareus to return to his 2015 form What does a successful season look like for Buffalo? {"location": null, "categories": [{"label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/American", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/American", "wgt": 100, "id": 32}, {"label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Investing/Day Trading", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Investing/Day_Trading", "wgt": 100, "id": 479}, {"label": "dmoz/Society/Future", "uri": "dmoz/Society/Future", "wgt": 100, "id": 550}, {"label": "dmoz/Business/Investing/Commodities and Futures", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Investing/Commodities_and_Futures", "wgt": 100, "id": 722}, {"label": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Trading", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Music/Trading", "wgt": 100, "id": 723}, {"label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services/Medical Billing", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Medical_Billing", "wgt": 100, "id": 1021}], "uri": "708126348", "lang": "eng", "title": "Winners and losers of Bills' trades with Rams, Eagles", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "American football"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_football", "score": 3, "id": "302605", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Cornerback"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornerback", "score": 5, "id": "304975", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Quarterback"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarterback", "score": 3, "id": "305872", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "NFL Network"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFL_Network", "score": 2, "id": "311040", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Defensive coordinator"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defensive_coordinator", "score": 2, "id": "311051", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Defensive tackle"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tackle_(American_and_Canadian_football)#Defensive_tackle", "score": 1, "id": "312085", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Buffalo Bills"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_Bills", "score": 5, "id": "312097", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jordan Matthews"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Matthews", "score": 4, "id": "331996", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rex Ryan"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rex_Ryan", "score": 2, "id": "357139", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tyrod Taylor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrod_Taylor", "score": 2, "id": "357144", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Franchise tag"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franchise_tag", "score": 3, "id": "368360", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tavon Austin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tavon_Austin", "score": 3, "id": "379841", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "E. J. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 4, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Stephon Gilmore"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephon_Gilmore", "score": 3, "id": "600930", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Daniel Jeremiah"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Jeremiah", "score": 3, "id": "620800", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jared Goff"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Goff", "score": 3, "id": "1270390", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kayvon Webster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kayvon_Webster", "score": 3, "id": "1292441", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "This is not a hot take column ready to slam the Bills, Eagles or Rams. The three-way deal that technically wasn't a three-way deal can be a win-win-win for all sides. The Eagles and Rams greatly improved their biggest weaknesses without giving up too much. These weren't traditional \"win-now\" moves by Philadelphia or Buffalo because Darby has two years left on his rookie deal and Watkins, who turned 24 in June, could be retained by the franchise tag in 2018 if the Rams can't reach a long-term deal with him.\n\nThe Bills are taking the biggest risk because talented young players are hard to find, and the 2017 Buffalo squad is now worse. Acquiring receiver Jordan Matthews from Philadelphia and cornerback E.J. Gaines from the Rams allows the Bills to tell fans they aren't giving up on this season, but this move is all about the future for a team in transition. Bills general manager Brandon Beane and head coach Sean McDermott didn't see Watkins or Darby as long-term fits and now look to the 2018 draft as the key moment to remake the organization in their image.\n\nThere's a lot to get into, so let's break down all the winners and losers of the trades below:\n\nJared Goff, Rams quarterback: The most striking takeaway from visiting Rams training camp was the team's lack of deep speed. The first week of camp was partly defined by a lack of big plays, with Robert Woods the closest thing the Rams had to a vertical receiver. That's not Woods' strength, and the acquisition of Watkins will allow Woods to do what he does best as a possession \"X\" receiver while Watkins tries to take the top off defenses deep.\n\nThe entire Rams receiver group makes more sense with Watkins in the No. 1 role, Woods sliding to No. 2, impressive rookie receiver Cooper Kupp in the slot and Tavon Austin floating in the abyss. Now it's up to Goff to prove he can complete deep throws, something that he didn't show as a rookie.\n\nGeneral manager Howie Roseman knew that a top cornerback trio of Jalen Mills, Patrick Robinson and Ron Brooks would struggle to hold up over the course of the season. The Eagles have struggled to draft difference-making cornerbacks for years, and Darby is a proven commodity. Pro Football Focus' Defensive Rookie of the Year in 2015, Darby is an incredible value with only $1.3 million combined due over the next two seasons. To put it another way: Darby outplayed Stephon Gilmore for two straight seasons, and Gilmore earned the highest guarantees of any free agent this year.\n\nThat contract is one reason why the Eagles had to give up a third-round pick in addition to Jordan Matthews to make the trade work, but I believe it's worth it because of how well Darby should fit into coordinator Jim Schwartz's system.\n\nNelson Agholor and Daniel Jeremiah: The trade especially made sense for the Eagles because they were able to fill a major position of need by giving up a guy who already appeared to be the odd man out of a revamped receiving corps. Agholor, the team's first-round pick in 2015, was poised to take much of Matthews' work in the slot. The Eagles also have seen youngsters Mack Hollins and Marcus Johnson emerge in camp.\n\nNFL Network's Daniel Jeremiah foresaw something like this happening when he predicted last week that Agholor was going to take over the slot position in Philadelphia, leaving Matthews with an uncertain future. Matthews hit out against Jeremiah after that take, but it turned out DJ knew what he was talking about.\n\nKayvon Webster, Rams cornerback: Rams defensive coordinator Wade Phillips told me at training camp that he liked his cornerback group more than outside observers, noting it is deeper than people think. This trade spoke to that confidence. E.J. Gaines was competing to start in L.A. and will likely start for the Bills.\n\nGaines' removal from the Rams opens up the starting job for Kayvon Webster, a little-known former Broncos cornerback who Phillips made sure to bring with him to the West Coast. Phillips believes Webster has matured as a pro and is ready to make a big impact after shining in limited work behind the best cornerback trio in football in Denver.\n\nBills fans: The plan is always changing. Beane and McDermott should not be punished for the sins of former Bills leaders, but that doesn't make it any easier for a loyal fanbase that is always believing the best in this organization without getting much return. The team gave up two first-round picks and a fourth-rounder to acquire Watkins back in 2014, and now he was dealt for pennies on the dollar.\n\nDarby looked like the next big thing in Buffalo under Rex Ryan in 2015, and now both men are out of town. It's hard to blame Bills fans for growing tired of buying jerseys or buying sales jobs from new regimes. It's up to Beane and McDermott to prove they are different.\n\nTyrod Taylor, Bills quarterback: Already in a difficult \"prove-it\" year with this new staff, Taylor just lost his only real deep threat. Matthews and recent free-agent pickup Anquan Boldin are best out of the slot. Rookie Zay Jones is more of a possession receiver type. It's hard to imagine this passing game having a lot of cohesion early in the season, and now the Bills front office has a lot of draft ammunition to find its quarterback of the future in 2018.\n\nTavon Austin, Rams receiver: Paid like a No. 1 receiver, Austin now appears relegated to a No. 4 job with the occasional end around or trick play mixed in. That's probably the role he's suited for, but the team's insistence this offseason that Austin could turn into a deep threat now sounds like wishful thinking. He has barely practiced this offseason following shoulder surgery and a training camp hamstring pull, which may have pushed the Rams to make this move. Austin doesn't make for a logical trade candidate because no team will want his contract, which has no guarantees after 2017.\n\nRams' future salary cap space: It's hard to imagine Austin with the Rams next season, in large part because general manager Les Snead is going to need to find cap space. The team already is strapped with commitments and needs to fit in a contract for holdout defensive tackle Aaron Donald and presumably a massive contract for new No. 1 wideout Sammy Watkins. The agent for Watkins knows he has great leverage in talks with the Rams, because the team does not want to give up such a high-draft pick on a one-year rental for a player.\n\nAlready short on draft picks because of the trade to acquire Jared Goff, dealing away a valuable second-round pick reduces the Rams' flexibility next year. The Rams will be highly motivated to make this Watkins acquisition work, with the honeymoon period in Los Angeles for coach Sean McVay and Goff growing ever shorter. This is a trade intended to help the Rams make noise starting now.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:01:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"uri": "nfl.com", "title": "NFL.com", "id": "5624"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:53:00", "url": "http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000828634/article/winners-and-losers-of-bills-trades-with-rams-eagles", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8699629", "image": "http://static.nfl.com/static/content/public/photo/2017/08/11/0ap3000000828639_thumbnail_200_150.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:01:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

With the preseason opener back on Thursday, the off-day gives the Bills a chance to recover before taking on the final week of training camp.\n\nWith two massive trades on Friday, the off-day became another day to process and mull over the future of the Buffalo Bills.\n\nGeneral Manager Brandon Beane shipped wide receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams for defensive back E.J. Gaines and a 2nd round pick in 2018. Tag-teamming that deal was a separate move to send defensive back Ronald Darby to the Philadelphia Eagles for wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 3rd round pick in 2018.\n\nAs it currently stands, the Bills hold two draft picks in each of the first three rounds of next year's draft.\n\nWatkins landed in LA on Saturday afternoon and was on the sideline for the Rams preseason game against the Dallas Cowboys.\n\nHe joins the Rams after the previous front office regime spent two 1st round picks on the star wideout in the 2014 draft. The last two years have been marred by multiple foot surgeries for Watkins. The Bills also declined the 5th-year option on his rookie contract earlier this year, making him a free agent after the 2017 season. Watkins says he feels no ill will toward the Bills after this trade.\n\n\"Nah, it's a business,\" said Watkins to the Los Angeles media. \"I'm in LA. I can't wait to get started honestly. It's a blessing to be here. Being in LA can help me out, nice weather, and to be in this city with these players, trying to chase a goal and win championships and go to the playoffs.\"\n\nDarby arrived in Philadelphia in time to watch his new team practice Saturday morning. He joins an Eagles team in dire need of help in the secondary. The 2-year starter in Buffalo will also join former teammates Corey Graham and Ron Brooks.\n\nWith Stephon Gilmore now on the New England Patriots, Darby stood a good chance of being the Bills top defensive back for the season opener. Now he heads to a division with superstar wide receivers like Dez Bryant and Odell Beckham Jr.\n\n\"It was fast. i just heard i was getting traded,\" said Darby after the Eagles practice. \"Close my eyes, open them, I'm on a plane. Close my eyes, open them, I'm laying down in a hotel, and now I'm out here, so everything's been moving real fast.\"\n\nThe Bills will gather again at St. John Fisher College in Pittsford for a training camp session on Sunday at 2:15pm. "score": 2, "id": "325514", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jordan Matthews"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Matthews", "score": 5, "id": "331996", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Eagles (band)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eagles_(band)", "score": 5, "id": "331997", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Forward pass"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_pass", "score": 2, "id": "345076", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jim Schwartz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Schwartz", "score": 5, "id": "349111", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Alshon Jeffery"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alshon_Jeffery", "score": 2, "id": "361975", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Darren Sproles"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darren_Sproles", "score": 2, "id": "374360", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Zach Ertz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zach_Ertz", "Howie Roseman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howie_Roseman", "score": 3, "id": "571949", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Mike Groh"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Groh", "score": 2, "id": "662344", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 5, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carson Wentz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 5, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "2016 NFL draft"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_NFL_draft", "score": 3, "id": "1273004", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 2, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Eric Rowe"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Rowe", "score": 2, "id": "1284489", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The acquisition of cornerback Ronald Darby in a trade that sent wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round draft pick to Buffalo on Friday was, in theory, in the works since the 2016 season as the Eagles watched an offense that lacked weapons around franchise quarterback Carson Wentz and a Jim Schwartz defense bogged down without reliable cornerbacks ...\n\nThe acquisition of cornerback Ronald Darby in a trade that sent wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round draft pick to Buffalo was, in theory, in the works since the 2016 season as the Eagles watched an offense that lacked weapons around franchise quarterback Carson Wentz and a Jim Schwartz defense bogged down without reliable cornerbacks.\n\nIn theory, that is. The actual trade that went down on Friday was in the works for a matter of days, or however many conversations it took for Howie Roseman to get a deal done.\n\nKnow this, though: From the day the Eagles drafted Wentz, they knew they needed to be a whole lot better around him. And on the other side of the ball, all of the pressure in the world from an aggressive front four couldn't cover up the fact that, pun intended, the Eagles needed more from the cornerback group.\n\n\"There's one football, right. I think we look at the skill-position groups as a whole. So we're looking at the wide receiver position, we're looking at the tight end position, we're looking at the running back position,\" Roseman said. \"And certainly, when we're making a trade like this, we're looking at those groups as well when we're letting go of a tremendously productive guy who played a ton of snaps and who has a ton of targets.\n\n\"When we went into it, we wanted to come out of the offseason with an improved offensive line, an improved defensive line, improved weapons around Carson, and certainly to address the corner position in a draft that we thought was unique at that spot.\n\n\"We weren't necessarily confident that we would be able to do all of that. We still sit here with a lot of things that we would like to do, but just seeing those guys on the field sometimes we're encouraged by the progress, encouraged by a lot of those guys that we brought in here, the chemistry of the group.\"\n\nGiving up Matthews and a third-round pick for Darby, who is only 23 years old with two years left on his contract and who two seasons ago was considered, in the midst of a fantastic rookie season, one of the rising, young stars of the position, is a significant price. The Eagles traded away their 2018 second-round draft pick in the Wentz trade prior to the 2016 NFL Draft and now they've dealt their third-round pick. They have an extra fourth-round selection from New England in the deal that sent cornerback Eric Rowe to the Patriots that becomes a third-round pick should Rowe play 50 percent of the Patriots' defensive snaps this season.\n\nBut, as Roseman said on Friday, you can't get value in this league without giving up value and that's the deal here. With Matthews gone, the Eagles will see who takes advantage of the opening. Does Nelson Agholor, who did not have a strong preseason game on Thursday night after a really good spring and summer, emerge? Does Bryce Treggs, who has come on in a big way the last couple of weeks in camp and in the preseason opener, continue to develop? Remember, the Eagles were high on Treggs when they claimed him off of waivers last summer from San Francisco.\n\nAdding Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in free agency and then selecting Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson in the draft are obvious reasons the wide receiver group has improved so much, but let's be just as fair and say that the internal improvement of players like Agholor, Treggs, and Marcus Johnson play into the equation. New wide receivers coach Mike Groh has done a terrific job with his room. The Eagles have an abundance of young talent at wide receiver after a 2016 season during which they were among the highest in the league in dropped passes and among the lowest in the league, 31st to be exact, in receiving yards at wide receiver.\n\nAnd, as Roseman said, it's important to factor into the equation the versatility the tight end group brings. Zach Ertz and Trey Burton are going to catch a lot of passes this year. Running back Darren Sproles is going to be involved a lot in the passing game. The Eagles have options in the passing game, and they're not afraid to use them.\n\nAt cornerback, well, it was obvious the Eagles needed some immediate help. The book on Darby is that he's got rare speed for the position and that, while he isn't a physically imposing player, he's going to play big and cover well. At 23, he teams well with a young core that includes Jalen Mills (23), C.J. Smith (24), Rasul Douglas (22 in August), and Sidney Jones (21), who is recovering from Achilles tendon surgery and will not, repeat, will not, be rushed back this season. Veteran Patrick Robinson is here on a one-year contract and he played well in the preseason opener at Green Bay.\n\nRoseman isn't finished with the roster. He's a wheeler and a dealer and he's going to keep looking. But just think about how far this team has come since the trade that put the Eagles in position to take Wentz No. 2 overall in the '16 draft. There is some really promising talent throughout the roster, young players who are getting good coaching and improving and emerging and building a foundation with some long-term veterans who are still highly productive on the field.\n\nThe Eagles gave up something on Friday in the form of a consistent, hard-working, and very well-liked and admired young veteran in Matthews and a valuable third-round draft pick in 2018 to get their hands on a two-year starter at cornerback who is a quality starting cornerback in this league. The Eagles are a better team right now than they were a day prior.\n\nAll of the pieces added to the existing roster are fitting right in like a puzzle that should stay together, for the most part, for many years to come.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:12:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"uri": "philadelphiaeagles.com", "title": "philadelphiaeagles.com", "id": "5290"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:06:00", "url": "http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/dave-spadaro/article-1/Darby-Another-Young-Piece-Added-To-Core/ea1e0261-63f9-463c-98e9-024266e3a981?campaign=phi:fanshare:facebook", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8693476", "image": "http://prod.static.eagles.clubs.nfl.com//assets/images/imported/PHI/photos/spadaro-column-headshot/580x400-EaglesInsider.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:12:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}
