"dmoz/Business/Financial_Services/Medical_Billing", "wgt": 100, "id": 1021}], "uri": "708116148", "lang": "eng", "title": "Watkins deal stuns the masses, but it's clear now, the Buffalo Bills are all in on the future", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "Philadelphia"}, "type": "loc", "score": 4, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Philadelphia"}, "type": "place", "country": {"label": {"eng": "United States of America"}, "type": "country"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia", "id": "196013"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles"}, "type": "loc", "score": 4, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles"}, "type": "place", "country": {"label": {"eng": "United States of America"}, "type": "country"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles", "id": "228323"}, {"label": {"eng": "Association football"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_football", "score": 2, "id": "302552", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Cornerback"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornerback", "score": 5, "id": "304975", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "National Football League"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League", "score": 5, "id": "305661", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Quarterback"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarterback", "score": 4, "id": "305872", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "National Football League Draft"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League_Draft", "score": 4, "id": "309406", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Cleveland Browns"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Browns", "score": 2, "id": "310098", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Wide receiver"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wide_receiver", "score": 5, "id": "310130", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Defensive end"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defensive_end", "score": 3, "id": "310749", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Placekicker"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Placekicker", "score": 3, "id": "311350", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Buffalo Bills"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_Bills", "score": 5, "id": "312097", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Starting lineup"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starting_lineup", "score": 3, "id": "316239", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Fullback (American football)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fullback_(American_football)", "score": 3, "id": "325507", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Philadelphia Eagles"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles", "score": 4, "id": "327126", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jordan Matthews"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Matthews", "score": 3, "id": "331996", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rex Ryan"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rex_Ryan", "score": 2, "id": "357139", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tyrod Taylor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrod_Taylor", "score": 3, "id": "357144", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sammy Watkins (American football)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sammy_Watkins_(American_football)", "score": 4, "id": "360557", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Marcell Dareus"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcell_Dareus", "score": 3, "id": "374415", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "E. J. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Gregg Williams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregg_Williams", "score": 1, "id": "400109", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 1, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 4, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "LeSean McCoy"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LeSean_McCoy", "score": 3, "id": "409985", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Doug Whaley"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doug_Whaley", "score": 2, "id": "500200", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Eric Wood"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Wood", "score": 3, "id": "574428", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Richie Incognito"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richie_Incognito", "score": 3, "id": "611034", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Vladimir Ducasse"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Ducasse", "score": 3, "id": "682057", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Andre Holmes"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andre_Holmes", "score": 3, "id": "1308974", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Patrick DiMarco"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patrick_DiMarco", "score": 3, "id": "1331176", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "ORCHARD PARK (WKBW) - The Buffalo Bills pulled the wool over everyone's eyes in the summer of 2017. While trying their best to get ready for the upcoming season, the Bills shocked the NFL world on Friday by announcing two blockbuster trades that immediately changes the course of the upcoming season and beyond.\n\nThe nuts and bolts of it:\n\nThe Bills traded away wide receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams, cornerback Ronald Darby to the Philadelphia Eagles, and a sixth-round pick in 2018 to the Rams as well.\n\nIn return, the Bills have received wide receiver Jordan Matthews, cornerback E.J. Gaines, a second-round pick from the Rams in 2018, and a third-round pick from the Eagles in 2018.\n\nThere is a lot to digest here, trying to figure out what the vision is both for the short and the long-term of the Buffalo Bills. It's something we've heard about time and time again from head coach Sean McDermott and general manager Brandon Beane over the last several months.\n\nAnd now, we've got our first #BeaneBomb which challenges us to figure out what the principles of each really are. So, here's my read:\n\nThe Bills are now all in on building for the future.\n\nThrough the entirety of the offseason, the core names have mostly remained the same for the Bills -- Tyrod Taylor, LeSean McCoy, Richie Incognito, Eric Wood, Kyle Williams, Marcell Dareus... but past those normal stalwarts, all we saw was a complete overhaul of the bottom two-thirds of the roster.\n\nThe Bills gave us a little hint of what could have been on the horizon with the Watkins and the Darby trades with what they did on draft day by acquiring an additional first round selection for 2018 -- perhaps as future ammo -- to what their true intentions really were. And with Taylor essentially being on a one-year prove it deal, while both Wood and Kyle Williams are on the final year of their contract, the complete overhaul into the future is also knocking on the door.\n\nNow, before we get into the individual players gained and lost in the deals, let's first analyze exactly the assets that the Bills now have in their holster, and what they can potentially do with those draft picks.\n\nSo, with the two trades today, this gives the Bills a really fun first three, maybe even four rounds of the 2018 NFL Draft. Here's the current stable of picks:\n\nTwo first-round picks, theirs and Kansas City's. Two second-round picks, theirs and that of the Los Angeles Rams. Two third-round picks, theirs and Philadelphia's. Plus, if they cut wide receiver Andre Holmes, defensive end Ryan Davis, and guard Vladimir Ducasse, it can bring them an additional third-round compensatory selection. And, if they take it a step further and cut either fullback Patrick DiMarco or kicker Stephen Hauschka in addition to those initial three cuts, they can obtain another potential fourth round pick.\n\nIf they do all of that, it would give them a whopping nine picks within the first four rounds of the draft. If they only go for the first level of compensatory picks, it will likely give them seven picks in the first three rounds. If they go for none of the compensatory options, they're still sitting pretty with seven selections in the first four rounds.\n\nThis brings just about the ultimate flexibility for Beane, McDermott, and the Bills.\n\nNow, the Bills have the ammo to significantly reshape their roster with the type of players, and people, that they want in the locker room for 2018 and beyond. If one of those two first-round picks ends up being a really high pick in the draft, the Bills have their franchise quarterback, and perhaps some ammo to get to the top of the order as well by way of multiple picks.\n\nNow, let's say both Buffalo and Kansas City both have an average to above-average year. With the ability now to deal compensatory selections, the Bills could potentially have nine picks to get up to whichever selection they need to in the draft order to take the franchise quarterback they so covet and even have themselves covered to add to the rest of the roster along the way.\n\nThey could literally pay a king's ransom to finally address the franchise quarterback position, and still have a normal draft. That, in itself, is worth its weight in gold to the Bills and their desire to build for both the short and long-term.\n\nLast year, if you'll recall, I wrote that in the current state of the Bills roster, draft picks, and cap space, that I'd rather be in the position the Cleveland Browns were in rather than what Rex Ryan, Doug Whaley, and company had going on. As it turns out, it seems Sean McDermott, Brandon Beane and the new wave of the Bills tends to agree.\n\nFlexibility is everything in the NFL when you're trying to build a roster, and the Bills just bought themselves a whole heaping amount of it.\n\nNow, let's get to the players involved.\n\nThe Bills dealt two young and talented players that show a lot of promise and potential, but also have gone through their share of adversity along the way. For Watkins, it was the concerns over an injury, and for Darby, it was all about his up-and-down play from one year to the next.\n\nWe'll start with Watkins, who is by far one of the most naturally talented players I've ever seen play football in person. The guy, when fully healthy, is one of the smoothest players going. To me, the only way you can deal a player with that type of potential is if you are getting a substantial sum in return, and it appears that's what the Bills did.\n\nWith only 16 games left on his current contract, a newfound but somewhat murky clean bill of health, and the potential for him to sign a mega contract in the coming offseason, the Bills weren't going to get a first round selection in return for Watkins. They did, however, maximize all the value they could get on him with his present situation with a second-round pick, got a potential starting player in return, and in a separate trade, replenished the wide receiver spot.\n\nThe short and long-term building personified.\n\nThe Darby trade was the biggest win of the two for the Bills -- at least it was to me. Darby was a revelation in his rookie season but then benched in his second season by the same coach that praised him so outwardly. Don't forget, this is a player that has been a man-to-man cover corner for basically the duration of his college and professional career, and one that they were trying to force into the starting lineup of a zone coverage schemed defense.\n\nStill, Darby has two years left on his current contract, is much more valuable to the type of defense the Eagles are running and yielded a huge lump sum in return. The Bills find themselves with a bonafide starting receiver in the NFL, and a third-round pick to boot. That trade, considering the lack of vision for Darby in the Bills current defensive system, could have been the biggest heist of the day for them.\n\nAs for those players they brought to Buffalo?\n\nShort-term players with only one year left on their current contract and with a cap hit of under $2 million each, that could turn into long-term options -- if the Bills like what they see in the 2017 season, that is.\n\nYeah, I'd say the Bills are living up to what they've been preaching.\n\nWith Matthews, he'll jump into the starting lineup and provide them with a real clean bill of health, and the versatility to line up both outside the numbers and in the slot -- much like what they've got with both Anquan Boldin and Zay Jones, too. Don't get me wrong, there is a big drop-off in pure talent from Watkins to Matthews -- and there will be some frustrating concentration drops with Matthews -- but they still have a starting caliber option for the team in 2017.\n\nAs for Gaines, the Bills receive a starting caliber player, and an experienced starter, that will feel much more at home in McDermott's zone-based scheme. He did not grade well on ProFootballFocus.com in 2016 while a member of the Gregg Williams defense in Los Angeles but did in his rookie season in 2014.\n\nBoth Matthews and Gaines are 25, and if they impress, could probably be brought back at a manageable salary if all goes well for them in Buffalo.\n\nTo put a line under all of this, I really, really liked the moves.\n\nThe Bills weren't lying when they said they wanted to build for both now and for later because that's exactly what they've done. And even if you don't like that Watkins or Darby has been dealt, or even if you aren't crazy about Matthews or Gaines, this is all underscored by a bigger point:\n\nIn today's NFL, unless you have the franchise quarterback in place, you're basically just spinning your wheels in the snow while stuck at a green light. With the moves they made today, the Bills now have themselves in a position to address the very thing that Bills fans have been clamoring for years on end.\n\nBy this time next year, we could be sitting here and analyzing the top flight quarterback the Bills just picked up in the 2018 NFL Draft.\n\nAnd to me, there's no beating that -- no matter who gets dealt.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T16:59:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"uri": "wkbw.com", "title": "WKBW", "id": "2037"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:26:00", "url": "http://www.wkbw.com/sports/bills/watkins-deal-stuns-the-masses-but-its-clear-now-the-buffalo-bills-are-all-in-on-the-future", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8695938", "image": "http://media2.wkbw.com/photo/2015/05/21/watkins_1432225720421_18616579_ver1.0_640_480.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "16:59:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

\"historically productive\" wide receiver in Jordan Matthews, who is just one of five players in NFL history to have at least 65 catches and 800 yards in each of his first three seasons. The Eagles invested a 2016 late-round pick in Jalen Mills that has paid off. This year, both second-day selections were used on the position in Sidney Jones and Rasul Douglas.\n\nThe Buffalo Bills offered Ronald Darby, a 23-year-old former second-round pick with 29 starts in his first two seasons. Darby was the runner-up in the NFL Defensive Rookie of the Year vote in 2015. But Roseman and the Eagles would have to part with Matthews, who is also well-respected in the locker room, and a 2018 draft pick in return.\n\nRoseman agreed to the deal and it was officially announced Friday afternoon.\n\n\"This was a unique opportunity. We were not shopping Jordan Matthews,\" Roseman said.\n\n\"You look around the league and it is a corner-deficient league. It's hard to find those guys. Smith (24 years old).\n\n\"He's got rare speed,\" Roseman said of Darby. \"His production on the ball, he doesn't have a high interception number, but his (pass breakup) number is incredibly high. Darby has 32 pass breakups and two interceptions in his career.\n\nThink back to the successful Eagles teams of the 2000s. Now, because of a trade the team made on Friday afternoon that saw Watkins shipped to the Los Angeles Rams, they won't be seeing him at all.\n\nIn exchange for Watkins, the Bills received E.J. Gaines, a cornerback who is gearing up for his third season in the NFL. Buffalo also received a second round draft pick in the deal while giving up a sixth round pick.\n\nIn an effort to replace Watkins, the Bills quickly traded starting cornerback Ronald Darby to the Philadelphia Eagles in exchange for Jordan Matthews, a receiver that was selected in the second round of the 2014 NFL Draft.\n\nThe team made two huge trades seemingly within a few seconds of one another, sending their fan base into a frenzy. Many Buffalo supporters are already claiming that the team is \"tanking.\"\n\nHowever, the team isn't tanking. In fact, Matthews could potentially make a huge impact in the Bills' passing game, making fans forget about Watkins before long.\n\nYes, Watkins is an extremely talented receiver who, when healthy, is one of the best in the league at the position. However, the problem with Watkins is that he's not always healthy.\n\nThe former Clemson Tiger missed half of the 2016 season with a nagging foot injury, an ailment that cost him three games in the 2015 season. While Watkins claims that his foot his 100% healed, that won't be proven until he takes the field for the first time in the regular season.\n\nMatthews, however, has been able to stay healthy throughout his three-year career. The 25-year-old didn't miss a single game throughout his first two seasons in the NFL, and missed just two games in the 2016 campaign.\n\nMatthews has been extremely productive over his first few years in the league, as well. Entering his fourth season, the former Vanderbilt wideout has 225 receptions for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns under his belt. Statistically speaking, Matthews is a more effective receiver than Watkins, who has caught 153 passes for nearly 2,500 yards throughout his career.\n\nWill Matthews be able to effectively replace Watkins' in the 2017 season? This is a bit of a loaded question, as the two players specialize in different roles. Watkins is an extremely talented No. 1 receiver who shines on the outside. Matthews, however, is primarily a slot receiver who is effective in the middle of the field.\n\nIn fact, according to Pro Football Focus, Matthews is the NFL's leading slot receiver over the past three seasons.\n\nThe Bills have added the NFL's leading slot receiver over the past three seasonshttps://t.co/iaGAijp01j pic.twitter.com/bUNP8xXbpA\n\n-- Pro Football Focus (@PFF) August 11, 2017\n\nWhile Buffalo no longer has a bonafide receiving threat on the outside, they've added a reliable pair of hands for quarterback Tyrod Taylor in the middle of the field by adding one of the NFL's best slot receivers. Watkins' absence will give also potentially allow rookie Zay Jones to step up and claim the first spot on the team's depth chart at receiver far earlier than anyone expected him to.\n\nWhile Matthews won't necessarily replace Watkins in terms of role, he'll replace him in terms of production. Barring any injuries or unforeseen circumstances, Matthews will likely finish the 2017 season as the Bills' leading receiver. The wideout caught 73 passes in his rookie season, 85 passes in his sophomore outing, and 67 passes in 2016 - numbers that would have led Buffalo in that statistic in each of those years.\n\nWhile fans are still shocked that Watkins is no longer a Bill, they managed to find a pretty solid replacement in Matthews. While he won't be starting against opposing team's primary cornerbacks, he'll still be a productive receiver who will likely stay healthy for Buffalo. Gaines to replace Ronald Darby leaves the Bills in a lesser place with just a month until the regular season begins.\n\nMatthews was a perfectly fine and productive wide receiver in Philadelphia, and Gaines developed into a solid starter for the Rams. But Matthews doesn't bring the game-breaking ability that Watkins does, and Darby had a stronger start to his career than Gaines.\n\nThe reason the Bills made both deals is because the team is stacked for the 2018 NFL Draft. After the Kansas City Chiefs moved up to draft Patrick Mahomes, the team sent a first-round pick to the Bills. Now the team has multiple selections in each of the first three rounds, and decided that Watkins and Darby will not be part of that long-term rebuilding effort.\n\nFor Watkins, the reason is obvious. He struggled to stay on the field and has continued to deal with nagging injuries since his rookie season. With a strong showing in the team's preseason opener, the Bills likely thought it was their final chance to get good value for him with free agency on the way in 2018.\n\nThe trade of Darby is a little more surprising, but is likely tied to the addition of Sean McDermott as Buffalo's head coach. As defensive coordinator of the Carolina Panthers, McDermott valued length in outside cornerbacks. The team drafted Tre'Davious White in the first round to give them that, but Darby didn't as much.\n\nGetting Matthews and Gaines means the team doesn't have a disaster at either position, but the coup of the deals for the Bills were the draft picks. The team was already a long shot to compete much in 2017, so losing Watkins and Darby doesn't tank any Super Bowl hopes.\n\nMatthews and Gaines are enough to keep the boat afloat, though.\n\nPhiladelphia drafted Matthews in the second round for the 2014 NFL Draft, and he's been a decent receiver for the Eagles ever since. He's hauled in 225 passes for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns in three season, but may have been phased out of the Philadelphia offense soon.\n\nPhiladelphia signed receiver Alshon Jeffery in the offseason, so it already has a No. 1 receiver to help quarterback Carson Wentz progress. With Nelson Agholor impressing in training camp, Eagles offensive coordinator Frank Reich didn't deny that Matthews could see reduced playing time to the former first-round pick.\n\nNow Matthews has a chance for a one-year audition with the Bills before he becomes a free agent in 2018. It will also be the first time head coach Doug Pederson meets with the media following the trade that sent wide receiver Jordan Matthews to Buffalo along with a draft pick in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby. We will carry that press conference live at around 10:45 a.m. here on PhiladelphiaEagles.com and the Eagles Mobile App. Until then, here's what you need to know for Saturday, August 12.\n\n1. Ronald Darby Calls Trade A Blessing\n\nCSN Philly's John Clark was there at Philadelphia International Airport, no surprise there, when new cornerback Ronald Darby arrived Friday night. It remains to be seen whether or not he will practice with the team on Saturday as he gets situated with his new team, but in a brief interview, Darby said he was \"surprised\" to learn of the move.\n\n\"It's a blessing at the end of the day,\" Darby said.\n\nThe 23-year-old with 29 career starts under his belt offered a scouting report for his new fans.\n\n\"I'm going to be aggressive, play fast, and get to the ball,\" he said.\n\nDarby has 32 passes defensed in his first two NFL seasons showing that he, indeed, will be around the football.\n\n2. Howie Roseman Capitalized On Unique Opportunity\n\nThe Eagles knew parting with Jordan Matthews, a productive wide receiver and outstanding person in the locker room, was going to be a tough decision. But the depth at the position, with the offseason additions and internal development that to position coach Mike Groh, allowed the Eagles to take advantage of the rare opportunity to add a young cornerback with starting experience.\n\n\"You look around the league and it is a corner-deficient league. It's hard to find those guys. It's hard to find guys who have been solid starters in the league and can play at a high level and teams that have them aren't really ready to move them.\"\n\nDarby is now a part of the youth movement at cornerback with Jalen Mills (23 years old), Sidney Jones (21 years old), Rasul Douglas (almost 22 years old), and second-year corner C.J. Smith (24 years old).\n\n\"He's got rare speed,\" Roseman said of Darby. \"His production on the ball, he doesn't have a high interception number, but his (pass breakup) number is incredibly high. He's played a variety of coverages. He won a National Championship at FSU.\"\n\n3. Nelson Agholor A Big Winner In Trade\n\nThe trade was just one of two for the Bills, as they sent wide receiver Sammy Watkins to the Los Angeles Rams for cornerback E.J. Gaines. Draft picks were also exchanged. But NFL.com's Gregg Rosenthal evaluated the deals and called wide receiver Nelson Agholor one of the big winners.\n\n\"The trade especially made sense for the Eagles because they were able to fill a major position of need by giving up a guy who already appeared to be the odd man out of a revamped receiving corps,\" Rosenthal wrote. \"Agholor, the team's first-round pick in 2015, was poised to take much of Matthews' work in the slot. The Eagles also have seen youngsters Mack Hollins and Marcus Johnson emerge in camp.\"\n\n4. Did NFL Network Analyst Know Of Potential Trade?\n\nNFL Network analyst and former Eagles scout Daniel Jeremiah predicted Agholor's ascension to the slot role in a recent episode of his Move the Sticks podcast.\n\n\"At the receiver position, I think they're in great shape. Nelson Agholor has had a total rebirth. He's in the slot. He's going to live in the slot. He's going to be their slot receiver. I'll be shocked if he's not,\" he said.\n\nHe didn't know what it meant for Matthews, but now we do.\n\nRookie wide receiver Mack Hollins epitomizes the change at the position. Expected to be a special teams player in his first year, Hollins scored the Eagles' lone touchdown on a 38-yard catch-and-run showing that maybe there should be a bigger role for him on offense.\n\nFran Duffy studied the All-22 and this is what he saw on the play.\n\n\"This was a post-cross concept from the Eagles, a very common vertical pass play that is prevalent in most offenses in the league. The basic idea is to put the free safety in the middle of the field in a bind. If the safety jumps down on the dig route (run by Mack Hollins on the right), then the post will be open for Torrey Smith on the left,\" Duffy wrote.\n\n\"The safety stayed home, creating a gaping hole in the middle of the field. The Packers run a three-man stunt up front, creating a free run at Wentz for linebacker Clay Matthews. This isn't Johnny Anonymous coming down the pike at Wentz, it is one of the most ferocious defenders in the NFL. Wentz showed off his athleticism, again keeping his eyes downfield and delivering this throw to the rookie, Hollins, who makes a great play after the catch, running through one tackle and stiff-arming a second defender with authority on his way to the end zone. It was an outstanding play by the Eagles' offense, and (hopefully) a good sign of things to come with this new-look unit.\"", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 573, "textStart": 564}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T10:24:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"uri": "philadelphiaeagles.com", "title": "philadelphiaeagles.com", "id": "5290"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:44:00", "url": "http://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/news/article-1/Wake-Up-Call-Ronald-Darby-Calls-It-A-'Blessing'-To-Be-An-Eagle/499bc974-0d39-4516-9f76-088602ebb4a3?campaign=phi:fanshare:facebook", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8824531", "image": "http://prod.static.eagles.clubs.nfl.com//assets/images/imported/PHI/photos/app_thumbnails/2017/Darby_Ronald_580App_081217.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "10:24:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

3, "id": "600930", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carson Wentz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 3, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Eric Rowe"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Rowe", "score": 2, "id": "1284489", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Look past the price tag, for a moment. There is one indisputable thing you can say about the Eagles' acquisition of cornerback Ronald Darby from Buffalo: They are in a much better position to contend for a playoff spot than they were 24 hours ago.\n\nMuch, much better.\n\nIn Darby, the Eagles added not only a starting-caliber cornerback, but also one who possesses a trait that is in dangerously short supply among the rest of the group.\n\n[Eagles trade Jordan Matthews to Buffalo, get cornerback Ronald Darby]\n\nHe has speed.\n\nIn 2015, when the Bills selected Darby at No. 50 overall, the former Florida State star ran a 4.38 40-yard dash at the combine. That number ranks in the top 15 percent at his position over the last three years (12th out of 104, per Pro-Football-Reference.com). By comparison, Jalen Mills and Rasul Douglas both ran 40s that rank in the bottom 20 percent, Douglas' 4.59 ranking 86th out of 104 and Mills' 4.61 ranking 90th.\n\nStraight-line speed is a small part of a cornerback's needed skill set, but it is an important one. The Eagles' lack of it has been on display throughout training camp, with Carson Wentz lobbing deep ball after deep ball over Mills, Douglas and veteran journeyman Patrick Robinson. For sure, Wentz deserves plenty of credit: He has been remarkably accurate on his deep throws throughout the summer. But the sheer number of shots down the field available to him had been jarring enough to think that it would be a deal breaker for any playoff hopes. This is the worst group of corners the Eagles have had perhaps in their history. And that is saying something.\n\nIn Darby, the Eagles clearly think they have found an answer. The Bills had one of the top pass defenses in the NFL last season, though Darby was aided by starting opposite a Pro Bowl-caliber cover man in Stephon Gilmore, who signed a huge free-agent contract with the Patriots this off-season.\n\nThe price was steep: a third-round pick and Jordan Matthews' final season before free agency.\n\nConsider:\n\nDarby was the No. 50 overall pick in the 2015 draft, which is notable because it means he was still on the board at No. 47, when the Eagles selected cornerback Eric Rowe, whom the Eagles gave up on after one year, trading him to the Patriots last season for a fourth-round pick. So when all was said and done, this was the balance sheet:\n\nEagles Give Up:\n\n- 2015 2nd-rounder\n\n- 2018 3rd-rounder\n\n- 1 year of Jordan Matthews\n\nEagles Get:\n\n- 3 years of CB (1 of Rowe, 2 of Darby)\n\n- 2018 4th-rounder\n\nIf they'd simply drafted Darby at No. 47 instead of Rowe, they would have gotten four years of rookie-contract cornerback play, plus they'd still have a 2018 third-rounder and one more season of Matthews in the slot.\n\nAll of that is immaterial to the wisdom of the move in the present moment. It's just a good example of how the Eagles' front-office dysfunction set the team back. If the current personnel structure had been in place back in 2015, perhaps the Eagles end up drafting Darby.\n\nWhatever the case, the move makes plenty of sense. Assuming Darby lives up to expectations and remains in Philly long term (he has two more seasons left before free agency), it will give the Eagles a ton of young depth at corner, with Mills, 2017 second-rounder Sidney Jones, and 2017 third-rounder Douglas.\n\nRead more by David Murphy Published: August 11, 2017 \u00e2\u0080\" 3:01 AM EDT | Updated: August 11, 2017 \u00e2\u0080\" 2:01 PM EDT\n\nThanks for your continued support...\n\nWe recently asked you to support our journalism. The response, in a word, is heartening. You have encouraged us in our mission -- to provide quality news and watchdog journalism. Some of you have even followed through with subscriptions, which is especially gratifying. Our role as an independent, fact-based news organization has never been clearer. And our promise to you is that we will always strive to provide indispensable journalism to our community. Subscriptions are available for home delivery of the print edition and for a digital replica viewable on your mobile device or computer. Subscriptions start as low as 25\u00a2 per day.\n\nWe're thankful for your support in every way.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 3362, "textStart": 3347, "freq": 2}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:30:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"uri": "philly.com", "title": "Philly.com", "id": "314"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:39:00", "url": "http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/eagles/philadelphia-eagles-ronald-darby-jordan-matthews-jalen-mills-patrick-robinson-rasul-douglas-20170811.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8689913", "image": "http://media.philly.com/images/dixon-110454-f-wp-content-uploads-2017-08-081117_ronald-darby_1200-1200x800.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:30:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Gaines and a third-round pick.\n\nThe Bills completed the instantaneous, positional exchange by dealing cornerback Ronald Darby to the Eagles in return for wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round pick.\n\nWatkins, selected fourth overall in the 2014 draft, has shown glimpses of brilliance over three seasons in Buffalo, but various leg injuries in 2015 and a season-ending broken foot in 2016 prevented the former Clemson star from playing a full season beyond his rookie year.\n\nWatkins' departure signals another step in owner Terry Pagula's plan to rebuild his team -- which is in the midst of a 17-year playoff drought -- practically from scratch. Pagula fired head coach Rex Ryan in the last week of the 2016 season and waited until the day after this year's draft to send Whaley packing.\n\nThrough all the changes, Pagula made clear who's boss. Whaley shocked reporters in January when he said he was not aware Ryan's job was in jeopardy and had no input in his ouster.\n\nIn May, Pagula tabbed Brandon Beane as the Bills' seventh general manger over the 17-year span. Beane joined rookie head coach Sean McDermott, whom the Bills hired in January.\n\nThe Bills' Watkins replacement, Matthews has been on the field for all but two games in his three-year career with the Eagles, after he was drafted in the second round of the 2014 draft. Matthews, 25, had his least productive season last year, amassing 73 receptions and three touchdowns in 14 games.\n\nThe Darby-for-Gaines trade appears to represent an even duller player swap, as each will be competing for a starting job with his new team.\n\nAt least the Bills have a few more draft picks to look forward to, results pending.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "title": "New York Post", "id": "13"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:50:00", "url": "http://nypost.com/2017/08/11/bills-rebuild-continues-with-two-trade-sammy-watkins-shocker/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8683159", "image": "https://thenypost.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/watkins-matthews.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&w=1200", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:50:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Gaines and a second-round pick in the 2018 NFL Draft.\n\nAfter Watkins' departure, the Bills now have Anquan Boldin, Zay Jones, Matthews, Rod Streater, Corey Brown, Andre Holmes, Brandon Tate, Dezmin Lewis, Brandon Reilly and Rashad Ross on its depth chart at wide receiver.\n\nMatthews, 25, is entering his fourth NFL season. The Vanderbilt product was a second-round pick in the 2014 NFL Draft. He has at least 103 targets in each of his first three seasons in the league. During his rookie campaign, Matthews had 67 catches for 872 yards and eight touchdowns. He snagged 85 receptions for 997 yards and eight scores in 2015. Last season he had 804 yards and three scores on 73 receptions in 14 games for the Eagles.\n\nHe is playing on the final year of his rookie contract and is due $1.09 million this season. Matthews had three catches for 18 yards Thursday in the Eagles' 24-9 loss to the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field. Watkins had four catches for 39 yards in the Bills' 17-10 loss to the Minnesota Vikings Thursday at New Era Field in Buffalo.\n\nPhiladelphia made several additions to its passing game this offseason, signing free agents Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith.\n\nThe Bills and the Eagles face off at 7 p.m. on August 17 at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia in their second preseason contest.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 7, "textStart": 0}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-17", "textEnd": 1605, "textStart": 1596}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T15:41:00Z", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "source": {"uri": "upi.com", "title": "UPI", "id": "149"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:09:00", "url": "https://www.upi.com/Sports_News/NFL/2017/08/11/Philadelphia-Eagles-trade-Jordan-Mathews-to-Buffalo-Bills/8321502471903/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8676647", "image": "https://cdnph.upi.com/ph/st/th/8321502471903/2017/upi/ebc94d77399fb1cbe3b62cde638e74cf/v2.1/Philadelphia-Eagles-trade-Jordan-Mathews-to-Buffalo-Bills.jpg?lg=4", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "15:41:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Adam Schefter confirmed the deal.\n\nThe Bills announced earlier Friday they traded wide receiver Sammy Watkins and a 2018 sixth-round pick to the Los Angeles Rams for cornerback E.J. Gaines and a 2018 second-round pick.\n\nBuffalo underwent a regime change during the offseason with head coach Sean McDermott and general manager Brandon Beane replacing Rex Ryan and Doug Whaley, respectively.\n\nThe moves Friday are a clear sign the Bills are going to retool the roster with a new vision, but it could take some time to complete the process. Going from Watkins to Matthews, and Darby to Gaines is a downgrade in upside at each position, but the team did get draft picks it hopes will offset the difference.\n\nAdam Caplan of ESPN provided some further background information on the swap:\n\nMatthews has registered 225 catches for 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns across three seasons since the Eagles selected him in the second round of the 2014 draft. That includes a 2016 campaign where he tallied 73 grabs for 804 yards and three scores.\n\nMeanwhile, Darby enjoyed a strong rookie season after the Bills took him with the 50th overall pick in 2015. He racked up 68 combined tackles, 21 passes defended and two interceptions. He struggled to match that production last year, however, with just 12 passes defended and no picks.\n\nMatthews should slide into the Bills' starting lineup opposite rookie wideout Zay Jones with recent signing Anquan Boldin operating out of the slot. | isportsweb", "concepts": [{"label": {"eng": "Philadelphia"}, "type": "loc", "score": 3, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Philadelphia"}, "type": "place", "country": {"label": {"eng": "United States of America"}, "type": "country"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia", "id": "196013"}, {"label": {"eng": "Cornerback"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornerback", "score": 1, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Matthews", "score": 3, "id": "331996", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tyrod Taylor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrod_Taylor", "score": 4, "id": "357144", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sammy Watkins (American football)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sammy_Watkins_(American_football)", "score": 4, "id": "360557", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "E. J. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 3, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 2, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}], "body": "Yesterday, the Buffalo Bills made a couple of surprising moves that appeared to show a lot about their intentions for this season. It may have been perceived by fans and the league that the Bills were laying an egg and looking towards the future. Yes, even though they added draft picks, there is a chance that these trades so late in the offseason could lead to a lack of chemistry on the Week 1 roster, and hurt the relationship the team has with it's fans. After 17 years of no playoffs, a lot was expected this season. But there's not necessarily reason to panic after the trades made.\n\nIt will be interesting to see how the team reacts to these moves this season, namely Tyrod Taylor, who just lost his number one receiver. He will now be entering this season, one that is important to not only Taylor's future with the Bills, but his future as a starter in this league, with his five top receivers as guys he's never played a regular season snap with. Sammy Watkins is a generational talent, one that the organization traded up a lot to acquire, and regardless of injuries, to let him go for an average to under average starter in LA Rams CB E.J. Gaines and a 2nd round pick is surprising and hard to understand. Here's what the moves mean for Buffalo's present and what it could mean down the road.\n\nThis Season:\n\nFor a team that has enough pressure as it is, what does trading your team's top receiver, and best young defensive back say to the rest of the players in Buffalo? It says nobody's safe, and team is looking to build a contender for the future through the draft. Chemistry on the team may be hurt by this as well. Tyrod Taylor is on his second \"prove-it\" deal in a row, and although the talent this year at receiver is significantly better, getting rid of a potential star in Sammy Watkins hurts the core significantly. Although Watkins has had an injury-plagued career, when he's been on the field he's been effective and all he needed was one full season to show what he can do.\n\nThe team however, did add WR Jordan Matthews from the Philadelphia to replace Watkins as the de facto number one receiver. Matthews has shown flashes of being a solid NFL receiver, with 225 catches for 2,673 yards over his first three seasons, and has only missed two games over those years. If he can take another step forward this season with an increase in targets, these trades may not look so bad.\n\nHopefully Matthews and Taylor can develop some sort of relationship in these last couple of weeks of the offseason, along with other top newcomers rookie Zay Jones and veteran Anquan Boldin. Boldin was a huge signing for Taylor, and could go a long way in his development at the QB position.\n\nAs far as moving CB Ronald Darby to Philadelphia as part of the trade for Matthews, I don't really get it. Darby has shown flashes over his first two seasons as a potential lock down corner in this league and to get an average receiver and a third round pick hurts the depth of this position as well as putting a bunch of pressure on rookie 1st round pick Tre'Davious White's shoulders, who becomes the teams number one corner. Yes, Buffalo also received E.J. Gaines from the Rams in the Watkins trade, but from what GM Brandon Beane has to say, Gaines isn't even a lock to make the roster. The Bills lacked depth at the position before trading their best player there on the depth chart, so this season will show a lot about HC Sean McDermott, who has been known for his ability to develop corners, namely Josh Norman.\n\nDown the Road:\n\nWith these additions however, the Bills look really good going into the 2018 NFL Draft. After adding a 2nd round pick and a 3rd round pick in those trades, Buffalo now has two 1st-rounders, two 2nd-rounders, and two 3rd-rounders in this years draft. That's not bad to build a future around in a talented 2018 draft. It also gives young players like Zay Jones and Tre'Davious White the opportunity to develop in bigger roles in their rookie year.\n\nSo, the other way to look at this is that Bills management is looking past this year, and going all in on the 2018 QB draft class which is very talented and is headlined by guys like Sam Darnold, Mason Rudolph, Josh Allen and many others. The Bills could be looking at Taylor as a rental for this season, and if he pans out as a viable starter then they can use the picks to build in other areas, like receiver or corner where they were hurt in these trades. Standout receivers like Deon Cain from Clemson and James Washington from Oklahoma State could be available in the early rounds with one of those picks which would giver the Bills a solid top 2 combination with Zay Jones for the long term.\n\nSo after all of this, the Buffalo Bills didn't make themselves that much worse in the present. They downgraded a couple of positions, but odds are Watkins would have gotten injured, and Buffalo will still have a better receiving core than last year with Jones, Boldin, Matthews and other guys like Andre Holmes and Philly Brown.\n\nThe cornerback position may have lost their best player, but adding E.J. Gaines, who has shown flashes of a capable starter with the Rams, could give Tre'Davious White the reigns at number one corner and give him an experienced guy opposite him to be a safety belt.\n\nObviously Sammy Watkins is a fantastic talent, but until he can stay on the field he's worth little to nothing, shown from the production out of Bills receivers minus Watkins last season. Buffalo has phenomenal depth at the position this year, and adding a veteran like Anquan Boldin, a future hall of famer, could be huge for the development of young guys like Zay Jones and Jordan Matthews.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T20:02:00Z", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "source": {"uri": "isportsweb.com", "title": "isportsweb", "id": "4620"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:32:00", "url": "http://www.isportsweb.com/2017/08/12/implications-of-recent-buffalo-bills-moves/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8867710", "image": "http://www.isportsweb.com/wp-content/uploads//2017/08/USATSI_10106556.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "20:02:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_Bills", "score": 3, "id": "312097", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rush (gridiron football)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rush_(gridiron_football)", "score": 3, "id": "324223", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Running back"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Running_back", "score": 3, "id": "324224", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Philadelphia Eagles"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles", "score": 3, "id": "327126", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jordan Matthews"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Matthews", "score": 5, "id": "331996", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "NFC East"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NFC_East", "score": 2, "id": "337440", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Rex Ryan"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rex_Ryan", "score": 2, "id": "357139", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sammy Watkins (American football)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sammy_Watkins_(American_football)", "score": 2, "id": "360557", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Alshon Jeffery"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alshon_Jeffery", "score": 3, "id": "361975", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Two-point conversion"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-point_conversion", "score": 3, "id": "384599", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Torrey Smith"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torrey_Smith", "score": 3, "id": "395521", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 2, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Frank Reich"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Reich", "score": 3, "id": "493164", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Howie Roseman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howie_Roseman", "score": 3, "id": "571949", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carson Wentz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 4, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 3, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Eric Rowe"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Rowe", "score": 2, "id": "1284489", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The Eagles' first-series touchdown drive in Thursday night's preseason opener showed two things: Why the team thought it could afford to deal Jordan Matthews, and why that trade with Buffalo is nonetheless a gamble for an organization trying to build a contender around Carson Wentz.\n\nIt was Matthews who kept the drive alive with a 7-yard catch on fourth-and-6 from Green Bay's 42, three plays before Wentz connected with Mack Hollins on what Hollins turned into a 38-yard touchdown ramble, the fourth-round rookie breaking from the middle of the field to the left sideline and delivering what Wentz later labeled \"two pretty nasty stiffarms there to finish up the play.\"\n\nMatthews caught three passes on the drive; he was the receiver Wentz was most comfortable with, the one Wentz looked for when he was dodging pass-rushers, as was frequently the case during the 10 snaps the QB played in Thursday's exhibition.\n\nBut that Hollins ramble represented the other part of the equation - the part that made de facto general manager Howie Roseman comfortable enough to trade away the sixth player in NFL history to catch at least 65 passes for at least 800 yards in each of his first three NFL seasons, since the Eagles drafted him in the second round from Vanderbilt in 2014. Roseman sent Matthews and the team's third-round pick in 2018 to Buffalo for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nMatthews is big (6-foot-3, 212 pounds) and sturdy, an exemplary worker, popular with teammates, especially with Wentz, who tweeted to Matthews that he would \"always be my boy, both on and off the field. Couldn't ask for a better teammate & friend.\"\n\n\"You worry about everything when you trade a professional like Jordan Matthews,\" Roseman told reporters Friday afternoon. \"This isn't one where you're celebrating and doing a dance, because you're giving up a good player and a good pick. In this league, you're not going to be able to get anything unless you give something ... it hurts when people you care about leave.\"\n\nBut Hollins (6-4, 221) also is big, and he looks pretty sturdy. And right now he ranks behind Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith, perhaps behind even Nelson Agholor, Thursday's two-point conversion failure notwithstanding, on a receiving corps the Eagles clearly feel they have upgraded substantially.\n\nRoseman touted Hollins on Friday as \"tremendously consistent, a big kid with really good speed.\"\n\nIntrigue bubbled beneath the surface with Matthews all spring and summer, as he approached the final year of his rookie deal. It became apparent that management wasn't disposed to give No. 1 receiver money, $10 million-plus a year, to a guy it didn't see as its No. 1 receiver going forward.\n\n\"Those things have a way of kind of sorting themselves out,\" Roseman said.\n\nMatthews sat out most of the spring work with knee tendinitis that the organization didn't seem to think was all that serious. Then, last week, offensive coordinator Frank Reich talked about Matthews sharing the slot position with Agholor and perhaps rookie running back Donnel Pumphrey, as the coaching staff pursued matchups. This would definitely have limited Matthews' snaps. Praise for Matthews in this camp has been sparing.\n\nAs the preseason began, it seemed very possible Matthews would be leaving, and inevitable that the Eagles would seek a starting cornerback in return. When the trade happened, they had to throw in the third-rounder, because as Roseman noted, it's \"a corner-deficient league,\" and prying away a starting-quality corner from anyone in August is a difficult feat.\n\nAlso, with Jeffery, among others, here on a one-year deal, Roseman stressed that he did not want to trade Matthews and get back someone with the same looming free agency problem. Darby, 23, was a second-round Buffalo pick in 2015, meaning he has two years left on his rookie deal.\n\nDespite the risks involved - Jeffery and Smith came with questions, Agholor has been a mistake-ridden disappointment through two NFL seasons, Hollins is a rookie with one preseason game behind him - it's clear that the Eagles felt they had to add a solid starting-quality corner to be competitive in the NFC East this season. In the spring, it was easy to talk about second-round draftee Sidney Jones maybe being back from his Achilles' tear by midseason, or third-round draftee Rasul Douglas starting from Day 1, but as camp developed, it was apparent the corner position was in worse shape, right now, than a year ago, which was saying something.\n\n\"Our priority was sorting out the cornerback position,\" Roseman said.\n\nThe Bills, who visit the Linc on Thursday, probably wouldn't have traded Darby for anything after his rookie season, when he finished second in defensive rookie of the year balloting, but like several Buffalo teammates, he dropped off dramatically in 2016, as the Rex Ryan regime flamed out. A new coaching staff, headed by former Eagles defensive coordinator Sean McDermott, seems to be inaugurating a longterm rebuild. Given the Matthews contract situation, the third-round pick might have been more attractive to the Bills than the player they got, on the day they also parted with 2014 first-round pick Sammy Watkins, who struggled with injuries and hasn't lived up to the tradeup from ninth to fourth overall Buffalo made to draft him.\n\nThe third-round pick going to Buffalo with Matthews isn't insignificant, but the Eagles pretty much had to add a decent corner, partly because last year they traded Eric Rowe to New England, a year after drafting Rowe in the second round - three slots ahead of where Buffalo took Darby.\n\n\"There's a point in a trade when you think, 'If I don't do this, I'm gonna lose the player,' \" Roseman said, when asked about including the pick in the deal.\n\nRoseman also pointed out that the Eagles can still court Matthews as a free agent next spring, if Buffalo doesn't lock him up, which seemed pretty silly - if you don't want to pay big money now, why would you in free agency, for the exact same skillset? This was probably window dressing to lessen the fallout over trading a popular player, but maybe Roseman does have a distant scenario in mind in which nobody is willing to pay Matthews what the receiver thinks he is worth.\n\nRoseman probably deserves credit for getting what would seem to be a decent corner at a time of year when that is next to impossible, but then there also is the fact that he bears much responsibility for the Eagles not having better corners in the first place. In fact, with this trade, the Eagles' 2014 draft joins 2011 and 2015 as major talent dead zones, unless you include Darby as a draft asset, assuming he comes in and plays well.\n\nGiven Darby's age, Roseman could reasonably sell this as a trade for the future, but the trade also reflects that the Eagles have aspirations in 2017, maybe bigger ones than they let on through much of the offseason.\n\nRead more by Les Bowen Published: August 12, 2017 \u00e2\u0080\" 3:01 AM EDT Thanks for your continued support...\n\nWe recently asked you to support our journalism. a trade with the Rams and a related trade with the Eagles. So who got the best end of the deal?\n\nTo recap, here's what each team ends up with after the two trades:\n\nFor the Bills, this move was about acquiring draft picks for the future: The new regime has already decided to move on from Watkins, the prize pick of the old regime. So they decided to move on from Watkins a year early and get a second-round draft pick. They also picked up a third-round draft pick for Darby.\n\nFor the Rams, this was all about Watkins: They want to give young quarterback Jared Goff another weapon, and now they've done so.\n\nAnd for the Eagles, this was about making the defense better right away: Darby should help immediately.\n\nWatkins is heading into the final year of his rookie contract and is cheap for the Rams, at a salary of just $690,000 this year. He'll be an unrestricted free agent next year unless the Rams slap the franchise tag on him. Watkins has 153 catches for 2,459 and 17 touchdowns in three seasons.\n\nMatthews is also heading into the final year of his rookie contract and is a little more expensive, with a salary of $1.1 million. Matthews has 225 catches for 2,673 and 19 touchdowns in three seasons.\n\nGaines is heading into the final year of his rookie contract as well, with a salary of $1.8 million. He has started 25 games for the Rams but missed the entire 2015 season.\n\nDarby has two more years left on his rookie contract, with salaries of $800,000 this year and $1 million next year. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 2, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Josh Rosen"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josh_Rosen", "score": 1, "id": "1270503", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Josh Allen"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josh_Allen", "score": 1, "id": "1273048", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "In a shocking pair of trades Friday, the Bills traded their top wide receiver, Sammy Watkins, and their top cornerback, Ronald Darby, in separate deals with the Los Angeles Rams and Philadelphia Eagles. In exchange, the Bills acquired Eagles wide receiver Jordan Matthews, Rams cornerback E.J. Gaines, as well as second- and third-round picks in 2018.\n\nEven given Watkins' problems staying healthy since entering the NFL as the fourth overall selection in 2014, he is a far-and-away better talent than Matthews. Darby, who finished second in defensive rookie of the year voting in 2015, had started 29 games over the past two seasons. Both Matthews and Gaines are entering the final season of their contracts, so it's possible neither will have an extended future in Buffalo.\n\nInstead of the players the Bills received in return, the key to whether this trade will be successful for Buffalo is the draft picks they acquired. Buffalo now owns six picks in the first three rounds of the 2018 draft -- one in each round. If they release a package of players later this month, they could add another 2018 third-round pick as part of the NFL's compensatory draft pick system.\n\nThe Bills never bottomed out as badly as the Browns in recent years, but Buffalo's impressive stash of draft selections rivals that of Cleveland, which is in full-blown rebuilding mode. First-year Bills coach Sean McDermott avoided using that rebuilding label for his team this offseason, but it now can be slapped on the 2017 Bills, who have clearly sacrificed short-term gain for potential long-term success.\n\nBuffalo's overall approach with these trades, and specifically the loss of Watkins, cannot sit well with starting quarterback Tyrod Taylor. By trading away his top passing target, the Bills are essentially setting up Taylor to fail this season. Mark down Aug. 11 as the beginning of the end of Taylor's tenure in Buffalo.\n\nTaylor took a $10 million pay cut in March to stay with the Bills, saying at the time he was putting his trust in management to fill in pieces around him after Taylor dealt with a lackluster group of receivers over his first two seasons as the starter. Instead, management has pulled out the rug on Taylor.\n\nBuffalo can avoid paying $14 million of Taylor's $18 million cap number next season if the team releases him before a $6 million roster bonus is due in March. After Friday's transactions, that move seems inevitable.\n\nWith a war chest of draft selections, the Bills have chips to move around the draft board next April. If Taylor is no longer on the roster, expect the Bills to pursue one of the draft's potential top quarterbacks -- USC's Sam Darnold, UCLA's Josh Rosen or Wyoming's Josh Allen.\n\nThe Bills' main competition in trying to land their franchise quarterback will be the New York Jets, who have been engaged in tank mode since the start of the offseason.\n\nAfter Friday, it looks like Buffalo is chasing the Jets in a race to the bottom of the barrel this season -- and the top of the 2018 draft.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 1846, "textStart": 1839}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:10:00Z", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "title": "ESPN.com", "id": "4"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:10:00", "url": "http://www.espn.com/blog/afceast/post/_/id/84332", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8676841", "image": "http://a2.espncdn.com/combiner/i?img=%2Fphoto%2F2017%2F0803%2Fr239708_1296x729_16%2D9.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:10:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"id": "579501", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}], "body": "Ronald Darby's first day with the Eagles came Saturday, and he watched practice from the sideline in sweats and a bucket hat. He needed to wait for Jordan Matthews to complete his physical in Buffalo before taking the field for the Eagles.\n\nIt's not expected to take long for Darby to become the Eagles' top cornerback. After the Eagles traded Matthews and a third-round pick for Darby on Friday, the 23-year-old Maryland native is in line to be a big part of the Eagles' present and future. He brings top-end speed that the other cornerbacks lack and a playing style that fits what defensive coordinator Jim Schwartz wants at the position.\n\n\"Everybody knows me for my speed,\" Darby said, \"but I'm willing to come up and tackle. Play aggressive.\"\n\nDarby thrived as a rookie in 2015 as an immediate starter for the Bills and had two interceptions and 21 passes defended. He was named Pro Football Focus' defensive rookie of the year that season. His performance declined last year, and Darby said he needed to do a better job finishing plays. Eagles safety Corey Graham, who started next to Darby in Buffalo, said scheme adjustments last season hurt the entire defense. He remembers how Darby excelled as a rookie and said that will translate to the Eagles.\n\n\"He was special the whole year,\" Graham said. \"He was lights out from the beginning. ...The kid has talent. As long as he can get in the playbook and learn exactly what we're doing and play fast, he'll be good.\"\n\nGraham, who has played in Schwartz's system before, indicated that Darby is a better fit in the Eagles scheme than what the Bills are expected to run this year with new coach Sean McDermott. Darby's man-to-man coverage ability is expected to be an asset. Darby didn't anticipate it taking a long time to learn the Eagles defense. Although Graham said Darby is better when he can play fast and not think, the concepts are similar to what Darby has done before.\n\n\"Corner, it's not that difficult once you get the concepts down, know the names of the plays,\" Darby said.\n\nDarby said he's a \"great match\" for the aggressive personality that Schwartz likes in his defensive backs. It's how Darby said he's played since he was at Florida State. In man-to-man defense, he said he can run against anybody. A high school track star who won the bronze medal in the 200 meters in the 2011 World Youth Championships, Darby ran a 4.38-second 40-yard dash at the combine in 2015. If he was tested this summer, he said the time would be even faster.\n\n\"I know for sure low 4.3s,\" Darby said.\n\nSafety Terrence Brooks, who was Darby's teammate at Florida State, said that Darby is \"so damn quick, it's crazy.\" But he also commented on Darby's physicality, which he didn't think should be lost when looking at Darby.\n\nGraham and Brooks are among the familiar faces Darby saw at Eagles practice. He knows former Bills teammates Ron Brooks and Nigel Bradham and former Florida State teammate Tim Jernigan. That will help in the transition to the Eagles.\n\nCoach Doug Pederson said the Eagles will treat Darby similar to how they did Graham last week -- give him a couple days to evaluate how he fits and then figure out what to do. Pederson said the Eagles will \"take it slow with him,\" not wanting to put him on the field when he doesn't know the defense. If Darby is available for Thursday's game against the Bills -- Darby's former team -- Pederson said he would play.\n\nThe Eagles need Darby ready by Week 1. That's when the NFC East schedule starts in Washington. Howie Roseman said the Eagles watched how Darby played against the division's receivers in 2015. Asked if he's excited to go against them again, Darby responded, \"Hell yeah!\"\n\nDarby watched the Eagles' other young cornerbacks on the field Saturday. He stood with Sidney Jones. Much is expected of Darby this season, but if the Eagles were right about the trade, he'll be in the Eagles secondary for years to come. He said it's even more \"exciting\" to know that it will come in Philadelphia in front of fans that impressed him in person when the Bills visited in 2015.\n\n\"The future's looking bright,\" Darby said. \"Right now's looking bright.\"\n\nVisit The Philadelphia Inquirer at www.philly.com", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T22:47:00Z", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "source": {"uri": "bostonherald.com", "title": "Boston Herald", "id": "2238"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:47:00", "url": "http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/patriots/2017/08/eagles_cb_ronald_darby_has_speed_but_is_ready_to_come_up_and_tackle", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8851604", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "22:47:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

2, "id": "310098", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Wide receiver"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wide_receiver", "score": 5, "id": "310130", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Free "310630", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Buffalo Bills"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffalo_Bills", "score": 5, "id": "312097", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "New Economic "score": 2, "id": "328979", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jordan Matthews"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Matthews", "score": 3, "id": "331996", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tennessee Titans"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennessee_Titans", "score": 2, "id": "350417", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Tyrod Taylor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrod_Taylor", "score": 3, "id": "357144", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sammy Watkins (American football)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sammy_Watkins_(American_football)", "score": 4, "id": "360557", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Johnny Unitas"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnny_Unitas", "score": 3, "id": "372653", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "E. J. Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 3, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Lisfranc injury"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisfranc_injury", "score": 2, "id": "388948", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Anquan Boldin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anquan_Boldin", "score": 2, "id": "406826", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "EJ Manuel"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EJ_Manuel", "score": 3, "id": "409977", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Kyle Orton"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyle_Orton", "score": 3, "id": "476719", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 3, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}], "body": "The Bills made two big deals that will likely end their 2017 playoff run before it even starts, but what might Buffalo's front office have in mind?\n\nBut they bypassed the cannonball from the side of the pool and went straight for the high dive.\n\nFirst came the report that wide receiver Sammy Watkins -- arguably their best skill player -- was traded. It was one of those tweets involving a big enough name (and not quite enough information) that make you look for the little blue check multiple times.\n\nThe team then announced the Watkins trade was indeed real, and it was with the Los Angeles Rams, for cornerback E.J. Gaines and a 2018 second-round pick. Buffalo would also include a 2018 sixth-round pick in the deal.\n\nNot even a minute later, the Bills released details of a second trade, this one with the Philadelphia Eagles. That deal sent cornerback Ronald Darby to Philadelphia in exchange for Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round pick.\n\nViewed as a three-team trade, here are the whos, whats, and wheres.\n\nSo what exactly did the Bills get out of all this?\n\nThere's a new regime in Buffalo and oftentimes, incoming coaches and front office executives tend to like getting players of their own. This was evident earlier in the offseason when the Bills decided to not pick up the fifth-year option for Watkins.\n\nIt's not difficult to see why the Bills might not be thrilled with him. During his three years in the league, the injury-prone 24-year-old took the field in just 37 of 48 possible games, playing 16 during his rookie year, 13 during 2015, and just 8 in 2016.\n\nWhen he was on the field, though, Watkins was a stud. In 2015, he led 86 wide receivers with 50 or more targets in Reception Net Expected Points (NEP) per target at 1.05. -- every time he was targeted, Buffalo gained over a full expected point. (That's insane, especially over 96 targets.) Among the 14 wide receivers in 2015 to gain 100 or more Reception NEP, Watkins's 60 receptions were the fewest by 9 catches.\n\nWatkins isn't averse to performing with bad quarterbacks. During his rookie season, Watkins had 128 targets from Kyle Orton and E.J. Manuel -- neither of whom will be mistaken for Johnny Unitas -- and managed to finish the year 18th in Reception NEP and 37th out 90 in Reception NEP per target among receivers with 50-plus target receivers.\n\nIn the final year of his rookie deal, Watkins could have left the Bills with just a third-round comp pick at the most -- or he could have had a good season and the Bills could have franchised or re-signed potentially one of the league's most talented receivers.\n\nHis skillset also meshed well with that of Tyrod Taylor, a player who, this summer, almost became an ex-Bill himself. Last year, Taylor had the seventh-highest average depth of target among quarterbacks (9.8), while Watkins was 15th among wide receivers (14.6).\n\nWatkins will be replaced by Matthews. The fit is strange because the Bills now have what amount to three big slot receivers in Matthews, rookie Zay Jones, and new free-agent signee Anquan Boldin.\n\nAmong 41 wide receivers with 100 or more targets last season, Matthews was 38th in Reception NEP, despite being 26th in targets and tied for 23rd in receptions.\n\nIt might not be too surprising to see the Bills go with a shorter and quicker passing game in 2017, given their personnel. It could look something like the Tennessee Titans of last season, though similar efficiency is certainly not guaranteed. It appears in both big-play ability and efficiency, the Bills will take a step back in 2017.\n\nThe Bills' secondary did need to improve, as last season, they ranked 20th in Adjusted Defensive Passing NEP per play. Ronald Darby was basically the team's top corner, and played a big part in that. He'll now be replaced by E.J Gaines.\n\nBy Sports Info Solutions charting from Football Outsiders, the two weren't drastically different by yards allowed per pass. Among 82 corners targeted 40 or more times in 2016, Gaines ranked 58th at 8.1 yards allowed per pass, while Darby was 62nd at 8.4.\n\nThe big difference, though, was in Success Rate. By that metric, Darby was 12th at 59 percent, while Gaines was 82nd at just 32 percent. So, while Darby was occasionally beaten for some big plays, Gaines was routinely beaten just about everywhere.\n\nDarby, 23, is also a full two years younger than Gaines. Part of Gaines's struggles in 2016 could be from his return from a Lisfranc injury that cost him the entire 2015 season. Maybe he'll improve another season removed from the ailment, but if the Bills want to deal away a receiver with foot problems, it's an odd move to swap your best cornerback for one with foot problems of his own.\n\nIn each of the two trades, draft picks were involved. For Buffalo, they can't be ignored, because they look like the main motivation for these moves. It's hard to imagine the Bills think swapping Watkins and Darby for Matthews and Gaines will be an upgrade for 2017.\n\nBecause, as the numbers show, it won't be. But this isn't just about the upcoming season.\n\nWith the second- and third-round picks acquired, the Bills now own two first-round picks, two in the second, and two in the third for 2018. That's a nice little setup they have going on there.\n\nBuffalo is now the most recent team to see the value in stocking up future draft picks for a rebuild. However, what makes the Bills different from teams like the Cleveland Browns or New York Jets is they weren't a team with league-low talent.\n\nSure, last year was disappointing, but the Bills were still a top-10 team by our nERD rankings as late as Week 13 -- replace the Rex and Rob Ryan regime with a competent coaching staff, and this could have been a Wild Card team. This morning, the Bills were 16th in our preseason nERD projections with a 32 percent chance of the playoffs, well above the Browns (6.1 percent), Jets (13.5 percent), and San Francisco 49ers (11.2 percent).\n\nThe might of the New England Patriots scared the Bills into preparing for a time when the Patriots could be ready to take a step back. In turn, Buffalo got worse for 2017. They now have their sights set on the future, and they have to hope the future goes according to plan.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T17:59:00Z", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "source": {"uri": "numberfire.com", "title": "numberFire", "id": "11841"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:53:00", "url": "https://www.numberfire.com/nfl/news/15812/are-the-buffalo-bills-crazy-for-trading-sammy-watkins", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8699647", "image": "https://d1tjohjvimcqgl.cloudfront.net/website/articles/15812_a2.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "17:59:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Rams, the other deal sends ripples into the wide receiver depth chart as well.\n\nThe Philadelphia Eagles have shipped receiver Jordan Matthews and a third-round draft pick in 2018 to Buffalo in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nMatthews was in exclusive company as a three-year veteran of the Eagles, posting 225 catches and 2,673 yards in his first trio of seasons with the team, but after Phialdelphia's offseason additions of Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith, not to mention a summer emergence by former first-round draft pick Nelson Agholor, Matthews was apparently deemed expendable.\n\nShipping the former second-round selection out of Vanderbilt to the Bills, who also own a host of other ex-Eagles like LeSean McCoy, solves two immediate concerns for Philadelphia and unofficial general manager Howie Roseman: Ridding themselves of a potential big-money extension for Matthews, who was due to become a free agent after the 2017 season, and landing much-needed help in the defensive backfield, where journeyman Patrick Robinson was slated to start opposite second-year man Jalen Mills at cornerback.\n\nDarby, 23, was a second-round pick of Buffalo in 2015 out of Florida State and represents an immediate upgrade for an Eagles CB depth chart. Wide receiver Sammy Watkins was dealt to the Los Angeles Rams while cornerback Ronald Darby was sent to the Philadelphia Eagles.\n\nIn exchange for Watkins and a sixth-round draft pick next year, the Bills received cornerback E.J. Gaines and a second-round draft pick in 2018. The Bills acquired wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick in 2018 for Darby.\n\n\"Jordan Matthews is a wide receiver with a long r\u00e9sum\u00e9, already in a three-year career and he's had great production with multiple quarterbacks,\" said Bills head coach Sean McDermott. \"With E.J. and what he's done with his career, we thought that he would give us a chance as well at the corner position.\"\n\nGeneral manager Brandon Beane told reporters he is not actively shopping any Bills players around the National Football League but had been receiving calls from other teams expressing interest in both players. Gaines to fill in for losing Ronald.\"\n\nMany are now questioning whether these deals, and the draft picks the team is accumulating, is a sign the team is already thinking about looking beyond the 2017 season to focus on building for 2018.
