Gaines and a second-round pick in the 2018 NFL Draft.\n\nAfter Watkins' departure, the Bills now have Anquan Boldin, Zay Jones, Matthews, Rod Streater, Corey Brown, Andre Holmes, Brandon Tate, Dezmin Lewis, Brandon Reilly and Rashad Ross on its depth chart at wide receiver.\n\nMatthews, 25, is entering his fourth NFL season. The Vanderbilt product was a second-round pick in the 2014 NFL Draft. He has at least 103 targets in each of his first three seasons in the league. During his rookie campaign, Matthews had 67 catches for 872 yards and eight touchdowns. He snagged 85 receptions for 997 yards and eight scores in 2015. Last season he had 804 yards and three scores on 73 receptions in 14 games for the Eagles.\n\nHe is playing on the final year of his rookie contract and is due $1.09 million this season. Matthews had three catches for 18 yards Thursday in the Eagles' 24-9 loss to the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field. Watkins had four catches for 39 yards in the Bills' 17-10 loss to the Minnesota Vikings Thursday at New Era Field in Buffalo.\n\nPhiladelphia made several additions to its passing game this offseason, signing free agents Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith.\n\nThe Bills and the Eagles face off at 7 p.m. on August 17 at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia in their second preseason contest.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 7, "textStart": 0}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-17", "textEnd": 1559, "textStart": 1550}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-10T22:00:00Z", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "source": {"uri": "newsline.com", "title": "Newsline", "id": "18859"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:57:00", "url": "https://newsline.com/philadelphia-eagles-trade-jordan-mathews-to-buffalo-bills/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8893148", "image": "https://newsline.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/cdnph.upi_.comPhiladelphia-Eagles-trade-9707edcad9756675465dbaee349216283aeb2d39.jpg", "date": "2017-08-10", "time": "22:00:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Gaines and a second-round pick per Adam Schefter:\n\nBills have acquired CB E.J. Gaines and Rams 2018 second round pick for WR Sammy Watkins and Bills 2018 sixth round pick.\n\n-- Adam Schefter (@AdamSchefter) August 11, 2017\n\nThis move will reunite former Bills teammates in Watkins and wide-out Robert Woods who the Rams acquired earlier in the offseason. As a result, this move bolsters an offense that the Rams are trying to ensure will look vastly different than it did a year ago.\n\nThe Rams were dead last in yards and scoring last season. They also averaged the least yards per play in the entire league.\n\nThis move provides them with more offensive firepower and also gives them a reliable go-to receiver they have not had in years. Last season Watkins missed half of the season due to injury which limited his production.\n\nIn 2015 when Watkins played in 13 games, he had 60 receptions for 1,047 yards and nine touchdowns. He averaged 17.5 yards per reception and 80.5 yards per game.\n\nThis move will reshape the Rams offense. It now gives them not only a go-to receiver, but also a player who can make plays down the field and draw the defense.\n\nFormer number one overall pick Jared Goff is in position to benefit the most from the Watkins deal. He will get a receiver who makes his job a lot easier and opens up the field.\n\nThis move will hopefully prove to be a big win for the Rams offense.\n\nBrendan Abban is a staff writer for the Los Angeles Rams on Endzonescore and hosts the KBR Sports podcast. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 4, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nelson Agholor"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelson_Agholor", "score": 1, "id": "1275166", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jordan Hicks"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Hicks", "score": 3, "id": "1290965", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "PHILADELPHIA -- Six Eagles teammates met for dinner, a sort of last supper, if only for now. It was emotional and, no doubt, cathartic, too.\n\n\"Somber,\" was how Zach Ertz described the mood. \"Guys were sad. I mean, you're losing a brother.\"\n\nThe six said their good-byes, then Jordan Matthews and Carson Wentz climbed into a car together and Wentz drove Matthews to the airport. The two best friends then bid farewell to each other.\n\n\"It's tough,\" said Wentz, the Eagles quarterback and face of the franchise. \"It's one of those things where there's a personal side of things, and the football side of things. The football side of things, you just have to trust what they're doing upstairs. But on a personal side, it's tough. This is my first time experiencing this with someone that's one of my best friends. Seeing him (Friday), it was tough on him, too. It was kind of out of the blue. There's really no other way to put it. It's just tough personally.\"\n\nSurely you've heard what happened by now. The Eagles traded one of the more popular players on the team and one of its best receivers in Matthews to the Buffalo Bills, along with a third-round draft pick next year, in exchange for cornerback Ronald Darby on Friday afternoon.\n\nThe ripple effect was felt on Saturday, as the Eagles took the practice field just 24 hours after the trade.\n\nEveryone in the locker room respected Matthews, especially the five players who dined with him Friday night: Wentz, tight ends Ertz and Trey Burton, linebacker Jordan Hicks and safety Chris Maragos.\n\n\"It was good to see him one last time before he left,\" Hicks said. \"Just kind of have that conversation, just encourage him and him encourage us. We're brothers for life. It's deeper than just football around here.\"\n\nAs difficult as it was to say good-bye to Matthews, the Eagles can take solace in the fact that they are a better team because of this deal, and that is not to take anything away from Matthews.\n\nThis team needed a cornerback. It's been the most pertinent topic of the offseason. Now they have one, and, as executive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman said shortly after the deal was announced on Friday afternoon: \"You're not going to be able to get anything unless you give something.\"\n\nDarby gives the Eagles a cornerback who becomes an instant starter on the outside, probably opposite Jalen Mills. Both are 23 years old. Waiting in the wings are rookies Rasul Douglas and Sidney Jones, both of whom are 21.\n\n\"With picking up Darby, for sure, I think that was a good pickup,\" Mills said. \"You see that team in Seattle, they were a young secondary, started young, then all those guys grew up together in the league, and now they're one of the top secondaries in the NFL. So for sure, with them doing this it was pretty good.\"\n\nThe biggest concerns, however, are the locker room effect and team chemistry.\n\n\"Everyone loved him,\" Wentz said. \"He was the ultimate competitor out here. He always was about the team first, and so, replacing a guy like that in the locker room is definitely not going to be easy.\"\n\nThey can talk all they want about being professionals and next guy stepping up and all that other clich\u00e9 stuff, but to lose someone as high-quality as Matthews will leave a mark.\n\n\"Our group was extremely close,\" Ertz said. \"The saddest part was him leaving us and us leaving him. We understand the business side of the game. If it wasn't for the Philadelphia Eagles, a kid from California (Ertz), and a kid from Huntsville, Alabama (Matthews) would have never met. He's got a brother for life in me. He knows that, and I know that.\"\n\nIn three years, Matthews was able to earn respect in a locker room of 53 different personalities from points all over the map. He never complained, he fought through injuries, and was grateful for every day he set foot on the field. But he was in the final year of his deal and the Eagles have their sights set on spending their money elsewhere, though it is beyond me why you wouldn't want to build a team around a player of Matthews' high fiber.\n\n\"There's only a few guys that I could say probably work harder than me -- and he's one of them,\" said safety Malcolm Jenkins, the team's defensive leader. \"He's earned a lot of respect from his teammates because of who he is every day. He's earned that respect from me and pretty much everybody in the locker room. He's a great leader. He loves this team and was really excited about this year. But that's the nature of the business so we're all kind of dealing with that personally and individually.\"\n\nWith Matthews no longer around, the doors open opportunities for others. Players like Nelson Agholor, who took first-team reps in Matthews' old slot position on Saturday. Mack Hollins will also get long looks there and perhaps even undrafted rookie Greg Ward.\n\nWentz, though, does not have the kind of chemistry with any of them that he had with Matthews and isn't sure how long it will take to build with Agholor, Hollins or anyone else.\n\n\"We were so close off the field, that on the field that helped just kind of knowing what to expect from each other,\" he said. \"That does take time.\"\n\nAt least it won't be long until the Eagles see Matthews again. It won't be dinner, but the Birds and Bills will play each other in a preseason game Thursday night at Lincoln Financial Field.\n\n\"It's going to be weird,\" Wentz said. \"It's going to be really weird. I don't know. It's not going to be fun, I'll tell you that.\"\n\nEnjoying our content? Become a Burlington County Times subscriber to support stories like these. Philadelphia Eagles took the NFL by surprise Friday afternoon when the team sent wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick to the Buffalo Bills for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\nDarby is an intriguing young player. He's 23 years old, still on his rookie contract and appears to have plenty of years ahead of him. Combining him with second-year pro Jalen Mills and rookies Sidney Jones and Rasul Douglas suddenly gives the Birds a group of young cornerbacks at a position that seemed incredibly thin in early April.\n\nPhiladelphia Eagles trade WR Jordan Matthews to Buffalo Bills for CB Ronald Darby\n\nHere's a look at what Darby's done so far in the pros, where he came from and more.\n\nName: Ronald Darby\n\nAge: 23\n\nExperience: Third season\n\nCollege: Florida State\n\nDrafted: 2015, second round, No. 50 overall by Buffalo\n\nCareer stats: 137 tackles, two interceptions, 33 passes defended\n\nHeight: 5-11\n\nWeight: 193 pounds\n\nDarby entered fall camp as the Bills' No. 1 cornerback despite a sophomore slump in which he failed to intercept a pass. According to Pro Football Focus, Darby graded as the No. 66 cornerback in the NFL last season, a steep fall from his rookie season when the site had him ranked No. 8. As a rookie, Darby's PFF grade of 86.3 was the fifth-best the site had given to a rookie corner since 2006.\n\nThe Bills have been undergoing a defensive shift from Rex Ryan to Sean McDermott this offseason, and it appears Darby didn't quite fit in with the team's future plans.\n\nDarby is a Florida State product, where he was the ACC Defensive Rookie of the Year in 2012. He was a starter on the Seminoles' national championship team the next year and didn't give up any touchdowns. Before Florida State, he played at Potomac High School in Maryland, where he ended his career as a five-star recruit, No. 2 player in Maryland and No. 2 cornerback nationally, according to the 247Sports composite rankings.\n\nHis career in Buffalo got off to a fast start, where he started 15 games and earned PFWA All-Rookie Team honors. Pro Football Focus named him Defensive Rookie of the Year. He made 14 more starts last year -- he has 29 starts in 29 games in his career -- but wasn't able to record an interception.\n\nHowie Roseman: 'Unique opportunity' led to Philadelphia Eagles trade of Jordan Matthews for Ronald Darby\n\nHere's Eagles executive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman's scouting report on Darby:\n\n\"He's got rare speed. His production on the ball, though he doesn't have a high interception number, but his PBU number is incredibly high. He's played a variety of coverages. He won a national championship at FSU. You see him go against the players we go against in our division -- the Bills in 2015 played the NFC East -- so you have that look. When you go into a draft, a lot of those things are unknown, so you have a lot of known quantities in him. We have some people in the building who have been around him, which is an important part as well.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T18:13:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"uri": "pennlive.com", "title": "PennLive.com", "id": "371"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:03:00", "url": "http://www.pennlive.com/philadelphiaeagles/index.ssf/2017/08/meet_new_philadelphia_eagles_c.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8775075", "image": "http://image.pennlive.com/home/penn-media/width620/img/philadelphiaeagles_impact/photo/23219247-standard.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "18:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

explain their emotions after Jordan Matthews trade\n\nSix or seven Philadelphia Eagles players, including quarterback Carson Wentz and tight end Zach Ertz, took a team leader to dinner Friday night to say goodbye.\n\nWhen the Eagles traded wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick to the Bills on Saturday for cornerback Ronald Darby, they parted ways with one of the most admired members of their organization. Matthews earned widespread respect from teammates and developed deep-seated bonds with many of them.\n\nHe and Wentz, for instance, went to Haiti for charity work this offseason and spent time together in North Dakota. Matthews also convinced Ertz to make Christianity a big part of his life.\n\nSo, Friday night's dinner, held several hours after news of the trade broke, was challenging for the group.\n\n\"It was emotional, for sure; somber,\" Ertz said. \"Guys were sad. I mean, you're losing a brother.\"\n\nOn the field, Eagles players seem confident they can replace Matthews' presence as a productive and reliable slot receiver. There's also little doubt that Darby, a second-round pick in 2015 and a two-year starter with Buffalo, can help ease Philadelphia's long-standing woes at cornerback.\n\nBut on a personal level, several Eagles said, Matthews' departure stings. "id": "1272379", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The Buffalo Bills have shown that the drama of the NFL off season is far from over. On Friday, the Bills traded away their starting WR, Sammy Watkins, and their top CB, Ronald Darby.\n\nWatkins was one of QB Tyrod Taylor's favorite targets. Watkins was drafted fourth overall in the 2014 NFL Draft after a fantastic career with the Clemson Tigers. Ronald Darby was drafted 50 overall in the 2015 NFL Draft. Darby finished second in the voting for defensive rookie of the year in 2015.\n\nWhat could motivate such a maneuver by the Bills management? Draft picks, and a focus on building the future.\n\nBuffalo traded Watkins and a 2018 sixth-round pick to the Los Angeles Rams for cornerback E.J. Gains and a 2018 second-round pick. For Darby the Bills received a 2018 third-round pick and WR Jordan Matthews from the Philadelphia Eagles. Both Matthews and Gains are competent players, but not the talent of Watkins and Darby. Both Matthews and Gains are playing on the last year of their respective contracts. After the 2017 season the Bills are not going to be saddled with expensive or lengthy contract obligations. With these moves the Bills now have six picks in the first three rounds of the 2018 NFL Draft (two first round, two second round, and three second round). Depending on how the Bills play the remainder of the preseason they could earn another 2018 third round pick based on the NFL's compensatory pick system.\n\nAlthough the Bills recently signed veteran WR Anquan Boldin to a one-year dear, trading his favorite target does not bode well for the former Hokie QB.\n\nFirst year head coach Sean McDermott and first year general manager Brandon Bean look to be setting up the 2018 NFL Draft to be what they will be betting their career with the Bills on rather than trying to build a team around the pieces left behind by former HC Rex Ryan and GM Dough Whaley.\n\nAs I stated in my Virginia Tech NFL Preseason preview this is a make or break year for Tyrod. These recent moves seem to indicate that the Bills are focusing on the future and will likely be unwilling to take the $18 million cap hit that Tyrod would represent if they kept him on the roster past March 2018. Survival is a great motivator. If they cut him after 2018, there would be no dead cap money. That leaves L.A. with a hard decision: trade Austin, or pay both receivers north of $20 million combined in 2018? For the past three years, the bounty the Bills gave up in order to select him has been an albatross around his neck, made worse by the fact that Odell Beckham, Jr., was available at the spot where Buffalo was originally supposed to pick.\n\nThat might be the case, but for now, the trade is the talk of the town. Gaines and 2018 second-round selection.\n\nBut Buffalo wouldn't wait very long to find Watkins' replacement. "score": 2, "id": "1270484", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "PHILADELPHIA -- The Philadelphia Eagles were desperate for cornerback help. When you're desperate, leverage is not on your side.\n\nExecutive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman ended up paying a significant price to acquire some much-needed help, sending wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third-round pick to the Buffalo Bills for cornerback Ronald Darby.\n\n\"You look around the league, and it is a corner-deficient league,\" Roseman said Friday a short time after the deal went down. \"It's hard to find those guys. It's hard to find guys who have been solid starters in this league and can play at a high level. And teams that have them aren't really ready to move them.\n\n\"In this league, you're not going to be able to get anything unless you give something.\"\n\nIn Darby, they get a young talent with upside who likely was available in part because of the scheme shift under new Bills head coach Sean McDermott. The former second-round pick out of Florida State finished second in voting for defensive rookie of the year in 2015 before taking a bit of a step back last season. Asked what he liked about Darby, Roseman pointed to his \"rare speed\" -- he ran a 4.38-second 40-yard dash at the scouting combine -- as well as his \"production on the ball.\" He only has two career interceptions but has racked up 33 pass breakups in 29 games.\n\nThe Eagles' evaluators also had the benefit of watching Darby against a number of receivers in the division, as the Bills played the NFC East in 2015. So they at least have some idea of how he could fare against Odell Beckham Jr., Dez Bryant, et al.\n\nDarby provides a much-needed talent infusion to a suspect cornerback group. Traveled veteran Patrick Robinson and former seventh-round pick Jalen Mills sat atop the depth chart prior to the trade, with Ron Brooks -- returning from a significant quad injury -- the favorite to man the slot. The corners from top to bottom have struggled with inconsistency through camp, and it was no secret that the Eagles were very much in the market for an upgrade. Darby has a good chance to claim one of the starting spots in short order.\n\nUnlike Matthews, who was in the final year of his rookie deal, Darby still has two years remaining on his -- a critical component to this trade going down. Just 23, he joins a young group of promising corners that includes Mills and rookies Sidney Jones and Rasul Douglas.\n\nIt's to be determined how Darby will fit into the locker room (there were some character concerns coming out of FSU) and into Jim Schwartz's scheme, but there's little question that the back end of the Eagles defense is in better shape from an ability perspective as a result of the acquisition.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:02:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "title": "ESPN.com", "id": "4"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:02:00", "url": "http://www.espn.com/blog/nfceast/post/_/id/77288", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8715923", "image": "http://a4.espncdn.com/combiner/i?img=%2Fphoto%2F2015%2F1029%2Fr21025_1296x729_16%2D9.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:02:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro_Football_Focus", "score": 3, "id": "362367", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Watchdog journalism"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watchdog_journalism", "Ron Brooks"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ron_Brooks", "score": 2, "id": "412589", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nigel Bradham"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigel_Bradham", "score": 2, "id": "412591", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Man-to-man defense"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man-to-man_defense", "score": 2, "id": "468081", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Howie Roseman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howie_Roseman", "score": 2, "id": "571949", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Corey Graham"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corey_Graham", "score": 3, "id": "579501", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}], "body": "Ronald Darby's first day with the Eagles came Saturday, and he watched practice from the sideline in sweats and a bucket hat. He needed to wait for Jordan Matthews to complete his physical in Buffalo before taking the field for the Eagles.\n\nIt's not expected to take long for Darby to become the Eagles' top cornerback. After the Eagles traded Matthews and a third-round pick for Darby on Friday, the 23-year-old Maryland native is in line to be a big part of the Eagles' present and future. He brings top-end speed that the other cornerbacks lack and a playing style that fits what defensive coordinator Jim Schwartz wants at the position.\n\n\"Everybody knows me for my speed,\" Darby said, \"but I'm willing to come up and tackle. Play aggressive.\"\n\nDarby thrived as a rookie in 2015 as an immediate starter for the Bills and had two interceptions and 21 passes defended. He was named Pro Football Focus' defensive rookie of the year that season. His performance declined last year, and Darby said he needed to do a better job finishing plays. Eagles safety Corey Graham, who started next to Darby in Buffalo, said scheme adjustments last season hurt the entire defense. He remembers how Darby excelled as a rookie and said that will translate to the Eagles.\n\n\"He was special the whole year,\" Graham said. \"He was lights out from the beginning. ...The kid has talent. As long as he can get in the playbook and learn exactly what we're doing and play fast, he'll be good.\"\n\nGraham, who has played in Schwartz's system before, indicated that Darby is a better fit in the Eagles scheme than what the Bills are expected to run this year with new coach Sean McDermott. Darby's man-to-man coverage ability is expected to be an asset. Darby didn't anticipate it taking a long time to learn the Eagles defense. Although Graham said Darby is better when he can play fast and not think, the concepts are similar to what Darby has done before.\n\n\"Corner, it's not that difficult once you get the concepts down, know the names of the plays,\" Darby said.\n\nDarby said he's a \"great match\" for the aggressive personality that Schwartz likes in his defensive backs. It's how Darby said he's played since he was at Florida State. In man-to-man defense, he said he can run against anybody. A high school track star who won the bronze medal in the 200 meters in the 2011 World Youth Championships, Darby ran a 4.38-second 40-yard dash at the combine in 2015. If he was tested this summer, he said the time would be even faster.\n\n\"I know for sure low 4.3s,\" Darby said.\n\nSafety Terrence Brooks, who was Darby's teammate at Florida State, said that Darby is \"so damn quick, it's crazy.\" But he also commented on Darby's physicality, which he didn't think should be lost when looking at Darby.\n\nGraham and Brooks are among the familiar faces Darby saw at Eagles practice. He knows former Bills teammates Ron Brooks and Nigel Bradham and former Florida State teammate Tim Jernigan. That will help in the transition to the Eagles.\n\nCoach Doug Pederson said the Eagles will treat Darby similar to how they did Graham last week - give him a couple days to evaluate how he fits and then figure out what to do. Pederson said the Eagles will \"take it slow with him,\" not wanting to put him on the field when he doesn't know the defense. If Darby is available for Thursday's game against the Bills - Darby's former team - Pederson said he would play.\n\nThe Eagles need Darby ready by Week 1. That's when the NFC East schedule starts in Washington. Howie Roseman said the Eagles watched how Darby played against the division's receivers in 2015. Asked if he's excited to go against them again, Darby responded, \"Hell yeah!\"\n\nDarby watched the Eagles' other young cornerbacks on the field Saturday. He stood with Sidney Jones. Much is expected of Darby this season, but if the Eagles were right about the trade, he'll be in the Eagles secondary for years to come. He said it's even more \"exciting\" to know that it will come in Philadelphia in front of fans that impressed him in person when the Bills visited in 2015.\n\n\"The future's looking bright,\" Darby said. \"Right now's looking bright.\"\n\nRead more by Zach Berman Published: August 12, 2017 \u00e2\u0080\" 3:01 AM EDT Thanks for your continued support...\n\nWe recently asked you to support our journalism. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zach_Ertz", "score": 2, "id": "382797", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Chris Maragos"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chris_Maragos", "score": 3, "id": "386830", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Howie Roseman"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howie_Roseman", "score": 4, "id": "571949", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Asante Samuel"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asante_Samuel", "score": 4, "id": "872943", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carson Wentz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 3, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Six years ago, Philadelphia Eagles executive vice president of football operations Howie Roseman, who owned a title, general manager, with more clarity and far fewer words at the time, was accused of playing \"fantasy football\" by disgruntled cornerback Asante Samuel.\n\nFriday's decision to trade wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a third-round draft pick to Buffalo for cornerback Ronald Darby seemed on the surface like just such a move, one that might not take into account the intangibles lost by jettisoning an ultra-popular player like Matthews, who is instrumental in building a winning culture.\n\nThe difference between the fantasy football complaint of 2011 and today is that there was no similar outrage expressed by any of the players about a squad that, for better or worse, will have a new look and feel with Matthews suddenly out of the picture.\n\nYes, there was shock. Yes, there was sadness.\n\nNo, a revolt was not forthcoming.\n\nThe Eagles began in earnest on Saturday, with a long, full-contact practice in pads that started just 33 hours after they took them off following their preseason opener in Buffalo, to put the Jordan Matthews era behind them.\n\n\"Sometimes,\" safety Chris Maragos said, \"when you face adversity, you find different ways to do things and you can overcome them.\"\n\nThough Matthews was respected and beloved by all, his former teammates are doing all they can to carry on.\n\n\"It's the middle of camp,\" safety Malcolm Jenkins added. \"So a lot of it is somber. I mean, we're less than 48 hours from a game, guys are a little bit sore. You're either happy or disappointed in the way you performed, didn't win the game and then you lose somebody in the locker room like Jordan Matthews and then you get a two-hour, 40-minute practice in full pads, live. So yeah ... definitely down today. It's one of those things that you've got to kind of fight through.\"\n\nQuarterback Carson Wentz likely was hit hardest by this decision. Not only did he lose his favorite wide receiver, but one of his best friends.\n\n\"Numbers don't tell you what kind of person he is, how he treats people and the effect he has on their lives,\" he said.\n\nAt the same time, Wentz is not ready to stand up and wonder aloud: \"Just what the heck is going on here?\"\n\nAfter driving Matthews to the airport on Friday, reality hit.\n\n\"Unfortunately this is a part of the business I'm experiencing for the first time,\" he said at his locker after Saturday's practice.\n\nA few minutes earlier, he put on a happier face for the TV cameras.\n\n\"You've just got to trust what they're doing upstairs,\" he said. \"Ultimately, they're the ones who make the decisions and what they think is best for the team I'm going to be in support of 100 percent. They haven't let me down or haven't let this team down yet.\"\n\nLater on Saturday, the Eagles signed undrafted free agent wide receiver Keevan Lucas, who was a teammate of quarterback Dane Evans at Tulsa, and assigned him Matthews' old number of 81.\n\nHead coach Doug Pederson probably wasn't happy to see Matthews go, either, saying he had a \"good relationship\" with the receiver. But he put on a bold face nevertheless.\n\n\"It's like anything that we do in life,\" he said. \"The next person steps up and here we go. We can sit and have poor attitudes and all that, but at the same time we're happy for both parties, and we're moving forward. That's business as usual.\"\n\nExcept it's not.\n\n\"From a personal standpoint, basically every time I do one-on-ones, it's against Jordan Matthews,\" Jenkins said. \"I stay after [practice] and do some releases with receivers, it's Jordan Matthews. So for me, even in my daily preparation, I've got to find a new Jordan Matthews.\n\n\"And I know he's kind of been that guy to a bunch of different guys lives, whether it be Carson Wentz or Trey Burton, Zach Ertz. He's had a big role in a lot of guys' lives.\"\n\nBut Jenkins and the Eagles will carry on, and if Darby can be what they think he can be at a position of greater need, then they will all get over what happened on Friday that much quicker.\n\n\"I talked with Howie,\" Maragos said, \"and he was very, very open, and he was like, 'this was a very tough decision to do.' I mean, he understands the weight of things and I think he, more than anybody, understands chemistry, camaraderie, all those types of things. He understands the severity of it.\n\n\"And I know [owner] Mr. [Jeff] Lurie too. He really respects quality people and [those are] the type of people he wants in this organization. So they take those things very, very seriously.\"\n\nMore than a new look, the Eagles will have a new feel having lost one of their most beloved leaders.\n\nNaturally, their next preseason game is against the Bills Thursday night at home. It means Matthews will come out of the visitors tunnel.\n\n\"It's going to be weird, really weird,\" Wentz said. \"I don't know. It's not going to be fun, I'll tell you that.\"\n\nNothing about Friday and Saturday was, either.\n\nYet this team has no choice but to pick up and keep going.\n\n\"At the end of the day, we've got to do what's best on the field,\" Maragos said. \"For me, as much as I love Jordan, Darby is going to help us out, and we've got receivers that can play. And that's the business.\"\n\nPROFILE: RONALD DARBY\n\nBorn: January 2, 1994 (age 23), Oxon Hill, MD\n\nPosition: Cornerback, Philadelphia Eagles\n\nCollege: Florida State\n\nAcquired: Trade with Buffalo Bills\n\nExperience: 3rd year\n\nHeight: 5' 11''\n\nWeight: 190 lbs.\n\nCareer accomplishments: Two interceptions, 33 pass breakups and 137 tackles in 29 career games (all starts) with Buffalo, which selected him in second round 2015 NFL Draft.\n\nNotable: One of the fastest players in the NFL, Darby ran a 4.38-second 40-yard dash at the NFL Scouting Combine.\n\nNfierro@mcall.com\n\nTwitter @nickfierro\n\n610-778-2243", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "1994-01-02", "textEnd": 5271, "textStart": 5256}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T19:28:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"uri": "mcall.com", "title": "The Morning Call", "id": "1805"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:07:00", "url": "http://www.mcall.com/sports/football/eagles/mc-spt-new-look-eagles-20170812-story.html", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8924715", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-598f87d8/turbine/mc-spt-new-look-eagles-20170812", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "19:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

He is entering the final year of his deal.\n\nFor the Bills, this move was about acquiring draft picks for the future: The new regime has already made a decision to move on from Watkins, the prize pick of the old regime. Overall, the Bills have six picks in the first three rounds.\n\nThe Bills never bottomed out as badly as the Browns in recent years, but Buffalo's impressive stash of draft selections rivals that of Cleveland, which is in full-blown rebuilding mode. "score": 2, "id": "579501", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}], "body": "PHILADELPHIA -- The Eagles' newest cornerback, Ronald Darby, knows the one word most people across the NFL would use to describe him: fast.\n\nA former track star, Darby ran the 40-yard dash in a blazing 4.38 seconds at the NFL combine in 2015 and maintained his reputation as a speedster through two seasons with the Bills. And, the 5-foot-11 corner said Saturday he's even faster than when he first entered the league.\n\nEagles cornerback Jalen Mills doesn't need a reminder about new teammate's speed. At LSU, Mills used to watch tape of the best corners across the country and spent plenty of time studying Darby. Guess what quality stuck out?\n\n\"He's a quick guy, you know what I mean?\" Mills said. \"A really quick guy.\"\n\nBut over the next four weeks, Darby faces a significant challenge. He needs to get comfortable playing in the Eagles' defense -- and he needs to do it fast.\n\nThe Birds acquired Darby in exchange for wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round pick Friday in large part because of their woes at cornerback. Patrick Robinson and Mills didn't inspire much confidence as the presumed starters, and third-round rookie Rasul Douglas likely needs more seasoning before he's prepared to accept a large role on an NFL defense.\n\nEntering this week, Philly's corners represented a glaring weakness on an otherwise balanced roster. The Eagles pegged Darby as the antidote for the struggled, but with the Sept. 10 regular season opener at Washington sitting less than a month away, he'll need to get acclimated to new surroundings in a hurry.\n\nHe seems to understand the task.\n\n\"My goal right now is to come in and learn from the vets -- vets like [safety Malcolm] Jenkins and all of them,\" Darby said. \"Just kind of learn the playbook.\"\n\n'You're losing a brother': Philadelphia Eagles react to Jordan Matthews' departure\n\nDarby isn't overly concerned about adapting to a new defense, though. He's joining a slew of former teammates -- he played with Eagles defensive backs Ron Brooks and Corey Graham and linebacker Nigel Bradham in Buffalo, while defensive tackle Tim Jernigan played with Darby at Florida State - and that could ease the transition.\n\nPlus, Darby said he's heard players rave about defensive coordinator Jim Schwartz, who doesn't run an overly complex scheme.\n\nAnd cornerbacks often have the same responsibilities in different defenses, so Darby doesn't expect to study unfamiliar techniques.\n\n\"At corner, it's not that difficult,\" Darby said. \"Once you get the concepts down, remember the names of plays and things, it comes pretty fast.\"\n\nStill, coach Doug Pederson said the team will try to play Darby in Thursday night's preseason game against the Bills, his old team. After that, Philly will wrap training camp and head toward the thick of preparation for the regular season, meaning they won't have much time to catch players up on schemes.\n\nSo, Darby will aim to nail down the Eagles' playbook and his responsibilities within the defense as quickly as he jolts around a football field. And if he can do that, he'll help spin the Eagles' crop of cornerbacks from a deficiency to a position filled with promise.\n\nAt 23, Darby believes he can still look ahead to prime years. Second-round rookie Sidney Jones, 22, has the talent to develop into a mainstay in Philly's secondary once he recover from a torn Achilles tendon. Mills, 23, and Douglas, 21, also have potential to produce steady play for the Birds in the years to come.\n\nDarby is the central piece. If he can settle in with the Eagles, he can be a fast fix at a key position.\n\n\"I just know it's a young group,\" Darby said of the Eagles' corners. \"I see them today, they're out there working hard, and there's a lot of talent. The future's looking bright. Matthews joins an offense that struggled through the air in 2016, as the Bills ranked 30th in passing offense and 27th in passing touchdowns (17).\n\nAs for Darby, the Eagles receive a cornerback who accounted for 69 combined tackles and 12 passes defensed in 2016. "score": 4, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Back (American football)"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_American_football_positions#Offensive_backfield", "score": 1, "id": "1269718", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Eric Rowe"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Rowe", "score": 3, "id": "1284489", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "PHILADELPHIA -- The new cornerback was at practice on Saturday, but he could not practice.\n\nRonald Darby was acquired by the Eagles in a blockbuster trade on Friday afternoon and was ready to go. Except the player he was traded for, receiver Jordan Matthews, had not yet taken his physical with his new team, the Buffalo Bills.\n\nWhen Darby is able to practice -- probably on Sunday -- it probably won't be long before he becomes one of the starting corners.\n\n\"My goal right now is to come in, learn from the vets like (Malcolm) Jenkins, and learn the playbook,\" Darby said. \"Corner is not that difficult. Once you get the concepts down and remember names of plays and things, it comes pretty fast. It's very exciting, especially in a city like this with great fans.\"\n\nCertainly the Birds bulked up their secondary, but it did not come without a heavy price. Not only did they have to part ways with the popular Matthews, they also had to throw in a third-round draft pick in 2018.\n\nIt was evident that the Birds needed help at corner. Darby, who is 5-foot-11, 195 pounds, is just 23 years old and has made 29 career starts already. Like Matthews, he was a former second-round pick, the 50th player taken overall in 2015 after having played at Florida State. In his rookie season two years ago, he had two interceptions, but none last year.\n\nHe gives the Eagles a young cornerback group that can grow and learn together. Sidney Jones and Rasul Douglas are both 21, Jalen Mills is 23 and C.J. Smith is 24.\n\n\"It's kind of a unique opportunity to have a bunch of young corners at that position,\" said Howie Roseman, the team's executive vice president of football operations. \"We spent a lot of time going over this because this is obviously a big trade for our football team, and you look around the league and it is a corner deficient league. It's hard to find those guys. It's hard to find guys who have been solid starters in this league and can play at a high level, and teams that have them aren't really ready to move them.\"\n\nThat didn't make the decision to deal Matthews any easier. It was equally as difficult to part with a third-round pick next year, because it now leaves the Eagles currently without picks in the second and third rounds, though they have three in the fourth -- their own, Minnesota's and New England's. The Patriots' pick could become a third-rounder if cornerback Eric Rowe, traded last year, gets at least 50 percent of their defensive snaps. Interestingly, the Eagles drafted Rowe 47th overall in the same draft that Darby went 50th overall.\n\nRoseman said the team wasn't actively shopping Matthews, even though Matthews had only this season left on his rookie contract. The VP added that he would not have done the deal if the player they were getting back had only one year left on his contract. Darby has two seasons remaining on his contract.\n\n\"You worry about everything when you trade a professional like Jordan Matthews,\" Roseman said. \"This isn't one where you're celebrating and doing a dance, because you're giving up a good player and a good pick. But in this league you're not going to be able to get anything unless you give something. I think we have a really good group, a character group, not only at the wide receiver positon but on this team and on the offensive side of the ball. But it hurts when people you care about leave.\"\n\nPederson's approach\n\nHead coach Doug Pederson said he may not allow receiver Alshon Jeffery to participate in team drills for the remainder of training camp.\n\n\"I just want to make sure he's healthy,\" the coach said. \"We're not playing for a while. Just want to give him plenty of rest. He's getting a lot of work with Carson (Wentz) in seven-on-sevens and individual work, getting everything he needs to get done leading up to the season.\"\n\nPederson may take the same approach with veterans such as Darren Sproles, who he said probably won't play again in the preseason. The coach is also giving plenty of rest during team drills to left tackle Jason Peters, defensive end Chris Long and defensive tackle Fletcher Cox.\n\n\"Everybody is case by case,\" Pederson said. \"It's individual by individual. This is the best interest for him.\"\n\nPumphrey concerns\n\nAfter a preseason in which he put the ball on the ground twice, rookie running back Donnel Pumphrey fumbled again during 11-on-11 work after being hit by linebacker Steven Daniels.\n\n\"We have to continue to work, work through that,\" Pederson said. \"(Saturday) was a very humid day. The guys were sweating a bunch. You could probably attribute it to that. I don't want to make excuses for guys. We just got to -- you know, the emphasis is obviously hanging onto the ball, whether he's catching a punt or obviously in the backfield. Just got to make a point of emphasis with him.\"\n\nMissing\n\nQuarterback Nick Foles did not practice again on Saturday and has missed most of camp with elbow soreness.\n\nPederson said that Foles would try to do some things Saturday afternoon after practice, then \"We'll see where he's at here in the next couple days.\"\n\nOthers of note who did not practice included running back Wendell Smallwood (hamstring), receiver Bryce Treggs (leg soreness), offensive tackle Halapoulivaati Vaitai (knee), right guard Brandon Brooks (ankle), cornerback Ron Brooks (hamstring) and cornerback Aaron Grymes (personal reasons).\n\nRoster move\n\nThe Eagles signed receiver Keevan Lucas and waived linebacker Steven Daniels on Saturday. Lucas, who played in the slot at Tulsa, was in the Eagles' rookie camp back in May on a tryout. He is 5-9, 190.\n\nEnjoying our content? Gaines"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._J._Gaines", "score": 2, "id": "380502", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Sean McDermott"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_McDermott", "score": 3, "id": "408038", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jerry Hughes"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerry_Hughes", "score": 2, "id": "428368", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Doug Whaley"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doug_Whaley", "score": 2, "id": "500200", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Eric Wood"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Wood", "score": 3, "id": "574428", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Stephon Gilmore"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephon_Gilmore", "score": 1, "id": "600930", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Rams"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Los_Angeles_Rams", "score": 4, "id": "650475", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 2, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Pat Mahomes"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Mahomes", "score": 2, "id": "786638", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Ryan Groy"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Groy", "score": 3, "id": "1283128", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Shaq Lawson"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaq_Lawson", "score": 2, "id": "1313831", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Sammy Watkins was traded to the Rams, but Bills fans have reason to hope in 2018 and beyond\n\nNo, the Buffalo Bills aren't tanking and no, Sammy Watkins shouldn't be considered a bust yet. The injury prone receiver's trade to the Los Angeles Rams may seem like a bid for a complete rebuild, but the Bills should be (and seemingly are) viewing 2017 as a transition year. While they won't be contending for the AFC East this season, they're in a perfect situation to not repeat the mistakes that they made with Rex Ryan before Sean McDermott took the helm.\n\nFor starters, the Tyrod Taylor contract needs to be examined. Taylor is locked in through 2018, with his 2019 salary being voided after a restructure. Some expected the Bills to sign Taylor to a massive deal, but they instead opted to bid their time a bit. The restructure, which Taylor accepted in March, is largely a transition contract while the Bills figure out exactly what their future is at quarterback. Should someone really stand out to them in the 2018 draft, they may take a shot on him, have him ride the bench while Taylor plays out his contract, and let the veteran test the market in 2019.\n\nIf Taylor makes it to free agency in 2019, he'll share a free-agent class that includes Carson Palmer , Matt Ryan and Alex Smith . Ryan will assuredly be re-signed by the Atlanta Falcons , Palmer may hang it up after this contract and Smith will largely be determined by the Kansas City Chiefs ' success over the next few years. Bottomline: Taylor has the potential to be playing for a serious franchise QB contract, and if the Bills find a player that they love in the 2018 draft, they'll have the means to take a shot outside of Taylor.\n\nAccording to Spotrac, in 2018 the Bills will have over $26 million of cap space available in free agency. Defensive tackle Kyle Williams and center Eric Wood will both be hitting the market. Both could be considered priorities during the offseason, but Williams will be 35 next year and 2016 third-round pick Adolphus Washington looms as a replacement, while advanced metrics loved the job Ryan Groy did last season filling in as an injury replacement on the offensive line.\n\nIf the Bills don't want to give Washington the starting job at defensive tackle or re-sign Williams, they could pursue Star Lotulelei of the Carolina Panthers , who is an unrestricted free agent in 2018. McDermott, of course, worked with Lotulelei in Carolina, and would give the Bills two potential stars in the middle of the defensive line. It's common practice for coordinators to bring some of their guys over upon team switches, and Lotulelei, who will be 28 next season, makes the most sense. McDermott is bringing back the 4-3 defense that Buffalo was successful in before Ryan tried converting them to a 3-4 base. With the talent that Buffalo has and McDermott's emphasis on pressure, Lotulelei is a great fit in Buffalo alongside pass rushing terrors like Jerry Hughes and potential 2016 first-round pick Shaq Lawson .\n\nWith all of this being said, there's one category that this benefits the Bills the most in: the draft. The Bills now have a cornucopia of options. They have two first-round picks, two second-round picks, two third-round picks, and a fourth, fifth and seventh. With nine draft picks -- six in the first three rounds -- Buffalo can now sit on them or try to deal them to teams that are seeking more early round talent.\n\nThe Bills traded their first-round pick in 2017 to the Chiefs (who selected Pat Mahomes), primarily for the Chiefs' 2018 first-rounder in addition to a pick-swap in the first round and a mid-round pick. Now, with Watkins going to the Rams for a second-rounder and E.J. Gaines and Ronald Darby being sent to the Eagles for a third-round pick and Jordan Matthews , they have the entire 2017 season to evaluate needs and draft accordingly. Should they decide that they want someone more established, teams are always willing to flip established players for picks.\n\nThe final factor: There's a new GM in Buffalo. Brandon Beane was hired from a Panthers executive position in March, and he seems intent on making sure that this is his Bills team. That isn't necessarily a bad thing -- every GM has different philosophies -- and Doug Whaley's may not have aligned with Beane's.\n\nBeane's moves could be interpreted in one of two ways: a mad scramble to do whatever he can to claim the team before the season, or a calculated effort in which he realizes that the team as it stands likely isn't a 2017 contender, but has the potential to be in 2018 and onward. These moves, and the timing of them, appear to be the latter case. Transitioning between coaches is a difficult endeavor, transitioning between coaches and GMs is a titanic one. Beane's moves feel chaotic, but beyond surface level they seem to be highly pragmatic.\n\nAll-in-all, the moves leave Buffalo in a pretty good spot. They lose one of their biggest unproven contract obligations in Watkins, and they give the Rams -- a team that probably shouldn't be taking rental players -- a rental player in Watkins while getting back great value for him. The Darby move is a bit more questionable, but he fits the timetable, as Darby would be a free agent in 2019 and could be in position to cash in after following up his excellent rookie season with a solid 2016 performance. The Bills just made cornerback a massive need, what with Darby being gone and Stephon Gilmore heading to the New England Patriots , but they have the means to fill that need (and Gaines can be a stopgap if need be) and do have 2017 first-rounder Tre'Davious White as one long-term piece at the position.\n\nThese are moves made with a long-term plan in mind. Beane doesn't care about Watkins's Fantasy value, but rather what he means to the Bills' outlook, both now and in the future. Trading a player on an expiring contract that has had injury issues for a second-round pick is a practical move, and it sets the Bills up well for the near future. Even though fans might not like it, if Buffalo plays things right (starting in March of 2018), they'll cotton on quickly.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T19:08:00Z", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "title": "CBS Sports", "id": "765"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:08:00", "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/the-bills-are-perfectly-set-up-to-build-a-winner-after-trading-watkins-darby/", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8685337", "image": "https://sportshub.cbsistatic.com/i/r/2017/08/04/0c45d364-0c48-4c9c-a2b4-7d8bd530692d/thumbnail/770x433/2e9b2e83c2abb4393f0cb0633f4d66dd/sammy-watkins-2.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "19:08:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

Eagles eased the uncertainty surrounding the cornerback position by welcoming Ronald Darby to Philadelphia.\n\nFriday's trade sent former wide receiver Jordan Matthews and a 2018 third-round pick to the Buffalo Bills in exchange for the third-year cornerback. As chance would have it, not only does Darby strengthen a budding young core at the cornerback position, but he also reunites with a handful of players from his time in Buffalo and at Florida State.\n\n\"It's like a comfortable feeling. Not even Nigel (Bradham) and Timmy (Tim Jernigan), but I also know Corey Graham, Ron Brooks. Those guys were with me at Buffalo so it's good to be around people you know,\" Darby said after Saturday's practice.\n\nBrooks and Darby share one of the closer connections on the team after the two spent the 2015 season - Darby's rookie season - on the Bills. He tallied two interceptions, 61 solo tackles, and 21 passes defensed in an impressive first year.\n\n\"He's definitely going to be a big contributor in this defense once he learns it and gets it down,\" Brooks said. \"He's definitely going to be a good addition.\"\n\nAdding to Darby's extensive list of former teammates, safety Terrence Brooks, who played with Darby for two seasons back at Florida State spoke highly of the Oxon Hill, Maryland native.\n\n\"If we're fortunate enough to get on the field together that'll be a great thing,\" the safety said. \"Darby and I had quite a bit of time with each other at Florida State and just to have him here is a blessing too. I mean the kid is a scrapper. He goes out there and he's got tight coverage, he doesn't shy away from contact, and that's like me too. So we all bring that kind of Florida State feel to this defense.\"\n\nThe Eagles' receiving corps received a tremendous upgrade during the offseason by adding the likes of Alshon Jeffery, Torrey Smith, and draft picks Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson which allowed the team to make a deal that would build up its most questionable position. Head coach Doug Pederson understood the decision to part ways with Matthews was a difficult one, but the trade was made based on what was best for the team.\n\n\"We're getting a tremendous athlete, obviously a two-year starter. What I've seen on tape - obviously I didn't study him when he came out of college - but what I've seen so far and what I'm hearing is (he is) not only a good teammate but a good person,\" Pederson said of Darby. \"Someone that's going to get in and get in the mix and get with a group of guys that know our system. We'll take it day by day with him and see where he's at.\n\n\"By no means are we gameplanning anybody right now. It's very basic on both sides of the ball. Just learning the terminology. We've got a week before we play again. We're hoping that he can be caught up and get some reps in the game.\"\n\nDarby, who did not practice Saturday as Matthews needed to first pass his physical in Buffalo, will likely headline an Eagles cornerback position armed with young talent including second-year player Jalen Mills, second-round pick Sidney Jones, and third-round pick Rasul Douglas. They will have the opportunity to grow and develop together as a secondary.\n\n\"I know it's a young group. I'm a young guy, only 23, and I saw them today and they're out there working hard and there's a lot of talent,\" Darby said. \"The future is looking bright so I just want to go out there and work with them and get better each day.\n\n\"It's very exciting especially in a city like this with great fans and Philadelphia itself. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Les_Snead", "score": 3, "id": "1294347", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "The former Eagles wide receiver clearly has reason to be upset after being traded so suddenly. He's moving away from the friends and teammates he had in Philadelphia.\n\nAnother reason for Matthews to be upset is that it seems like Buffalo isn't even super interested in him.\n\nIt's typically standard for a team trading for a player on a one-year deal to start negotiating a long-term contract. But it sounds like the Bills aren't in a rush to keep Matthews. The Eagles' 2018 third-round pick was the real prize of the trade for Buffalo.\n\nContrast that to what's going on in Los Angeles with the Rams. They traded with Buffalo because they really wanted Sammy Watkins. Rams GM Les Snead publicly admitted the team wants to extend his contract.\n\nThe point I'm trying to make here is that this Eagles-Bills trade indicates Matthews' value was not very high. I've seen some question why the draft pick had to included and this trade wasn't just a player-for-player swap: Matthews for Ronald Darby. Now you have your answer.\n\nIt shouldn't be a surprise that Matthews' value wasn't very high. As previously mentioned, he's going into a contract year. The league likely realizes there could be a disconnect between what his agent will be asking for (based on Matthews' inflated stats) and the player's actual value relative to his skill set.\n\nAnother comparison I'd like to make while illustrating this point is the Brandin Cooks trade. Cooks only has 188 more yards and one more touchdown than Matthews does in his career. The Patriots surrendered a first-round pick because they really wanted him. Now compare that to the Matthews trade where he had to be traded in addition to a third-round pick in order for the Eagles to get Darby.\n\nI'm real curious about how he even fits in Buffalo. Anquan Boldin and rookie Zay Jones are already slot guys. That's where Matthews has played in most of his career. Maybe the Bills will try him on the outside, but he hasn't had success there in limited playing time. In 2016, Matthews played on the outside for 32.9% of Philadelphia's offensive snaps, according to Pro Football Focus. Matthews was targeted 40 times when not playing in the slot. He had 20 receptions for 222 yards (a paltry 11.1 average).\n\nIt's a bummer to see Matthews end up in a situation where he's not necessarily wanted long-term. Gaines and a third-round pick. They also dealt top cornerback Ronald Darby to the Philadelphia Eagles for receiver Jordan Matthews and a second-round draft choice.\n\nMcDermott and Beane conceded they would need to sell Friday's trades to the locker room and to fans who've waited nearly 18 years for a playoff appearance.\n\n\"I get it,\" McDermott said. \"I absolutely get it. That's why I didn't sleep last night because these are tough decisions. I'm a part of that. When I signed my name to that dotted line, I became a part of that 17-year time period.\"\n\nMcDermott added, \"I'm invested. I feel what they feel.\"\n\nThe draft picks, if used properly, will serve the Bills longer than whatever Watkins and Darby would've contributed in 2017. And those losses are additionally mitigated by obtaining Matthews and Gaines.\n\nBuffalo owns six selections within the first three rounds of next year's draft.\n\nAs one AFC general manager texted to me, second- and third-round picks for players the Bills obviously didn't want is a nice return.\n\nBeane was asked how he'll try to convince Bills veterans -- defensive tackle Kyle Williams needed to be persuaded to return for a 12th season -- they're still trying to field the best possible team and make a playoff run.\n\n\"Well, it's hard,\" Beane said, \"because these guys are talented players. ... They don't necessarily know Jordan or E.J. So hopefully they'll reserve judgment until those guys get in and strap the pads on and jump in with them. We'll see where it goes from there.\"\n\nWhen quarterback Tyrod Taylor re-signed with the Bills this offseason, he expected to throw to Watkins.\n\nTaylor and Watkins took 16 snaps together in Thursday night's exhibition against the Minnesota Vikings at New Era Field. Taylor connected with Watkins on each of the first three plays and sent five of the eight passes he attempted Watkins' way.\n\nFifteen hours after the game, Watkins was gone.\n\nMcDermott was asked how he will explain Friday's decisions to Taylor.\n\n\"I'll take it a step further and how you sell it to the entire team,\" McDermott said before Friday's practice. \"My stance with our football team and the leaders of our football team -- you mention Tyrod, being one of them -- is to be honest and up front with these guys.\n\n\"They know that we're going to do everything possible and make every decision that's in the best interest of this football team short- and long-term. That's my responsibility.\n\n\"I believe in clear and concise communication and developing trust, and that's what I hope has developed over the course of the first six months on the job.\"\n\nHope. He was slated on the depth charge to start at cornerback this season. You don't know me if you think I'm throwing in the towel.\n\n\"I get it\", McDermott said.\n\nI can imagine the Rams, with no real number one receiver, liked watching that. \"We go with the information that we have since they've been in Eagles uniforms and that wide receiver group has been tremendously competitive throughout the spring and summer\".\n\n\"It doesn't say anything\", Beane said. If we were throwing in the towel, I wouldn't have tried to get a starting receiver back. In the final year of his rookie contract, Matthews will be eager to get on the same page as new quarterback Tyrod Taylor, but with Andre Holmes, Anquan Boldin and rookie Zay Jones now representing his top competitors for targets, the 25-year-old should like his chances of finally topping the 1,000-yard mark.\n\nThe trades caught Bills players by surprise a day after a 17-10 preseason-opening loss to Minnesota. It's a win-now league. \"It's our best interest\". The Bills previously declined his 2018 option.\n\nIf Watkins can live up to Robey-Coleman's assessment, it becomes a worthwhile transaction, even if it also means using the franchise tag to keep him or signing him to a lucrative long-term deal as his contract expires at the end of this season. The Bills were already expected to shift more of a high-percentage passing game this season, which wouldn't have suited Watkins, who averages a lid-lifting 16.1 yards per reception in his career.\n\nWatkins has been hampered by an assortment of injuries and limited to playing just eight games last season after having surgery for a broken left foot. Walt Powell, who caught 14 passes for the Bills in 2016, is the leading returning wide receiver, and he's suspended for the first four games of the regular season. When the trade happened, they had to throw in the third-rounder, because as Roseman noted, it's \"a corner-deficient league\", and prying away a starting-quality corner from anyone in August is a hard feat. \"And teams that have them aren't really ready to move them\".\n\nEJ Gaines, the former sixth-round pick out of Missouri, started over Trumane Johnson in his rookie year back in 2014. Gaines from the Rams.\n\nBuffalo also continued stockpiling 2018 draft picks by getting a second-round selection from Los Angeles and a third-rounder from the Eagles. The Bills dealt a sixth-round pick to the Rams as part of the Watkins trade.\n\nThe shakeup continues an offseason overhaul under new coach Sean McDermott and GM Brandon Beane.\n\nWatkins was a starter since Buffalo traded up five spots in the 2014 draft to select him with the No. 4 pick. He has 153 catches for 2,459 yards and 17 touchdowns in three seasons but topped 1,000 yards just once (2015).\n\nWatkins' future in Buffalo was already in question after the Bills declined to pick up his fifth-year contract option in May.\n\nMatthews, also entering the last year of his contract, was Philadelphia's most productive receiver, averaging 75 catches, 891 receiving yards and six touchdowns in his first three seasons. But the Eagles signed free-agent receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith and drafted Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson.\n\nDarby started 29 games in his first two seasons in Buffalo. He was a second-round pick (50th overall) in the 2015 draft.\n\nRavens lose two more\n\nAiling Ravens quarterback Joe Flacco won't play in the preseason as he continues to recover from a back injury. According to the team, Flacco remains on track to start Sept. 10 when the Ravens open the regular season against the Bengals.\n\nTwo other offensive players, however, won't be playing in that game.\n\nThe Ravens announced starting left guard Alex Lewis and rookie wide receiver Tim White will miss the season with injuries that will require surgery. They become the eighth and ninth players since June 1 that the Ravens have lost for the year because of injury, suspension or retirement.\n\nPackers ask for review of hits\n\nThe Packers submitted videos to the NFL of hits by Eagles players that knocked out Green Bay's Malachi Dupre and Damarious Randall.\n\nCoach Mike McCarthy said he expected the league to evaluate the hits from Thursday's preseason game from the perspective of player safety. When asked to clarify, McCarthy said, \"If I turned them into the league, I don't think they're legal hits.\"\n\nAround the league\n\nRedskins outside linebacker Trent Murphy suffered a torn ACL in his left knee during Thursday's preseason opener and will miss the rest of the season, according to a person with knowledge of the situation. ... A person familiar with the situation said Dolphins rookie linebacker Raekwon McMillan will miss the season with a torn ACL in his right knee. ... A person with knowledge of the diagnosis said Broncos nose tackle Billy Winn will miss the season with a serious right knee injury suffered in Thursday's preseason opener against the Bears. ... The Jaguars released left tackle Branden Albert, who retired then abruptly unretired. The 32-year-old Albert is free to sign with any other NFL team. ... "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Matthews", "score": 5, "id": "331996", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Donovan McNabb"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donovan_McNabb", "score": 3, "id": "337436", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Mark Sanchez"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Sanchez", "score": 3, "id": "343518", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Alshon "Ronald Darby"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Darby", "score": 3, "id": "763026", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Carson Wentz"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carson_Wentz", "score": 1, "id": "1270043", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Note: This column was originally written before the Eagles traded Jordan Matthews to the Buffalo Bills in the NFL's most shuddering Friday-afternoon news dump to date. It has been adapted to reflect Matthews' departure.\n\nBefore we discuss anything, let's call Jordan Matthews exactly what we all know he is: A decent wide receiver.\n\nForget, for a second, his numbers. The ones that, whether like misleading Mark Sanchez completion percentages or rightfully recognized all-time yardage marks from Donovan McNabb, give him good standing in the Philadelphia Eagles record books.\n\n\"Decent\" shouldn't be too generous a title to award Mr. Matthews. We won't even dabble with \"good\" or \"great,\" although you'd be hard pressed to find many \"good\" wide receivers who were as steadily productive, with the same slew of quarterbacks, receiving counterparts and general circumstances, as No. 81 was in Philly.\n\nAnd yet, still, even commending Matthews as mildly competent, let alone making mention of the fourth-year veteran's career highlights, seemed guaranteed to elicit backlash during the dark days of Internet-expert wide-receiver analysis before J-Matt's trip out of town to Eagles North -- er, the Bills -- no less.\n\nIn case you're an Eagles fan who also happens to take up offseason residence beneath a rock, Matthews wasn't exactly a unanimously beloved member of the team leading up to his abrupt departure. Now, the mid-2000s version of all of us -- the ones leeching to every Anquan Boldin trade rumor to hit the streets -- may have embraced a solid, if unspectacular, wideout like Matthews with open arms. Heck, we all did just that in 2014. But there were intriguing opinions out there about why the Eagles should have been willing to move on from Matthews, an impending 2018 free agent.\n\nThen there was me and about three others. (Or so it seemed.)\n\nLet me be clear in noting that, with Ronald Darby (!) now in the fold at a cornerback spot that needed an upgrade like no other, Matthews heading to the Bills isn't sour as much as it is bittersweet -- with a heavy dose of long-term sweetener. Let me also be clear that, come March 2018, I may very well have been OK with the Eagles and Matthews parting ways anyway. By that point, Alshon Jeffery, the big-bodied all-star receiver this city has been craving since the era of everyone's favorite (or disdained) Hall of Fame snub, might turn a Pro Bowl year into a big-money extension.\n\nBut those clamoring for J-Matt to be exiled from the WR depth chart -- for the Eagles to thrust proven depth out of town -- just to prove a point about Matthews being overrated? I hope, now that their scapegoat is actually gone, they will respect who and what Jordan Matthews was for this team and this city. (The fact that he was merely a three-year, semi-starting receiver here should speak volumes, too.)\n\nHow did factions of fans so suddenly develop distaste for Matthews? Maybe, with a glimpse at an unusually talented WR lineup, they saw no need for any remnants of a flawed and underwhelming past. Maybe, for reasons nowhere to be found in other free-agency plunges, they were worried about a future hurdle for Howie Roseman's cap management. Maybe, with some degree of sense, they wanted the Eagles not to overvalue a guy who's had some untimely drops and didn't warrant the No. 1 job he was forced to shoulder early in his career.\n\nBut just because Matthews was an imperfect wideout and has now been shipped elsewhere doesn't mean he isn't worthy of some respect. It doesn't mean Eagles fans shouldn't, you know, be thankful they could root for him. And, really, beyond those statistical debates or financial concerns, was there an Eagle outside of, say, Matthews' handshake buddy Carson Wentz who made himself more likable?\n\nThe in-game hiccups were frustrating, but you're telling me the no-nonsense, team-first attitude that accompanied his 225 catches, 2,673 yards and 19 touchdowns in three years stood for nothing?\n\nIf Matthews were wearing midnight green in 2017, I know I wouldn't have been so bummed about it. Maybe, just maybe, he would've even won back a few fans with a redefined role on a supremely restocked offense.\n\nNow, Jordan Matthews leaves to fill in for Sammy Watkins out in Buffalo, high-fiving the Eagles' newest starting cornerback as he arrives. He departs amid some polarizing and often unnecessary debate, but he leaves behind a trail that I respect.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2018-03-", "textEnd": 2140, "textStart": 2130}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-10T22:00:00Z", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "source": {"uri": "bleedinggreennation.com", "title": "Bleeding Green Nation", "id": "6261"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:05:00", "url": "https://www.bleedinggreennation.com/2017/8/11/16121912/jordan-matthews-trade-philadelphia-eagles-wide-receiver-nfl-buffalo-bills-ronald-darby-news", "storyUri": "eng-3355470", "id": "8838409", "image": "https://cdn0.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/Y4fPnQjd2tjequtTihQ7iaw9Xx4=/466x25:3185x1449/fit-in/1200x630/cdn2.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_asset/file/9023837/usa_today_9536833.jpg", "date": "2017-08-10", "time": "22:00:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Gaines and a second-round draft pick.\n\nIn exchange for Matthews and a third-round selection in the 2018 NFL Draft, the Eagles received cornerback Ronald Darby from Buffalo.\n\nWorking with rookie quarterback Carson Wentz, Matthews had 73 receptions for 804 yards and three touchdowns in 14 games for the Eagles in 2016, missing two contests because of an ankle injury.\n\nMatthews joined the Eagles as a second-round selection in the 2014 NFL Draft after setting an SEC single-season record for receptions and SEC career records for receptions and receiving yards at Vanderbilt.\n\nAfter catching 67 passes for 872 yards and eight touchdowns as an NFL rookie, Matthews had 85 receptions for 997 yards and eight touchdowns in 2015. He'd been Philadelphia's top wide receiver for the past two seasons.\n\nDuring the offseason, the Eagles added wide receivers Alshon Jeffery and Torrey Smith in free agency and drafted wide receivers Mack Hollins and Shelton Gibson in April.\n\nMatthews played in the Eagles' preseason opener on Thursday night against the Green Bay Packers and caught three passes for 18 yards.\n\nMatthews is entering the final season of his rookie contract.\n\nWith the departure of Watkins, Buffalo will have a nearly new wide-receiver corps in 2017. Gaines and the No. 2 pick in the 2018 draft, the Rochester Democrat and Chronicle reported.\n\n\"We're excited,\" McMiller said. \"We're ecstatic.\"\n\nThe Bills hired a new general manager, Brandon Beane, in May, and he is overhauling the organization.\n\n\"We kind of had an idea about him trying to rebuild the whole team,\" McMiller said. \"We're definitely excited about going over to L.A. That's what you do in this business. You put one step in front of the other and you move on. I asked them to continue to trust me and our decisions, in terms of what we're doing, and we need to be focused on what's in front of us.\"\n\nGeneral manager Brandon Beane said Friday he had been receiving trade calls about Watkins since Beane was hired in May, days after the Bills declined Watkins' fifth-year contract option for 2018. Beane presented the Los Angeles Rams' proposal -- a 2018 second-round pick and cornerback E.J. Gaines in exchange for Watkins and a 2018 sixth-round pick -- to McDermott and owner Terry Pegula after the Bills' preseason loss Thursday night to the Minnesota Vikings.\n\n\"I'm always going to listen,\" McDermott said of the trade proposal. \"Brandon's job, and his staff's, is they go out and find players. And it's our job to develop the players. So as a football coach, it's my job as Brandon approaches me with a potential situation, to listen. I'm protective of our players. I'm very protective of our players, and it's got to be the right deal, the right situation for us to do something like this.\n\n\"I feel like we're moving in the right direction, I honestly believe that. And I would end by saying this: I have the ultimate trust in Brandon and his staff.\"\n\nQuarterback Tyrod Taylor, who loses his top receiver in Watkins, and running back LeSean McCoy both echoed McDermott's trust in Beane in making the right deal.\n\n\"I have faith in our management and I have faith in Coach McDermott that they made a decision based on the betterment of this team. Like I said, definitely just surprised that everything happened. It just happened so fast,\" Taylor said.\n\n\"The good thing about that is it's past my pay grade,\" McCoy said. \"Those guys make the decisions for our team. As players and coaches, they coach and we play. That's how it works.\"\n\nMcCoy, who was traded from the Philadelphia Eagles in 2015 for linebacker Kiko Alonso, said he can relate to Watkins in that Watkins was dealt for \"a guy he's probably better than\" in wide receiver Jordan Matthews. The Bills acquired Matthews on Friday along with Philadelphia's 2018 third-round pick for Darby.\n\n\"If you compare the two, it's obvious [that] you can agree who is better,\" McCoy said of Watkins and Matthews.\n\nThe Bills' two trades Friday give the team a total of six selections in the first three rounds of the 2018 draft. However, the deals could weaken Buffalo's chances of improving on their 7-9 record from last season.\n\nAsked Friday if the Bills are better off for the upcoming season after making the moves, Beane said, \"you can make an argument either way.\" Beane also pushed back against the idea that Buffalo is not putting the best team on the field in 2017 in order to move on from quarterback Taylor and find his replacement in the draft next spring.\n\n\"It doesn't say anything,\" said Beane about what the trade means for Taylor. \"Everybody's forgetting [signing Anquan] Boldin last week. This is not a throw-in-the-towel thing at all. Somebody mentioned that somebody said that out there, and honestly, that's annoying to me. You don't know me if you think I'm throwing in the towel. When I go out there and play pingpong, whatever I'm doing, I'm not throwing in the towel. If we're throwing in the towel, we're not trying to get a starting receiver back.\n\n\"To your question on Tyrod, it's nothing. We got Anquan, who we added. I told you, I honestly believe he's a Hall of Famer. He still can play in this league. Jordan Matthews is a starting receiver. If you look at his numbers and what he's done, those aren't anything to laugh at. So Tyrod will get every opportunity to lead this team, and we're all rooting for him. It's our best interest.\"\n\nMcDermott understands Bills' fans frustrations about another potential rebuilding season after the franchise has missed the playoffs for the past 17 seasons.\n\n\"I get it,\" McDermott said. \"I absolutely get it. That's why I didn't sleep [Thursday] night, because these are tough decisions. As I said before, I'm a part of that [playoff drought]. When I signed my name on the dotted line, I became a part of that 17-year time period. I see the RVs pulled out here every game. I heard about it, and then [Thursday night] I experienced it.\n\n\"I'm invested. I feel what they feel. We're building a football team. We're building a football team that we want to compete in the short and the long term and to be good for a long time. Sometimes that's a day-to-day process and sometimes those are not easy decisions from a leadership standpoint. I understand where [the fans] are coming from. That said, we're going to compete like crazy.\"", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3355364", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T22:28:00Z", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "source": {"uri": "espn.com.au", "title": "ESPN.com", "id": "5195"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:41:00", "url": "http://www.espn.com.au/nfl/story/_/id/20317203", "storyUri": "eng-3355364", "id": "8772377", "image": "http://a2.espncdn.com/combiner/i?img=%2Fphoto%2F2017%2F0622%2Fr223116_1296x729_16%2D9.jpg", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "22:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}
